Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: It was chosen mainly for performance reasons (when generating proofs, not when running it on a PC). But it has some nice advantages such as the ability to run multiple programs within the same proof without allowing one program to interfere with the others.

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content:
Please correct me if I'm wrong (not very familiar with those two frameworks):
- K Framework is a framework for formal verification (and can be used to design languages easy to formally verify). Cairo, on the other hand, is not designed to address the formal verification problem, but to design provable statements (assuming the Cairo program really describe the wanted statement). Formal verification can be used to ensure a program describes some specific statement, but we don;t provide such a tool.
- Circom circuits is a framework to describe statements, which are compiled to zkSNARK circuits. Using "simple" circuits is very similar to using ASICs, it soves a specific problem very well, but you need a different circuit (and thus a different verifier/prover) if you changed the proven statement. Cairo, on the other hand, is uses a CPU like architecture (a universal circuit). Writing in Cairo is like writtingin the assembly language of a CPU, you can describe as many program as you want, and execute them all on the same CPU. Similarly, a single Cairo Prover/Verifier can be used for all Cairo programs.

Author: w3tester
Content: Hello all, great pleasure to join the channel and congrats on the release of CairoüòÄ  I have a question regarding the on-chain proof verification part. As is known, the STARK proof is much larger than a SNARK proof‚Äîit may be something as large as 100KB? If people want to verify this proof on e.g. Ethereum, do they need to send the proof to the verifier as a transaction? If so, would the data block be too large for Ethereum? Please feel free to correcting me if I got it wrong. Thank you!

Author: sg7389
Content:
I guess the upcoming "Proving Service" would be the person in charge of sending tx with the STARK proof payload (ofc if a Cairo tx includes recursive STARK for anonymous tx, the end user as well has to prove in her device tho)

The size of STARK proof would be AFAIK around 20KB~100KB depending on the complexity of circuit (hash invocations count), but the order is log scale.

I'm optimistic for calldata usage because the eth2 phase1 can have data shards and it would be a game changer.

Author: w3tester
Content: And I understood the average block size of Ethereum is around 20-30KB. Don't think it is economic to use one block for one proof. That would be too expensive. I guess there will be some off-chain/L2 solutions to handle the proof data? But then what is the role of the on-chain verifier smart contract?

Author: sg7389
Content:
A data-available scaling solution (Rollup) inevitably stores off-loaded data into calldata. There's no way to avoid it IMHO.

Your suggestion of Ethereum block limit looks fair enough for me. I also want to know some community opinion.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The size of a STARK proof is ~70KB, so we split it into a few Ethereum transactions (so that it doesn't have to fit in one block). On the other hand, the size of the proof almost doesn't change if you increase the size of the computation being proven. So a prover service may take several programs and send only one proof attesting to the validity of all of the programs. This means that the cost of sending the proof to the blockchain is actually amortized between the programs included in the proof (which can make it really cheap).

Hello!

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content:
Hi @Renaud Lifchitz ,  what do you by an example?

Author: sshine#7158
Content: Question: If Cairo is a suitable blockchain language, where are the examples of how to express contract-related things? The first few demos seem to cover array summation and puzzles.

Author: sshine#7158
Content: I can't see the examples on cairo-lang.org that relate to "Cairo's zero-knowledge proof system, which will provide massive scalability to ethereum." -- where do I look for the Cairo-Ethereum tangent?

Author: sshine#7158
Content: Question: Is this somehow related to https://github.com/AU-COBRA/ConCert ?

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content:
I would not say Cairo is a "blockchain language". Moreover, it is as related to blockchain as python is.
So what is Cairo?

Let's start with something else. I want to verify on Ethereum x86 program executions. I could write in solidity a simulator of x86, or maybe I could just write in solidity a contract that can verifier x86 execution traces, provided to it at call data.
In both cases the gas cost would be (at least) linear with the length of the execution trace.

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content: And as you can see, this does not make much sense, as any one would prefer to write the logic directly in solidity, to avoid the overhead of x86 simulation.

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content: With Cairo, on the other hand, you can verify program execution with gas expenses logarithmic with the execution length:

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content: This allows you to offload heavy computation from your solidity contract to a Cairo program, and  use the computation result trustlessly and gas efficiently inside your contract.

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content:
For example, assume you want to connect your dApp to a big key-value database (billions of records), and allow the contract to "query" the database trustelssly. The simplest solution would be to store the entire database in you dApps contract storage. But this would be very expensive.
An alternative is to store on your dApp contract only the hash of your database, and keep the database offchain. Whenever there is a need to pass (trustlesly) a record from the offchain database to the smart-contract you prove to it instead that you used a Cairo program which queried a database having the same hash kept onchain, and the value of the required key there is <value>.

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content: So although Cairo is *not* a blockchain language, A smart-contract can enable much more if it offloads work to Cairo. This is very similar to using Oracles, but without putting your trust on them.

Author: sshine#7158
Content:
Wow, this is a very helpful example.

So you can make an on-chain verifiable lookup into an off-chain database using only checksums and logarithmic computation in proportion to the size of the database?

If a Solidity -> Cairo backend exists, does that mean you can create off-chain proofs about your contract?

Author: sshine#7158
Content: I'm sorry, I'm still adapting to the ZK way of thinking. You do create off-chain proofs, but you only publish the hash. Can you then, on Ethereum, make a transaction that only goes through if hashes align, or is the verification made in another layer on top?

Author: sshine#7158
Content: It is one thing to publish a transaction containing a hash that could only have been made if you did the proper lookup, and it is another thing to have that transaction necessarily `REVERT`  if it isn't the case.

Author: sshine#7158
Content: Full disclosure: I might be more interested in writing a Sword -> Cairo back-end because Sword is a much smaller derivatives language. This could perhaps work as motivation for others to write a Solidity -> Cairo, which I would be happy to contribute to, but won't have time to lead.

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content:
Absolutely @sshine ,
you can think about the on-chain verifier (in this case) as something containing a function `verify(proof, db_hash, key, value)`, and if the `proof` does not satisfy the statement "I know a db which has hash digest `db_hash`, and it has <`value`> at <`key`>", it reverts.

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content:
Actually, because the verifier is universal, looks something as follows:
`verify(proof, cairo_program_hash, outpub_blob)` and it reverts if the proof does not prove the statement "I know a cairo program with hash digest `cairo_program_hash` and some private input to this program making it output `output_blob`".

Author: sshine#7158
Content: Mind-blowing.

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content: For the case above you can think `output_blob` encodes (`db_hash`, `key`, `value`). This encoding is defined by the `cairo_program`.

Author: sshine#7158
Content: I'm going to come back to this Discord in the weekend and ask more about what it means to make a back-end for Cairo. The use-cases I see for Sword are less storage and an easier way to bootstrap oracles.

Author: sshine#7158
Content: And provable outcome, being the main motivator. üòÖ

Author: sshine#7158
Content: In case anyone else comes along and wants to focus on a Solidity -> Cairo translation, I am highly interested in extracting both the Ethereum ABI and the Solidity AST into stand-alone Haskell libraries. There are some decent resources in the 'hevm' package, but the dependency footprint is not super light.

Author: sshine#7158
Content: Older versions of Solidity tend to stick around for a long time because contracts live long and because of the cost of code auditing. (E.g. basic OpenZeppelin ERC20 contracts were 0.5.x earlier this year when Solidity was 0.7; they seem to be <0.8 now.)

Author: sshine#7158
Content: ...so probably it'd be sane to maintain one module per AST version, and an abstract representation underneath made with parameterised ADTs, nothing fancier.

Author: sshine#7158
Content: I'm out! Talk to you in a few days! üôÇ

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The two main differences are (1) Cairo is Turing-complete (which means you can basically write whatever you want, including unbounded loops, recursion, random access memory, and so on) and (2) Cairo is compiled to byte code (like normal programming languages) which is then proven using STARK, rather than compiled to an arithmetic circuit (an implication of this is that you can put multiple **different** programs in one proof).

Author: sg7389
Content:
Can I confirm my understanding?

1. Cairo manages only one Rollup and the commitment size is up to 70KB even if so many programs are on it.

2. Cairo programs can interact with other Cairo program via CALL-ish bytecode. In other words, Cairo has composability within a Rollup.

3. "Querying L2 from L1" composability which is mentioned above as "trustless oracle" is possible. And so how about "Refering L1 from Cairo programs"?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
At this point, Cairo is a language which allows you to prove things and record the proof on-chain, as Michael explained above. In the future it'll likely be extended to be more EVM-like, allowing you to do the stuff you mentioned, such as talking to other programs (in the future: "contracts") and talking to L1. 

As an example, take the first point you mentioned - Cairo allows you to batch different runs of different programs to one proof of ~70KB which is verified on-chain. But it's not a Rollup. You can implement Rollup in Cairo, but Cairo itself is not a Rollup.

Author: _mezzo_
Content: When will be Cairo extended to support contracts?

Author: sshine#7158
Content: @mezzo: When we make a Solidity -> Cairo or similar backend. üôÇ

We can put a lot of Cairo programs (e.g., DB querying trustless oracles) with almost-constrant cost, right? So connecting arbitrary DBs into dapps would be very popular paradigm.

Suppose we will have recursive STARK on the Cairo Rollup, "reasonable L2 dapps + Cairo DB" paradigm as well could be implied, maybe?

side note: I understood the Cairo for Rollups are Cairo programs with token deposit/withdrawal and data-availability, and the Cairo for DBs are Cairo programs without token deposit/withdrawal and data-availability.

Author: webbandflow
Content: what would it take to have a verifier running in a Substrate runtime?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Nice! Yes, your program looks sound. The proof of your Cairo program will convince the verifier that the government signed on your year of birth and that it's <= 2003, but will not reveal the actual year of birth üôÇ
The way to handle inputs is using the output builtin üôÇ Change the hard-coded public keys and current years to locals which are set by the hint (like the yob and signature), but unlike the yob and signature output them. Everything that you output is seen by the verifier so that once it gets the proof it'll know that it proves that **you** were at least 18 at **2021**. This way the same program can be used for everyone else, without changing the source code.
We plan to provide (coming soon üôÇ ) a service that gets executions of Cairo programs, generates the proof and sends them to a blockchain verifier. This way, not only you'll have your proof verified, but you'll be able to use this fact on-chain to interact with other contracts if you want.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Hi, indeed, as you've noticed, the hints aren't necessary to verify the soundness of the program, but I agree that they would have helped to learn how to write similar programs.
The main reason why we didn't publish the hints was that the way we wrote them we used code from our StarkEx backend (which is not open source) and it wasn't easy to separate between the two.
Another reason is that we now tend to believe that the "right" way one should write a Cairo program is slightly different than what we did there - hints should mainly be used for library functions, and possibly parsing the inputs in `main()` but not throughout the code (this makes it easier to avoid soundness mistakes).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Over time we will publish more tutorials and examples. Also, if you have concrete questions on how to write code or best practices, don't hesitate to ask them here üôÇ

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Hi @mnaei , we don't have an `elif` construct at the moment (probably we will, in a future version), but `elif` is just syntactic sugar to writing another `if` block inside the `else`-part of the first `if`, so you can do that.
Another thing that we don't currently have is booleans so you can't write complicated if statements (but again, you can easily overcome this by using nested `if`s)
Also, notice that we have a #deleted-channel channel here, so you can use it if you have more playground-related questions.

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214

Author: Michael Riabzev#1214
Content:
I did not dive deep into the implementation/algorithm, but I can suggest a guideline.
What can go wrong if somebody changes completely the hints in the code?
If the the damage is bounded only to the Cairo program not being satisfied - no harm is done.
If it would allow the Cairo program to be convinced of a false statement - this is a soundness issue.

One (bad) example could be a program calculating the maximal number in some vector. Of course, if you do all the comparison only in the hints, changing their direction would result in the Cairo program being convinced the minimal number is actually the maximal (soundness issue).

Additionally, you can use range-checks to verify such inequalities (see the exercise): https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/builtins.html#range-checks

Author: spapini#3824
Content:
Yes, I believe it is not sound, since the prover can choose a wrong path in get, and return empty, even if the element exists.

Cairo does support comparison actually, I think you have some functions in starkware/common/math.cairo

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: In the current setting (before we have a more EVM-like system), each proof is stateless and independent on the blockchain state. So any two Cairo runs are completely independent. It's up to the Ethereum contract to manage the state updates (e.g., store the "current" Merkle root, make sure this is the "old root" mentioned in the proof's program output and then update the Ethereum storage with the new root).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: We haven't published one yet, but we will. The documentation that was published is on the language itself and how to write Cairo programs.

Author: sidhujag
Content: thanks I understand a L1 consensus system would want to update the account root, and I also understand having two provers run their own proving which makes sense as well, but how would the execution verification differ if tx A was executed before tx B versus tx B executed before tx A? both combinations are "valid" but we want A->B and verification should enforce that.. is there a state root thats output from cairo as well or is it just an execution hash and how can you derive the order of state internally regarding data?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: It's up to the specific Cairo program to output the root-before and root-after of the Merkle tree (and only if it needs "storage" and in StarkEx2.0 we actually chose to maintain two different Merkle trees). Then the Ethereum contract can update its state. The final order is determined by the order of the Ethereum transactions to the dapp contract.

Author: perama
Content:
Hey, cairo is really cool. Might I ask a question?

Can different proofs from different programs be compressed into a single proof for submission to the verifier?

E.g I can see from https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/issues/2 that soon there will be a prover that can accept a trace that a developer produces for their program. Looking at https://etherscan.io/tx/0x654361d7e484e9cfef40e5925ac90d364def32df4fadb2b0d35abf964a9c8ea4 it seems like the proof being submitted there is large. Is it true that the proof in that transaction could contain the different programs e.g. for 2 or more completely unrelated systems, and they can share the cost by paying the person who submits the transaction?

E.g. How I see it: From the examples with the 15-puzzle. Two players could generate a trace, then a proof each of their solution which then goes to an agent who combines them and submits a single proof. Furthermore, players of a 24-puzzle and a 35-puzzle could also join in and bring the cost down within a single aggregate proof. Each new proof being added doesn't add much to the size of the final proof. Then the verfier contract logs the output of the proofs in a fact registry which then each separate dapp can look at for game logic.

Is that about right?

Author: perama
Content:
If the above is true, would it follwo that each dapp user would pay to verify the claim in the fact registry, for on the order of a few dollars, citing their claim and the proof they had originally generated locally / sent to the aggregator. 

As in like this:
https://etherscan.io/tx/0x5618ffcc6ea14a98043295dd54919cf2c11533afe4c82b47a36ba79a762bac60

The smart contract could then respond to the claim if it was confirmed valid and proceed with game logic.

Author: vanta#2387
Content: Hey, I'm sorry if this is a stupid question, but back in 2017 I read that STARKS use 130 GB of RAM, is that still the case with cairo or can it generate ZK Proofs on a normal machine now? Are there any more resources where I can read about this?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Exactly üôÇ That's the idea behind the Cairo GPS (https://www.cairo-lang.org/cairo-for-blockchain-developers/). You can put two (or more) unrelated programs in one proof and share the cost of the proof (which hardly increases when you increase the size of the computation, due to the logarithmic nature of the STARK protocol).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Yes. It's also worth noting that registring a fact on-chain is not entirely negligible (20K gas just for the storage), so if you are able to batch within an app, the cost per action will be reduced (but I'm sure that Cairo will make even small apps with no batching more efficient).

Author: EliBenSasson#9612
Content: First, the 130GB RAM was for a huge proof, not for small ones. While it's still the case that larger computations require more memory, you can see here a STARK codebase that let's you prove the correct computation of 768K hashes on a computer with 16 GB or RAM. https://github.com/starkware-libs/ethSTARK

Hi @Sergii Bomko, you can find a short description of each contract here: https://github.com/starkware-libs/starkex-contracts/tree/master/evm-verifier.
Where to start depends on what you're looking for:
If you're looking for the core STARK verification, you should start with https://github.com/starkware-libs/starkex-contracts/blob/master/evm-verifier/solidity/contracts/cpu/CpuVerifier.sol.ref which is the implementation of Cairo verifier in START, or even https://github.com/starkware-libs/starkex-contracts/blob/master/evm-verifier/solidity/contracts/StarkVerifier.sol.ref (used by the previous file) which is a generic STARK verifier (not Cairo specific).
If you really want the math parts you have https://github.com/starkware-libs/starkex-contracts/blob/master/evm-verifier/solidity/contracts/FriLayer.sol implementing the FRI protocol inside STARK and https://github.com/starkware-libs/starkex-contracts/blob/master/evm-verifier/solidity/contracts/cpu/layout0/CpuConstraintPoly.sol, which implements the Cairo AIR constraints.
If you're looking for more Cairo things then you have the GPS contract https://github.com/starkware-libs/starkex-contracts/blob/master/evm-verifier/solidity/contracts/gps/GpsStatementVerifier.sol responsible for handling multiple programs in one proof, for example.
Hope this helps üôÇ

Author: sergii.bomko
Content: Hi guys, question about "Voting system" tutorial. I'm curious about the logic, you manipulated with Merkle roots of public keys(eg to prevent double vote), but what about state of the voting. I suppose for real simple voting system we would store votes(Merkle root of yes/no amounts). Is it right?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
In the simple system, we output the total number of yes and no for the entire batch. You can imagine a solidity contract that keeps track of those counters, so the current system is usable.
Of course, for a real system you may have different requirements, such as storing who voted what (and then a yes/no Merkle tree will indeed help), more than 2 choices, more than one question (e.g., 4 yes/no/don't-care questions) or weighting on the voters. All of these can be implemented in Cairo (but will require some more work üôÇ )

Author: sergii.bomko
Content: I see, thanks. from my point of view I think how to decrease smart contracts state changes as much as possible. that is why I thought about Merkle root on L2

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Yes, this will do it (you can even use a simple hash chain: `hash(hash(public_key_root, yes_votes), no_votes)` and this will be the only state stored on-chain)

Author: sergii.bomko
Content: Hi guys, I'm curious how StarkEx handles double spend issue? What part of the solution handles such errors? (eg I send two transactions in one batch)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Do you mean doing the same transfer more than once, or doing two different transfers,  where the user didn't have the money for both of them?

Author: sergii.bomko
Content: second version

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: We use a DictAccess array (see the third Hello Cairo page) to track the vault balances. The first transaction we remove the funds from the user, so the second one will fail

Author: sergii.bomko
Content:
In the case will cairo run fail(1) OR do you exclude the transaction from output(2)? 
1 - how do you resubmit batch in order to produce  successful output?
2 - how do you handle failed transaction after cairo execution? I suppose it should be visible somewhere

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: In that case, Cairo will fail (so you probably won't try to generate a proof in the first place)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: In the StarkEx system, we simply reject invalid transactions before they get into the pipeline

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
The only things that may fail (without being able to know it'll fail) are deposits, as the user may cancel a deposit before the proof was accepted on-chain. In that case you just regenerate the batch, without the user's deposit.
Other transactions (transfer, settlement, withdrawal) don't have this problem

Author: sergii.bomko
Content: Did I get it right? You have some kid of logic in StarkEx engine which prevent any type of errors before batch processing? So you throw an error during transactions submission

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Right

Author: sidhujag
Content: Does Cairo define what a leaf of the merkle tree looks like in terms of the state root tree or is that flexible? The state transitions themselves that are sent to L1 can those not be balance adjustments instead? There would be less of those as if the leafs are accounts you would only need to send accounts affected (similar to your Cairo storage post above where only modified storage slots are sent instead of every modification from executions)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Cairo as a language has no notion of Merkle trees, the Merkle trees are simply a set of library functions written in Cairo. As such, it's fully flexible, and you can change it in any way you want (the hash function used must be supported in Cairo, so currently should be Pedersen).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: I didn't really understand the second part, but as with the Merkle trees, this is also entirely up to the Cairo program - you can decide exactly what data to put on-chain.

Author: sidhujag
Content: ah i see I thought that the state root was an artifact computed as an output of every cairo program so if its context specific thats good as we can change the merkle tree representations in application specific ways correct?

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content:
As Lior said, yes. You can write whatever you want in Cairo, the same way you can write whatever you want in Python.
In that sense, the question about the data-availability is unrelated to Cairo but to the specific implementation you will be using. IIUC what you're saying, then generally speaking you are correct. In the context of a Rollup system, in which the data required to construct the state is publish on L1 in each state transition, one can send only the changes to the balances.

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content: Currently there is no published c++ verifier

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Cairo has no native support for strings. You do have pointers, so you can use them to represent strings. Either one char per field element or pack 31 chars per element. The first is easy to implement, the second will require some more complicated library functions. And it's *not* clear that the second will be more efficient by the way, it depends on what you do with the strings. May I ask what do you want to implement?

Author: matoken.eth
Content: I work at ENS and we are currently looking into supporting l2 integration for various roll-up solutions

Author: matoken.eth
Content: The idea is to allow ENS domain owners to set a resolver on l2 which store eth record for ENS names. So wondering basic key value store can be written using Cairo

Author: matoken.eth
Content: The more detailed write up is at https://medium.com/the-ethereum-name-service/a-general-purpose-bridge-for-ethereum-layer-2s-e28810ec1d88

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: So for domains, I'd suggest storing each part of the domain as one field element (either the hash of the string or the ASCII characters). It depends on the exact requirements, but it's very possible that the Cairo code does not have to deal with the actual ASCII strings.

Author: webbandflow
Content: Are there examples of programming elliptic curves in cairo programs?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Not that I know of. If you're familiar with the formulas of an elliptic curve, it should be relatively straight forward to implement them in Cairo (as all you need is field operations). Note that while implementing an elliptic curve over the field used by Cairo is easy, implementing elliptic curves over other fields is more complicated (and more expensive).

Author: ryanberckmans
Content:
I'm trying to understand the expectations for scaling end-user L1 gas costs on StarkNet, especially vs. optimistic rollups.

It seems that L1 gas costs for end-users of Arbitrum and StarkNet are currently within an order of magnitude of each other.

For example, Arbitrum reports that a Uniswap v2 swap on the Arbitrum Community Chain uses about 2k L1 gas today vs. I've seen data points from StarkWare ranging from 400 gas to 2k gas per tx.

I think I understand that the size of StarkWare's aggregated proofs is logarithmic in the size of the transaction batch being secured. How do we expect this scaling to manifest in terms of end-user costs? Is the idea that in five years when the gas price is 50x higher, each StarkNet L2 transaction will use single-digit amounts of L1 gas?

Author: EliBenSasson#9612
Content: That's a terrific question @ryanb . You're correct in saying that the amortized gas cost of proving goes to 0 exponentially fast with the number of txs batched. Now, it really depends on (1) batch size and (2) L1 footprint of non-proof data, which in worst case scales linearly with #txs. We don't yet know the numbers for either (1) or (2). I'll say this, we currently have the lowest amortized gas cost per tx in production systems, and I conjecture this will be the case also in 1 year and in 5 years.

Author: urik#1734
Content: Adding to that: the zkrollup demo we did for reddit had an amortized cost if 315 gas/tx. Had we run the same system in Validium mode (offchain data) , it would have dropped to 17 gas/tx (!).

Author: ryanberckmans
Content:
Thank you!

You guys must be looking forward to (hopefully) showing that (2), in practice, scales sublinearly with #txs.

Are there other open research questions that will determine if we're ultimately able to realize a fully generalized, permissionless L2 with sublinear L1 gas scaling in #txs?

Author: urik#1734
Content: We've shown that on Mainnet - done üôÇ

Author: sidhujag
Content: the 17 gas per tx was shown here if you want to see https://www.reddit.com/r/ethereum/comments/i01sjk/starkwares_submission_to_reddits_scaling_bakeoff/ @ryanb

Author: gaxi#1123
Content:
I followed the ‚ÄùHow Cairo Works‚Äù and ran this code
```
func main():
    [ap] = 25; ap++
    %{
        memory[ap] = sqrt(memory[ap - 1])
    %}
    [ap - 1] = [ap] * [ap]; ap++
    ret
end
```
then I got this  error
```NameError: name 'sqrt' is not defined```

I also tried this code and it worked fine.

```
func main():
    [ap] = 25; ap++
    %{ 
            from starkware.python.math_utils import sqrt
            memory[ap] = sqrt(memory[ap - 1], 26)
    %}
    [ap - 1] = [ap]  * [ap]; ap++
    ret
end    
```
But I guess this isn't the best way. Does anyone have an advise?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
You can use python's sqrt function:
```
%{
    from math import sqrt
    memory[ap] = int(sqrt(memory[ap - 1]))
%}
```

Author: mnaei#4063
Content: I have a bit of a theoretical question. How are Zero Knowledge Proof and Homomorphic Encryption related? It seems like ZKP is polynomial time verification for Non-Polynomial HE execution. But how do they relate to each other fundamentally? Do they share the same math? And can ZKP programming languages such as Cairo be extended to execution HE computation?

Author: EliBenSasson#9612
Content: That's a terrific question. Theoretically, Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) implies ZK for the complexity class NP, but the reverse direction isn't known (and not believed to hold). I don't know if FHE also implies succinct ZK and transparent ones, like ZK-STARKs (suspect not). The biggest difference these days is that FHE is currently far less efficient than ZKPs, for a given computation.

Author: mnaei#4063
Content: From my understanding, would it be fair to summarize that FHE is not necessarily a super class of ZKP due to it's lack of succinctness in proof and transparency in execution?

Author: EliBenSasson#9612
Content: I think that's a fair statement but should point out I'm not familiar enough with recent progress on FHE to be sure.

Author: EliBenSasson#9612
Content: So would be happy to hear what others know about your question

Author: PR0XY#0128
Content:
Hey @EliBenSasson! Currently building a DeFi project on L2 and trying to do some research into the existing solutions. Right now I'm pretty committed to zkrollups > optimistic, but I've only looked into Matter Labs + zksync so far. Given that the commitment is pretty big (you have to learn a whole new language) I'm trying to understand which solution to go with.

Can you give me a brief overview for why someone would choose Starkware over zksync? Both look (on the surface) to be around the same place in terms of language maturity & implement zk rollups. Are you guys on mainnet? If not, when do you plan on doing a mainnet launch? Sorry for the barrage of questions, just not sure how to navigate the resources on the website efficiently

Author: urik#1734
Content:
Hi @PR0XY.
We're not exactly at the same place as zksync. Cairo is in production on Mainnet and Turing-complete. That cannot be said of zksync.
We power DeversiFi on mainnet. next week going live with dYdX, and two weeks later with Immutable. So, well ahead of the competition.
Note that on our Cairo Playground you can write your business logic, have it STARK-proven. Then, on Ropsten, you can have the proof verified, and the result of your computation - its Fact - registered in the FactRegistry smart contract.
In short, you can code a scalable dapp with Cairo today

Author: urik#1734
Content: Note the SHARP (Shared Prover) functionality, also live on Ropsten. This is transparent to you, but its importance cant be overstated: it allows multiple dapps to prove their state transition in a single STARK proof. That means they can all share the gas costs of verifying proofs on-chain. For production systems, that is savings in the $Ms/year.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Not sure exactly what you mean, but in general proofs cannot interact with the outside world and you need additional protocols to prove things about such interaction (for example, if the REST API server signs its reposnse it may be possible).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Yes, today an app backend can invoke SHARP (previously named GPS), which registers a fact on-chain. Then any smart contract can query this fact. We will soon publish a full tutorial for such an application (with a backend and a solidity contract). It's not possible to start this process on-chain (we do have plans in which Cairo will become a blockchain language and then the interaction with it will be more similar to on-chain interaction. See https://medium.com/starkware/on-the-road-to-starknet-a-permissionless-stark-powered-l2-zk-rollup-83be53640880)

Author: spapini#3824
Content: lol. You are right that the cairo trace is embedded into the AIR trace almost as is. There are more stuff in the AIR. I think the fundemental take here is that the constraints of cairo never change. They don't depend on the program, they are universal. Perhaps you meant that we could add constraints to universal cairo that could somehow optimize loops? We did try to make the constraints optimized, though the issue here is that adding logic to the AIR actually makes it less efficient, so we try to keep it as simple as possible. I talked about it a bit in the previous zk talks

Author: mnaei#4063
Content:
I was hoping someone could provide some clarification. In a zkp circuit, is the circuit itself know by the verifier?

I know the runtime values and arguments are only known to the prover. And the return value of the circuit is known by the verifier.

My intuition/understanding is that the verifier should know the contents of the circuit. Doesn't that potentially leak some information? Or do we run a zkp on the zkp to verify the circuit also?

Author: spapini#3824
Content:
On a regular zkp, yes, the verifier knows the circuit. This makes sense, otherwise, why would the verifier be interested in a result of an unknown program?
If you did want something like that, you could do a recursive proof (i.e. zkp on zkp).
In cairo, the circuit is the cairo vm verifier, not your program. The hash of the program is public, but you could keep the program itself private if you wanted

Author: tkstanczak
Content: I have two questions about the Building a Scalable Cairo-Based Automated Market Maker (AMM) - Cairo:

Author: tkstanczak
Content: 1) what is currently the bess decentralization strategy for batch construction -> is there any way to minimize front running, reordering and censoring trades?

Author: tkstanczak
Content: 2) the solution requires the account state root so it suggests the tokens are all on L2, what is currently the best strategy to get on-chain ERC20 contracts tradable this way? (can they be split into L1 and L2 pools for the sake of moving between L1 and L2 AMM trading?)

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content:
Hi @tkstanczak !
1) It is hard for me to say what is the best decentralization strategy for batch construction but I can give couple of ideas - 
a) The sequencer can first commit to a batch of transactions, and sequence them based on some randomness source (e.g. VeeDo). The proof enforce that the sequence was done correctly and that all transactions in the committed batch were included.
b) Transactions can be submitted with time-locks, and the proof can prove the "reveal" of the transactions.
Those ideas were described here - https://drive.google.com/file/d/1_4-E_i6WIDMNRDIgBIf0YiaJtm33XW9s/view
and I would love to elaborate more if you find it relevant.

Author: tkstanczak
Content: I like a) it can actually sequence from the smallest tradest to the largest (assuming it only deals with AMM)

Author: tkstanczak
Content: b) great, we have a Nubia call on MEV and Cairo, it will be great to conenct it with flashbots research

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content: 2) The post that was released today (this one - https://www.cairo-lang.org/build-a-scalable-cairo-basesd-automated-market-maker/) is a tutorial on how to build a full system using Cairo and SHARP. It was not meant to describe the ideal L1/L2 AMM construction. We will release a different post describing this kind of construction that we find efficient and user friendly in about a week from now.

Author: spapini#3824
Content: filling in the hints is not enough. the AIR constraints require that the union of all accessed memory addresses over all instructions is continuous. In future versions we will automatically add nops that touch those, but it still costs instructions.

Author: .tawarien
Content:
%builtins output

func main(output_ptr : felt*) -> (output_ptr : felt*):
    alloc_locals
    local x = 10
    local c

    if x == 0:
      c = 5
    else:
     %{ids.c = 5%}
     assert x = x
    end
    local y = x + x
    local z = y * y + x
    assert [output_ptr] = x
    assert [output_ptr + 1] = y
    assert [output_ptr + 2] = z
    return (output_ptr=output_ptr + 3)
end

Author: .tawarien
Content: Until now I only ever encountered the "Non continuous segment <segment> at offset <offset>" error, but in the security.py are 4 other potential errors in the same method:  verify_secure_runner. Those seem to be only checked when sending an execution trace to SHARD. It would be nice if verify_secure_runner would be executed after the vm, so that I do not have to send my programs to SHARP each time in order to find out if they contain one of these errors. But this is just a usability suggestion, nothing more.

Author: spapini#3824
Content:
1) The requires ARE checking the state. The state of the system is not just the tree, it's also the total supply of each token. Note that the cairo program uses these values to compute the price. If you didn't check these, we could lie about them and the cairo program would use different prices. Bottom line is that the state isnt necessary a single hash(though it could be). Look at AmmState.

Separating the state to multiple fields makes it easy for the evm contract to reason about it (for example if we wanted to add some L1 functions)

Author: spapini#3824
Content: 2) yes

Author: spapini#3824
Content: 3) A malicious prover could prove a bunch of valid txs, yes. But only valid txs, since cairo verifies it

Author: scooletz
Content:
I have a few question related to MEV, frontrunning and the presentation that @Yael Doweck | StarkWare gave about VeeDoo security. As far as I understand, it's based on  `VDF` where `f^(-1)` is fast to compute and can be used for COMMIT and `f` is slow to compute and can be used for time-locked REVEAL. 
The first step is the sequencer submitting a list of transactions in L1 to its smart contract. Actually `hash(list)` is used to minimize the overhead. The next step is the operator revealing the transactions (performs slow `f`) and provides the proof of execution to the verifier smart contract. 

1) Does the operator perform both REVEAL and execution of the transactions on the state in one program?
2) Is it the `hash(list)` that is included in the Cairo output of the operator program to match the fact later on with the initial one provided by the sequencer? Do I get it right?
3) Is the sequencer and the operator can be treated as the parts of "backend", similar to AMM example?
4) Does it mean that "users" can send commited transactions to a sequencer and later on the whole execution is performed by the backend, as it's capable of revealing them on its own?

Author: .tawarien
Content: Just out of curiosity about how everything works under the hood, are the constraint that make up the Cairo AIR accessible somewhere or do I need to wait until the prover is open sourced to see them?

Author: spapini#3824
Content:
We plan to release a paper soon with all the details explained. Until then, these are the constraints in our public verifier contracts:
https://github.com/starkware-libs/starkex-contracts/blob/master/evm-verifier/solidity/contracts/cpu/layout0/CpuOods.sol

Author: Yael Doweck | StarkWare#7488
Content:
Hi @Scooletz , nice to meet you.
1) In my presentation, the operator only does the reveal and not the execution of the transaction. In that case the proof only attests to the integrity of the computation of the VDF. However, in the future we plan to add VeeDo as builtin to Cairo and then it would be possible to compute both the VDF and the execution in one Cairo program.
2)Yes, it can be done this way.
3)Yes, the sequencer and operator are parts of the backend, they can be implemented both as a centralized or a decentralized entity.
4)Yes, as I mentioned, this will be possible with a VeeDo builtin in Cairo.

Author: spapini#3824
Content:
x/x=1 is a syntactic sugar for x=1√óx. Thus, we consider division by 0 leads to undefined behavior. "if x!= 0" is an efficient way to verify x is non zero.
You can, however, use y=1/x. This is equivalent to x√óy=1, and ensures x has an inverse in the field.

Author: spapini#3824
Content: But jmp if x !=0 in cairo is handled by a few simple constraints in the cairo AIR, since it just means changing the value if a register. i.e., y=c if x!=0 else d, which is simple in air

Author: scooletz
Content: @Yael Doweck | StarkWare I read about VDF VeeDoo a few times and I'd like to confirm my understanding of the security approach in there. As a transaction is REVEALed after a specific period of time (when the `f(tx)` is calculated), the guarantee for no front running is based on including a transaction in a list by sequencer in time lower than the reveal operation. Otherwise, a malicious sequencer could REVEAL all transactions, analyze them and add their own. Do I get it right, that the security is based on this timing of including a `tx` in a sequence that then sequencer commits to by publishing it on-chain? Any user that would notice their transactions not included could raise an issue that there's potential for front-running?

Author: .tawarien
Content: When the bootloader executes/proofs multiple runs of the same programm, does it compute the programm hash once for each run or can it reuse the hash and only compute it once?

Author: Yael Doweck | StarkWare#7488
Content: Yes you are correct. The commitment for a transaction (a concealed transaction) should also contain an expiration time so that the sequencer won't be able to include it in the sequence after the reveal period have passed.

Author: EliBenSasson#9612
Content: @Scooletz another option to use the VDF is to have the sequence of tx's committed to a block B without processing them, take the blockhash h_B of that block, compute a VDF on it s = f(h_B), and use the output s of the VDF as seed to randomly order the tx's already committed to block B, processing them in the new random order. This way, you only compute one single VDF and the initial sequence of tx's in the block is independent of the order in which they're processed.

Author: scooletz
Content:
Thank you. My understanding is that with random ordering we prevent front-running, back-running making it unusable. By unusable I mean that no malicious actor can issue transactions and expect extracting value out of them.
For a while I was thinking what block means, whether it's a blockchain block, but as far as I see it, it could be again a list of transactions with its hash stored in the sequencer smart contract. The flow of the execution would be based not on revealing transactions one after another but by sorting them according to the seed based on the VDF applied to the hash. Do I get this right?

Author: spapini#3824
Content:
You could do something like a separate exchange built in cairo, and let its L2 contract trade in regular UNISWAP like a regular trader, but with compressed trades across the batch. For example, if 100 users traded ETH->USDC in the cairo AMM, the updates state tx would also call UNISWAP with just a single ETH->USDC call.
This is basically Defi Pooling https://medium.com/starkware/defi-pooling-1332ddebff21

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: About the minting of NFTs for Immutable, the way it works is quite simple.

Author: guthl_starkware
Content:
Immutable runs StarkEx2.5 which has a new offchain method call Mint.
This mint method can only be called by Immutable and allows to assign an empty account (also known as vault in our system) a specific assetId to a specific StarkKey (assetId are the way any asset is represented on StarkEx. Happy to dive into the details if you are not familiar).
Two conditions for the operation to be valid:
- The vault is empty
- The bit #251 is set to 1 to specify that it is an offchain minted asset. Every asset coming from L1 have the bit #251 is set to 0.
The last point is important to prevent the ability to mint myself 1000ETH using the minting method

 To be withdrawal, an asset minted offchain must be paired with an L1 contract capable to L1 mint the asset at withdraw time and comply with some predefined format (a double keccak hash for that matter)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
The Cairo AIR (AIR is the STARK equivalent of a circuit) consists of the main CPU and builtins. Builtins can perform simple tasks (such as hash functions) without loss of performance (with respect to writing a dedicated AIR). The idea is that useful primitives will be implemented as builtins and the code will mainly deal with the business logic.
You can read more here: https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/builtins.html

Author: Coventry#0393
Content: How hard would it be to make an AIR for SHA256?  Will the math here carry over to Cairo, or does it critically depend on the field being characteristic 2? https://eprint.iacr.org/2018/046.pdf#page=80

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
You can work in any field. Field of charactersitic 2 may sound nicer but the only thing that easy to do there is bitwise-xor. bitwise-and is not that easy (and you also need integer arithmetic, which is easier to do in fields of larger characteristic).
In both cases it's not an easy AIR (but definitely feasible).

Author: EliBenSasson#9612
Content: To add a bit more to this: symmetric cryptographic primitives like SHA2, Keccak and AES tend to "break algebraic abstractions", meaning that in order to make the primitive cryptographically secure its designers intentionally move between different algebraic worlds, to make it "structureless". Thus, SHA2 mixes operations of mod2^{32} integer arithmetic, XORs, and other operations (Majority, AND, etc.). This has the unfortunate consequence that arithmetization and moving to any finite field costs quite a lot.

Author: EliBenSasson#9612
Content: AES is an interesting special case, it is actually designed to be somewhat GF(2^8)-friendly. But that's the exception.

Author: 0xmichalis
Content: regarding let (local x) = foo(10)

Author: 0xmichalis
Content: how hard is it for the compiler to support local x = foo(10) instead?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
This is a good question. Currently `let x = foo(10)` has another meaning: it makes `x` point to return value struct, so if we have `func foo(z : felt) -> (w1 : felt, w2 : felt)`, then you can write  `x.w1` or `x.w2`.
Given this, having `local x = foo(10)` will be confusing. We can add the syntax `local (x) = foo(10)`  avoiding this problem, or try to find another syntax for getting the return struct.
What do you think?

Author: malchev#6407
Content:
Hm I can't seem to get it to work.  This code for example:

```
%builtins output

from starkware.cairo.common.serialize import array_rfold

func add(el, els : felt*) -> (res):
    return (res=el + [els])
end

func main{output_ptr}():
    alloc_locals

    local array : felt*
    local array_len : felt
    %{
        values = range(1000)
        ids.array = array = segments.add()
        for i,v in enumerate(values):
            memory[array + i] = v
        ids.array_len = len(values)
    %}

    let (sum) = array_rfold(0, array, array_len, 1, add)
    assert [output_ptr] = sum
    let output_ptr = output_ptr + 1

    return ()
end
```

Should work fine but instead I get:

```
Error: Error at pc=30:
Unknown value for memory cell at address 30.
Cairo traceback (most recent call last):
code:22:17: (pc=0:43)
    let (sum) = array_rfold(0, array, array_len, 1, add)
                ^**************************************^
/var/task/starkware/cairo/common/serialize.cairo:23:5: (pc=0:10)
    call abs callback
    ^***************^
```

This errors out at ```call abs callback``` in ```array_rfold```.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: When you write `add` in the line `let (sum) = array_rfold(...` it gives you the offset of the function from the beginning of the program. First convert it to a pc value using `get_label_location(add)` (`get_label_location` is in `starkware.cairo.common.registers.cairo`). Let me know if this works

Author: malchev#6407
Content: That's what I was missing, thank you.  Works now.

Author: tommyz89
Content: Hey everyone, I'm watching ETHGlobal intro to Cairo video and it's mentioned that Cairo does not support privacy yet. However, Ben says that it's quite easy to add and will be added in the future. Assuming privacy is added, does it mean that I can write an NFT token in cairo and token balances/transfers will be private by default?

Author: EliBenSasson#9612
Content: No, that won't suffice. Adding true privacy requires quite a lot. But what kind of privacy do you wish to obtain for an NFT? It is a unique item, so dealing with it privacy is even more complicated than it is for fungible tokens. So what do you have in mind?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
To add to what @EliBenSasson  said, making the proofs private is not enough - it only means that getting a proof won't give you more than the knowledge that the statement being proved is correct, but if the statement *itself* contains private things you'll have a problem. For example, currently, we use Merkle trees of accounts and the statement says it's ok to move from one Merkle root to another. But the Merkle tree itself is built of (unhidden) private information. So information may leak through the statement, even if the proof is zero-knowledge.
ZCash is a good example of building a data structure, which, together with zero-knowledge proofs, allows full privacy (and indeed, it's not account-based).

Author: tommyz89
Content: yeah, NFT was a bad example. I think erc20 is better. I'm thinking how cairo could help in building "private ERC20". Zcash implementation is fairly complex and I'm wondering if cairo could simplify it by any means. From Stark Workshop I remember that proofs contain samples of execution so I guess that's why they can leak data (if I understand it correctly) which @Lior Goldberg mentioned above.

Author: tommyz89
Content: That means proof cannot contain any sensitive data at all. I guess I'm having a hard time understanding how added privacy could work in cairo. Where's the line between privacy (added in the future) and zero-knowledge.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
The proof does not contain sensitive information unless the program explicitly instruct it to.
There are two components in full privacy:
1. The proof has to be ZK. This feature will be added to Cairo in the future (based on need), and it's relatively easy.
2. The data structure storing the tokens should be chosen to allow private transaction (such as the one used by ZCash). This requires a careful design according to the business and privacy requirements.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: In other words, ZK is a property of the proof system. Privacy is about what you're doing*with* the system.

Author: malchev#6407
Content: Hi @Lior Goldberg, I notice that all of the examples in Cairo that I've seen so far aren't tail-recursive, even though they are trivial to write tail-recursively.  It occurred to me that in Cairo TR isn't actually better though, because AP only ever strictly advances.  Is this right?

Author: jonathan.quai
Content: Can I use Ethereum state in a Cairo program? For example, do some computations based on the Ether balance or token balance of a user?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Right, in Cairo tail recursion is not better. However, for a function that returns more than one value, using the tail recursion syntax (`return foo(...)`) may save some instructions.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: To understand this better you can use the tracer where you can see exactly how many steps each instruction takes. We also have a profiler that you can use to compare different codes

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Cairo itself is a stateless programming language, so there are no native instructions that can interact with the blockchain. To write a Cairo program that interacts with the blockchain, see https://www.cairo-lang.org/cairo-for-blockchain-developers/ and for an example https://www.cairo-lang.org/build-a-scalable-cairo-basesd-automated-market-maker/.
(When StarkNet is available, you'll have builtin functions to interact with the blockchain.)

Content: No, since Cairo is verified on-chain, there is no problem just passing the required information to the proof verification

Author: malchev#6407
Content: On the subject of Ethereum, I've been wondering how easy it would be to use STARKs to generate a proof of the validity of the Ethereum blockchain up to a certain block.  This way you can skip verifying the blockchain by yourself without also relying on third parties to attest to it as well.  Would that be doable in Ciaro?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: You can see the instructions on how to run it here: https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/debugging_tricks.html#profile-output-profile-pb-gz

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Verifying the entire blockchain (to the level of an Ethereum full node) is quite complicated: First, you have to verify keccaks, SHA256 and signatures, all require Cairo builtins (in order to make it efficient), then you have to emulate EVM which can be done, but will require a lot of code.
A simpler task is to only verify the blockchain headers and the PoW and rely on the full nodes to verify the EVM execution. This will require a keccak builtin.

Author: malchev#6407
Content: I had missed that too, thank you.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: It's a new feature of this version (v0.1.0)

Author: neokry
Content: I can‚Äôt seem to find examples of comparison operations in the Cairo docs (a > b) (a && b) do these exists? Is there another way to do it because I get an error from the compiler trying to use (>). Sorry if this is a dumb question still new to the language.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Cairo don't have a > operator at the moment, but there are library functions for verifying that a <= b (such as `assert_le` in `math.cairo`) and for checking whether a <= b (such as `is_le` in `math_cmp.cairo`). Both require the `range_check` builtin (see https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_cairo/dict.html#putting-it-all-together).

Content:
We are building a very similar idea to this as a L2 on top of Ethereum - not only the contracts are written in Cairo but also the EVM itself. Since it will be written in Cairo it won't mimic the EVM but will rather be more like an OS. You can read more here - https://medium.com/starkware/on-the-road-to-starknet-a-permissionless-stark-powered-l2-zk-rollup-83be53640880
And we will keep publishing more details soon.

Content:
You can start from looking at the Hello Cairo tutorial. We also have challenges in the Cairo playground (https://www.cairo-lang.org/playground/) that teach the language.
Note that learning Cairo will not teach you how to write Smart Contracts (at least not until StarkNet is ready). At the moment Cairo works in combination with Solidity to create scalable Smart Contracts.

Author: roboteddy
Content: @0xmichalis I think for there to be a way for folks to escape on L1 in the event that the L2 halts or starts misbehaving, transactions affecting L2 balances will need to be written (in small part) to L1, which would tend to limit throughput

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content: You are right - changes to the L2 state will be posted as on-chain data in a format that will allow reconstructing the state for escape. This factor won't limit the size of the L2 state, but the scale the system can offer.

Author: roboteddy
Content: @Tom Brand | StarkWare thanks! once ethereum has data shards, is there a plan to make a version of the escape contract that can accept evidence from on-chain data from any of the shards? or is there a different plan to scale?

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content:
The shards will be used to post data, and then anyone will be able to generate the evidence on the relevant shard. This is still far ahead, but the way I see it is that we will use the shards to offer cheaper data availability solution.
There are more ideas on how to offer better scale re data availability, of course. We will publish more once things will be more concrete.e

Author: bender_3000
Content: It boils down to how data availability is handled.  For rollups all DA is sent to L1 and with Validium its not.

Author: bender_3000
Content: Validium sends the DA to trusted 3rd parties.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: I don't think anyone offers such a service at the moment, but this will probably change once Cairo becomes more mature :)

Author: bender_3000
Content: Yeah that was my thinking. Would the Starkware team be open to providing such a s service, for a fee of course?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Right, in validium you don't put the data on-chain. Instead you wait for enough signatures from a fixed list of third parties (the committee) that they saw the data.
Note that the validity of the transition is verified by the contract (unrelated to the committee mechanism). The only thing you need the committee for, is if you want to exit the system and the operator doesn't let you (then you need the DA info, and you can get it from the committee members).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: This is not on our roadmap at the moment, but we may work with other companies to help them provide this service

Author: Antipesto#1041
Content: Is that it then? Just that data is handled off-chain to increase transaction throughput?

Author: Antipesto#1041
Content: Ahhh okay this makes sense! You have a group of trusted people to oversee the off-chain data to confirm is validity?

Author: bender_3000
Content: It is not confirming its validity in the traditional sense as Cairo its self won't allow you to make a fraudulent proof. It's really just keeping a record of the state changes incase they are needed to allow you to exit to L1. So should the starkservice fail or Starkware tries to censor the transaction you can always reconstruct the state changes and exit to L1.

Author: mongoose#1674
Content: @afm When you say set membership, are you trying to check that a given element is part of a set? If so, the portion of the docs about taking advantage of non-determinism may be of interest. For example, you could use a hint that does the check and sets the Cairo inputs to the correct location within the set that the element resides. Then the verifier just has to check that this location indeed contains the element of interest. Here is a link to that part of the docs: https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_cairo/program_input.html#taking-advantage-of-non-determinism

Content:

Author: mongoose#1674
Content: @SoliditySnake When you run your program, are you running it with a --layout=small flag? My understanding (which is primitive) is that the output doesn't work in the default layout.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Yes, that's true. You need --layout=small in cairo-run, otherwise you don't have access to builtins (output being one of them)

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content:
Good questions! dYdX works on top of StarkEx which is a single-app rollup, meaning there is not possibility to deploy new applications on that rollup.
That does not mean you can't integrate with dYdX in some way. If you want to elaborate further what exactly you want to do I might be able to understand better if it is possible or not.

We are working on StarkNet which is much more close to what you are describing - a permissionless ZK-Rollup in which developers can deploy contracts and those contracts can interact with each other. You can read more about it here - https://medium.com/starkware/on-the-road-to-starknet-a-permissionless-stark-powered-l2-zk-rollup-83be53640880
Or watch a talk about it here - https://youtu.be/Bn3zXQP06A0

Author: Aha#8760
Content: Hello, evaluating L2 solutions for an ongoing project. How do you build on StarkEx if you don't want to wait for StarkNet, some kind of partnership?

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content:
Hi @raugfer sorry for missing that - currently we haven't deployed verifiers on other EVM compatible blockchains so it is not readily available. We are currently focusing on Ethereum. Once the Polaris prover will be out it will be much easier to add support to different chains.

re your 2nd question - even if verifying proofs is possible on various blockchains, there should be a careful design to allow the L2 state to be synchronized. The definition of L2 (as I understand it) is that the L1 defines its state. In the example of StarkNet, the state of the system is defined by the StarkNet L1 contract. You might be able to expand this definition to support multiple L1s, but it is not trivial.

Author: SoliditySnake#0449
Content: Hi all! I need to implement creation of new mapping entries in my contract which are of struct type (like 10 different variables) along with processing them later. Should I use Cairo for creation of such entries and processing them in one batch of txs or should I create new entries on L1 and then just process them with the help of Cairo? What solution is more efficient and possible? Just trying to choose the best option and plan development accordingly.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: It depends on what other things you want to do with them. If you can treat them entirely in Cairo, and say, keep a Merkle tree of those items (I'm assuming many such items, are created and sometime later processed), then this way you'll get the cheapest cost. If, on the other hand, some of the handlings needs to be in solidity then you may consider storing them on Ethereum storage (which will be much more expensive).

We do plan to create a system (called StarkNet) which allows writing contracts, and then you'll have an API. You can read about our plans here: https://medium.com/starkware/on-the-road-to-starknet-a-permissionless-stark-powered-l2-zk-rollup-83be53640880

Author: perama
Content:
I just had an idea relating to large trades on automatic market makers and the slippage they incur.

In one talk @EliBenSasson#9612 describes how the transaction ordering inside an L2 block can be determined by the output of a VDF/veedoo.

With publicly visible transactions, a single large trade could normally be abused by slotting transactions before and after the trade as MEV. With random ordering, these attacks would not be as easy to achieve, although an attacker could submit many small transactions with the hope of a probabilistic win

However, because transactions are cheap, the original large trade could instead be fragmented into ten smaller trades 

The "attacker" now sees those ten transactions and has the opportunity to send multiple smaller counter-trades that will be randomly interleaved in between. 

In this way, the AMM price fluctuates up and down multiple times per block, resulting in less slippage for the original seller. At the end of the block, if enough arbitrage transactions were sent, the AMM price may even be similar to before hand.

What do you think about the idea? Intra-block trade fragmentation as a way of attracting arbitrage for mutual benefit

Author: perama
Content: One motivation being that in the naive case of a large nonfragmented trade, other normal users have a chance of receiving a very large Delta on their trade. With the fragmented trade described, the magnitude of the delta for normal users in the same block might be much smaller.

Author: sidhujag
Content: how do you deal with attacks against the zkp servers for example if the code is modified and users are unaware the code changed and sign off on changes unknowingly?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: What do you mean by "sign off on changes"? The correctness of every batch of transactions is verified on-chain by the verifier contract, so even if the server is malicious, it cannot move the state to an invalid one

Author: sidhujag
Content: what about voilition or the one where data availability is offchain?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: In all cases, the state cannot be changed to an invalid one (e.g., moving funds without the user's signature). What may happen is that the user may not get the authentication path, which is required for using the escape hatch (exiting the system without the operator's involvement). For this we use a committee of a few external parties - the blockchain will agree to move to a new state only if (1) the verifier approved it and (2) enough committee members have signed that they got the information required to generate the authentication paths

Author: sidhujag
Content: consider this case, im nto sure its possible but: user A balance 5, user B balance 10 on L1 balance entered into L2. Server changes code to remove zkp the signature checks for accounts, then user A maked adjustment to user B account to take his coins so user A has 15, user B has 0.. L1 does not do signature checks, with the validity proof be valid since it removed the signature check?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: This way an attacker has to hack multiple parties and even then they won't be able to move funds

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Of course, this is a trade-off between security and cost (full on-chain data is the most secure, but it also costs more üôÇ )

Author: sidhujag
Content: im imaging a case where there is a business running zkp prover as their own L2

Author: sidhujag
Content: is that case possible? as there is no way to know if the server change removed the signature check?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Why won't it be possible? As long as the verifier remains on-chain, and let's say that you go with the on-chain data path, this should work

Author: 0xmichalis
Content: the hash of the cairo program is posted on-chain as part of the proof so you cannot cheat by removing the signature check off-chain, right @Lior Goldberg ?

Author: sidhujag
Content: the onchain data does not do the signature check

Author: sidhujag
Content: if the hash of the program is entered on chain it can be removed as a check in the cairo program itself the validity proof remains valid

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Right

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The on-chain data is governed by the program whose hash is hard-coded in the on-chain verifier

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: If the program says some data must be transmitted on-chain, the verifier will not accept the new state unless this data was transmitted

Author: sidhujag
Content: yes but cant you simply remove the check on the program and how will onchain verifier know it changed?

Author: sidhujag
Content: is validity proof invalidated?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: yes

Author: sidhujag
Content: ah nice ok thats the answer

Author: 0xmichalis
Content: you won't be able to produce a proof that matches the original program

Author: sidhujag
Content: almost fell off my chair

Author: sidhujag
Content: with each onchain verifier pointing to a hardcoded program, does that mean for specific applications only?, or can it be generalized to support turing complete contracts running in a general way in one program?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
To be accurate, the verifier contract itself does not have a hard-coded program. In fact, it can prove many different programs in one proof (this is called SHARP - Shared Prover).
Usually, there is an application contract in which the program hash is hard-coded, which talks with the verifier to make sure this specific program was proven with that specific output. The application contract holds the state so it decides when the state can be updated.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: By the way, in StarkNet (whose very first alpha is coming really soon), we are going to build a system where users can deploy contracts and interact with them. In that case the StarkNet program, which is it self hard-coded, runs arbitrary (Turing Complete) programs üôÇ

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: More information on SHARP: https://www.cairo-lang.org/cairo-for-blockchain-developers/

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: More information on StarkNet: https://medium.com/starkware/on-the-road-to-starknet-a-permissionless-stark-powered-l2-zk-rollup-83be53640880

Author: federico2014
Content: Hi, I have a doubt about Cairo, if the proof generation is delegated to the SHARP,  will it leak the private input if I want to generate the zero-knowledge proof

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
At the moment the Cairo prover doesn't have the zero-knowledge feature at all - with or without SHARP. The reason is that we chose to focus on scalability (rather than privacy), as it seems to be much more important at the moment.
Adding zero-knowledge is rather easy and technical, and once there will be demand for it, we will add it. Then, as you noted, SHARP won't be a good option - the users must be able to generate the proof on their machine.
In order to combine both scalability and privacy, one option is that each user will create a proof locally, and then send the proof to SHARP which will generate one proof that many user-proofs are valid (this is recursive proving)

Author: spEEd#1854
Content: I have a doubt regarding prover and verifier. Where exactly are they running? Are they running on separate hardware when the code is deployed in a practical scenerio?

Author: spEEd#1854
Content:
Another doubt wrt non determinism :
From the hello-cairo wiki

"We start by defining a local variable idx which we leave unassigned for now. Then we have a hint that looks for the entry with the requested key and assigns the index to idx. The hint itself does take O(N) operations, but this is not part of the Cairo code ‚Äì remember, a hint is just the instructions for the prover on how to resolve non-determinism. In practice, the operations of a hint are much cheaper (and in most cases negligible) with respect to Cairo instructions."
https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_cairo/program_input.html#running-the-program

What is meant by not part of cairo code? My current interpretation is the verifier tries to make sure the program doesn't fail. However there can be multiple values for which the code doesn't fail. Here comes the python code or "hint" in handy which can be used  (by the verifier?) to eliminate options. But then I get stuck in the fact that verifier doesn't have access to the python code. So what exactly is happening?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: I'm not sure I understand the question

Author: spEEd#1854
Content: My main confusion is due to this statement  " operations of a hint are much cheaper "

Author: spEEd#1854
Content: Can you please give a small example?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The pure Cairo instructions define what the program guarantees. A hint is used by the *prover*  in order to satisfy this guarantee. For example, the Cairo code may check that x*x = 25. This means the verifier won't be able to tell if x is 5 or -5 (but it'll know it's one of them). The hint is required to instruct the prover what value of x to use.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: It's important to note that if the hint say x=5, the verifier **can't rely** on that. It only knows that x is 5 or -5

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: In the example in the tutorial, the verifier doesn't care *how* the index was computed (and this is why it's ok to use a hint) - it only cares that it's in the valid range and that it points to an item with the requested key

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The generation of proof is an expensive process (at least when compared to naive execution without proof generation). A hint doesn't become part of the proof (it only helps the prover to choose some of the values), so you don't pay for executing it what you pay for executing a pure Cairo instruction.

Author: spEEd#1854
Content: Thanks a lot for the response. I think I have understoof the basic concept

Author: spEEd#1854
Content: Are the prover and verifier mentioned in the above pic and the prover and verifier in the "hello cairo" tut the same things?

Author: spEEd#1854
Content: What exactly happens when I am running  cairo code on my local machine?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: When you run Cairo code on your machine it can output a cairo_pie file, which contains the information to prove that this run was executed correctly. You can then send this file to SHARP which will generate the proof (together with programs of other users). SHARP will register a fact on-chain attesting to the validity of the execution (it will be verified on-chain by the SHARP verifier contract). Then your dapp solidity contract can verify that this fact exists (by talking with the verifier contract) and continue as if it had verified the claim itself.

Author: spEEd#1854
Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: dict_manager is a class defined in `src/starkware/cairo/common/dict.py`

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: It manages the information about the allocated dict required by the hints (that is, prover side only)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Handling dicts is different between the prover side (hint) and verifier side (Cairo code).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The verifier just have to squash the dict changes to make sure the read and write calls were consistent. See https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_cairo/dict.html

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: While you can generate the DictAccess entries yourself (as done in  https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_cairo/dict.html), it's more comfortable to have a mechanism that will take care of most things.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The file `dict.cairo` (including `dict_new`, `dict_read`, `dict_write` and `__dict_manager`) does exactly that.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: It stores the current values as a python dict so that when you want to read a value it can add a DictAccess entry without requiring you to specify the current value - it just fetches it from the dict_manager

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: You pass the end pointer and not the start because it's more convenient this way (since you have to add a DictAccess entry at the end).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: By the way, squashing the dict at the end is essential, since (as always) the verifier can't rely on the hints in the dict_read and dict_write functions

The trade would be settled and verified there only? Or the user would first ping the solditity contract which will then coordinate with the cairo code?

Author: spEEd#1854
Content: The AMM tut assumes starts after the point where transactions have been received.How exactly would the order reach from user to off-chain cairo?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
(I'm referring in my answer to the SHARP-based solution. In StarkNet things are going to be much more similar to Ethereum)
You need an operator - a server which collects orders from users (of course, not the private keys, just the signed orders). This server will create Cairo jobs that adds the order to an off-chain Merkle-based order book. It will send the job to SHARP which will generate the proof and send it to the blockchain. A solidity contract will process it and update the root of the Merkle tree (like in the AMM example).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: In order to handle deposits/withdraws, you'd output the amount of funds being deposited and for which user, and make the solidity code do the "opposite" update on the on-chain storage

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The deposit/withdraw idea is described here: https://medium.com/starkware/starkdex-deep-dive-introduction-7b4ef0dedba8 (under "Main user flows")

However, there is a buy order in Batch2 which matches that sell order. What exactly happens? Would I need to load the remaining transactions of Batch1 again along with batch2?

Author: spEEd#1854
Content: By load I mean re-insert them in a new instance of order-book

Author: spEEd#1854
