Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: You can store the open orders in a Merkle Tree, whose root is kept on-chain. This way you can share information between batches

Author: spEEd#1854
Content: But the matching mechanism, in my case orderbook would have a data structure which is combo of trees and linked lists. So that would need to be reinitialised, ie all the open order would need to be put again?

Author: AlonS#3599
Content: Your orderbook can be independent of the incoming batches. The only thing you need to prove is that every match you submit has correctly fulfilled two orders (so you fill your orderbook with incoming order requests, and fulfill orders when suitable matches are processed)

Author: greg_vardy
Content: Hey, I‚Äôve been walking though the Cairo compiler source code, but I‚Äôm struggling to understand the semantics of the VM. It would be super cool if there were some docs on the compiler & VM design and semantics

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
We plan to release some docs on the Cairo machine soon (but it won't be about the compiler itself). Maybe it would help.

Can you give an example of what kind of information you're looking for?

Author: greg_vardy
Content:
```
    class Res(Enum):
        # res = operand_1.
        OP1 = 0
        # res = operand_0 + operand_1.
        ADD = auto()
        # res = operand_0 * operand_1.
        MUL = auto()
        # res is not constrained.
        UNCONSTRAINED = auto()
```

Author: greg_vardy
Content: What is the reason for having UNCONSTRAINED? From some logging I have added to the vm, I see it's mostly used when Instruction.Opcode is NOP

Author: greg_vardy
Content: (that is from instruction.py)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The reason is technical and has to do with the Cairo AIR - we use the otherwise-unused res cell for conditional jumps (indeed, in such a case the opcode is NOP). In other words, for conditional jumps we don't need res, so we left it unconstrained.

Author: greg_vardy
Content: Ah okay, that's clever. Thanks!

Author: tupacamaru2
Content: Hi, I'm about to start a project and I have a question. I'm comparing StarkNet with Lightning (BOLT). I need the functionality of Lightning invoices ( server-to-server invoices and payment, not end-user ). However I would prefer to have my project on Ethereum on some L2. At 1st sight it appears that StarkNet has the L2 scalability, but it looks like it only has the low level tools to create the invoicing app. What would be the closest software design in StarkNet to invoices in Lightning? I suppose that one peer only needs to provide a payment address with value and the other peer the proof of payment. Can someone please elaborate? The answer will be very important to help me determine if I'll go with Lightning or StarkNet. -- Feel free to write privately to me or to reply here. -- Thanks --

Author: perama
Content:
Hey, I think invoices are possible atop L2. For two agents, each with eth/tokens inside the roll-up, they could send a message requesting a small payment. This message can be signed and sent to the Prover, who will incorporate that change into a proof. That proof then ensures that the L1 accounts for those entities have the new account balances.

The StarkEx system has existing in-production apps. So the proof cost is shared between many. 

The decision of which messages are sent for proving could be decided based on your application message frequency.

The difference with respect to lightning is that you don't need 1-1 channels. This removes the need for channel balancing activities and allows for more flexible payments if different recipients are added later.

Check out the StarkEx docs:

https://docs.starkware.co/starkex-docs-v2/

Author: perama
Content:
I think you can also set something up where you can pay to someone who has never used Ethereum. They generate an Ethereum address, pass it to you as a message (e.g. server to server in your instance) . You sign the message, it goes in the proof. Now they can send some back to you on L2 by sending a message. 
Later, they can exit the L2 and have the funds on L1. 

(Compared to lightning where an L1 transaction is required to open a channel).

Author: greg_vardy
Content:
Quick question: In the docs it says that immediates can serve either as the second operand in a given operation or as a standalone value for assignment. I tested using the immediate as the first operand and it seemed to work :
```
    [ap] = 1000; ap++
    [ap] = 12345 + [ap -1]; ap++
```

Author: greg_vardy
Content: Is there a reason that the docs specifically mention that the immediate should be the second operand?

Author: perama
Content:
Good question. I agree that any order is a valid operation. Perhaps they are second the sense that:

1. The compiler first applies the offset of `-1` to `ap`, then finds the value (`[]`) at that location
2. The operation is performed with the operand derived from step 1, the operator `+` and the "second" operand, `1000`.

As in a BODMAS style "what is done first" descriptor, rather than a left to right ordering.

Author: perama
Content:
Assuming you are reading: "Basic instructions", "a)" in:

https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/cairo_intro.html?highlight=immediates

Author: greg_vardy
Content: Yeah that‚Äôs what I was reading

Author: greg_vardy
Content: I dont think that‚Äôs happening in the compiler , it‚Äôs happening in the VM, although I could be wrong

Author: perama
Content: So maybe for `[ap] = [fp - 3] / [ap + 4]  `, neither operand is "second"

Author: greg_vardy
greg_vardy
Content:
```
class Register(Enum):
    AP = 0 
    FP = auto()
```
But op1 is type Op1_addr which is :
```
    class Op1Addr(Enum):
        # op1 = [pc + 1].
        IMM = 0 
        # op1 = [ap + off2].
        AP = auto()
        # op1 = [fp + off2].
        FP = auto()
        # op1 = [op0].
        OP0 = auto()
```
Because of these differences,  this instruction ```[ap] = 12345 + [ap -1]; ap++```  actually results in 12345 being op1 and [ap - 1] being op0 , as you can see from adding logging to vm.py: compute_operands(..):

Author: greg_vardy
Content:
```
  def compute_operands(self, instruction: Instruction) -> \
            Tuple[Operands, List[int], List[MaybeRelocatable]]:
        """
        Computes the values of the operands. Deduces dst if needed.
        Returns:
          operands - an Operands instance with the values of the operands.
          mem_addresses - the memory addresses for the 3 memory units used (dst, op0, op1).
          mem_values - the corresponding memory values.
        """
        # Try to fetch dst, op0, op1.
        # op0 throughout this function represents the value at op0_addr.
        # If op0 is set, this implies that we are going to set memory at op0_addr to that value.
        # Same for op1, dst.
        dst_addr = self.run_context.compute_dst_addr(instruction)
        dst: Optional[MaybeRelocatable] = self.validated_memory.get(dst_addr)
        op0_addr = self.run_context.compute_op0_addr(instruction)
        op0: Optional[MaybeRelocatable] = self.validated_memory.get(op0_addr)
        op1_addr = self.run_context.compute_op1_addr(instruction, op0=op0)
        op1: Optional[MaybeRelocatable] = self.validated_memory.get(op1_addr)
        print("in compute_operands: ")
        print(f"op0_addr: {op0_addr}")
        print(f"op0: {op0}")
        print(f"op1_addr: {op1_addr}")
        print(f"op1: {op1}")
.......
```
for the program: 
```
func main():
    [ap] = 1000; ap++
    [ap] = 12345 + [ap -1]; ap++
    return ()
end
```
yields the following prints:
```
.
.
.
in compute_operands: 
op0_addr: 1:3
op0: 1000
op1_addr: 0:7
op1: 12345
.
.
.
```

Author: greg_vardy
Content: So from what I can tell this is basically correct

Author: perama
Content: üëè 10/10 for the digging!

Author: greg_vardy
Content: Well apart from that it‚Äôs happening in the VM and not the compiler , but yeah basically correct

Author: spapini#3824
Content:
Yes, there is no such instruction as [ap]=12345+[ap-1] actually, only the reverse. Having multiple representations for the same operation is wasteful, after all.
The former is a syntactic sugar for the latter in a way.

Author: spapini#3824
Content: As for the division, a=b/c is actually syntactic sugar for b=a*c, and if a or c is immediate, then it's op1

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Yes, this is what I was referring to (the main contract is under the gps dir, which is the previous name of SHARP)

We don't have concrete plans to open source the SHARP prover at the moment (it's best to use it as service anyway, due to the ability to put multiple programs of multiple users on the same proof and get very low gas price this way, which is the "shared" part of SHARP)

Author: perama
Content:
Very interesting

So to map this to my understanding of Cairo proof generation: This appears to have direct application to the time required in proof generation

The prover performs low degree testing (FRI) to generate a probabalistic proof (that the polynomials in the AIRs have low degree). The proof is expensive because it requires evaluation of multiple points. The paper outlines a method to map this computation to allow speed similar to FFT-enabled calculations. Without this new mapping, the computation cannot enjoy FFT-speeds because the prime used in Cairo is not a composite of two smaller primes.

(Moreover, that the technique will have many applications outside of Cairo)

Is that how you see it at a high level @Kobi Gurkan ?

Author: kobigurk
Content:
Yes and no

You‚Äôre right that it‚Äôs about proving time. By utilizing the move to the frequency domain, you can do a lot of polynomial operations faster. This is useful in starks, Groth16 and many other pricing systems

The current methods people use require that the prime has high 2-adicity - p-1 has a large power of 2 as a factor (tbh doesn‚Äôt have to be 2, just many small factors)

This paper opens up the possibility to run these proving systems on arbitrary fields. For example, proving statements about secp256k1, the bitcoin/eth curve

Author: perama
Content: So would a manifestation of that be a proof system in a smart contract using the native sha3 opcode, rather than a precompile? With the implication that such a system would be significantly cheaper than existing deployments? E.g. a cheap mixer or a cheaper payment specific roll-up?

Author: kobigurk
Content: I don‚Äôt think it will be significantly cheaper since you still work a prime field. I think it‚Äôs more about being able to create proofs about fields we couldn‚Äôt efficiently before. @EliBenSasson might have a more specific vision

Author: amro#2887
Content: What kind of statements worth proving over btc secp256k1 you mean?

Author: kobigurk
Content: For example, proving knowledge of the private key and then doing something with it. Useful for onboarding keys to other systems

Author: perama
Content:
It seems like a really interesting problem for how to meter the transactions. First the DoS prevention, second the cost amortisation of the mainnet transaction.

I imagine that there needs to be a statement like: a block producer should have CPU/GPU/RAM specs W. Then a statement blocks should be checkpointed at cadence X. Then sent to mainnet at cadence Y. Then testing with computer W allows you to determine roughly Z the number of proofs possible in period X.

Then a transaction can be partly priced based on components that contribute to A time to process, and B time time to prove. E.g. an ECDSA operation built-in time C and a Pedersen hash time D.  Those costs C and D can be estimated by filling a block with only that operation and dividing the number of the single operations performed achieved within cadence X.

And partly the cost is pinned to the mainnet gas price and period Y. Which is based on the size of CALLDATA it generates with a Storage operation, which is ?polylogarithmic, but practically can be seen as linear at scale. 

Is there a good sense of what W will look like?

Author: guthl_starkware
Content:
@perama If you are interested by the topic, there is a great talk by John Adler about Resources Allocation in blockchain at the last EthCC. 
We don't currently have a clear target for the prover hardware requirements, but it is by far one of the most interesting (yet underestimated) questions to ask when it comes to scaling.

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: Another open question we have is the proper way to manage the double pricing between L2 gas costs + L1 gas cost. The main issue is that we don't control the gas price of the calldata on L1. So, we need to handle this special case.

Author: perama
Content:
Pretty soon there will be gas price derivatives now that the basefee is intra-protocol

Maybe you could require that a transaction purchases a share in a hedge against the gas price moving against the protocol, proportional to it's CALLDATA use

Author: perama
Content:
That is a very nice talk, thanks 

Getting a picture of what a StarkNet node will have to maintain:

1. So when I deploy a contract to StarkNet, does that cause StarkNet state growth only (without CALLDATA use)?
2. Does a transaction that interacts with that contract, but does not 'do' anything, cause the minimum CALLDATA use possible in StarkNet?
3. Do adding messages to L1 increase mainnet CALLDATA?
4. Do adding storage writes increase starknet state but not mainnet CALLDATA?

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content:
Hey Perama!
I'm not sure I understand fully the terminology you're using. I assume that by CALLDATA you mean the L1 on-chain data footprint, and by state growth you mean the size of the L2 state.
so to try and answer your questions - 
1. Yes, since the contract code is part of the state. A non formal description of the state is just a mapping between `address` to `(contract_code, storage)`
2. Transaction are not part of the CALLDATA, but only state changes, so I think the answer to your question is right. I'm not surre I understand what you mean by "cause the minimum CALLDATA use possible in StarkNet".
3. Yes, messages to and from L1 are sent as CALLDATA.
4. As I wrote in 2, state changes are published as CALLDATA, so they do increase it.

Author: perama
Content:
Great thanks.

Ok for 2, say there is an L2 contract with a userID stored. 

a) I send a transaction that checks the balance and decides not to increment. This increases L2 state but has no L1 footprint

b) I send a transaction that checks and then decides to increment the users balance. This has caused L2 state increase and also some L1 footprint. 

c) Updating two user's balances would cause a slightly larger footprint that b).

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content: For a), if this is the only thing the txs is doing, then the state does not change

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content: b) and c) are correct AFAIU

Author: perama
Content: Oh that's interesting. So it is processed by the StarkNet network, and so causes some burden which could be metered, but is not part of the state. So the record of the metering might not be part of the state?

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content: exactly. This is also the same in Ethereum

Author: JonasMtzgr#6276
Content: Hi! Is it possible to verify signatures on the secp384r1 elliptic curve with Cairo?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Theoretically this is possible because Cairo is turing complete, but it'll be very inefficient without a builtin, and we don't have such a builtin at the moment...

Author: JonasMtzgr#6276
Content: Thanks for the quick response! The reason I'm asking is because I want my smart contract to verify certificate chains that use secp384r1 signatures. Verifying a single secp384r1 signature in solidity is prohibitively expensive, and barely below the block gas limit. I know I could do it with Truebit, but I would love to avoid the 1 week delay with a cairo solution.

Author: JonasMtzgr#6276
Content: What does inefficient mean here? I don't care about computational effort during preprocessing, for example. Or do you expect the on-chain part (i.e. verify the ZKP using the Cairo verifier contract) to be expensive?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
No, on-chain part shouldn't be a problem here. But you do have off-chain costs that may not be negligible w.r.t on-chain costs if you'll choose the pure Cairo path (without a builtin).
To be honest, I didn't do the estimations for secp384r1. Do you have an estimation for the number of arithmetic operations required for verifying one signature? Also, an estimation on how frequently you'll need to verify such signatures?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: When you say it's barely below the block gas limit in solidity, do you know if it's pure EVM or with some precompiled contracts?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
IIRC a SHARP job is currently limited to 1,000,000 steps. You can see the number of steps using `--print_info` in `cairo-run`. However, this is just a configuration for the testnet SHARP. If needed SHARP can do much more steps.
(Note that using builtins has its own limitation which is different per-builtin.)
Deciding whether to break your program to multiple jobs depends on the size. I think 1M step parts are good (but it's not a must)

Author: batdavinci
Content: I cannot find what is exactly in a program's trace, which is sent to the SHARP prover - it seems from running the Debug function in the playground it appears to be hashing parts of the program with the associated function outputs in clear text, is there some documentation on what is happening in the trace sent to the SHARP prover? In addition, is there an ability to get data from an external source during the program's runtime?

Author: batdavinci
Content: Thank you!

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
cairo-run has some flags to print how much resources (steps and builtins) were used by a program. I think you can see the number of steps in the playground (but not the number of builtins)
You can get data from external sources during the execution using hint (which can run arbitrary python code). This is true if you run locally, not in the playground.

Author: batdavinci
Content: Thank you! From a perspective of SHARP, what exactly is verified, the compute steps and the result? In addition, is the cairo program available to inspect by third parties?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
SHARP gets the compiled program (not the source code) and proves that "there exists a run of the program that results in the given program output". Then, the hash of the compiled program is taken together with the hash of the program output and this creates a "fact", which is registered on-chain.
So, in order to convince a third party of the correctness of a claim w.r.t a particular output, you should give them (1) the source code and (2) the output; they should verify that the code does what it should & compile & hash it themselves (or an auditor can attest to the validity of the final hash); then they compute the fact and make sure it's registered by SHARP.
It may sound complicated, but it's usually done by the app's smart contract (we have a few examples, such as https://www.cairo-lang.org/build-a-scalable-cairo-basesd-automated-market-maker/)

Author: perama
Content:
Hey, @RoboTeddy  I made some notes exploring what form a Durin gateway might take if integrated with StarkNet

https://perama-v.github.io/cairo/ens/

I think one interesting aspect is that the act of making a query to the L1 ENS registry is a read-only operation. 

- Call L1, receive GatewayURL+data. (free)
- Call GatewayURL with data (?free from altruistic providers as public good).
- Gateway operator calls StarkNet, retrieves name->address mapping and some proof data, returns to user. (free)
- User calls L1 to verifyProofData, as long as there has been enough delay for StarkNet state proof to reach L1 since L2 name storage transaction. (read-only / free - so the proof can be expensive AFAICT)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: This is a way to implement a loop in Cairo. It is used in places where performance is important and you don't want to pay the overhead of tail recursion. Loops is Cairo are possible, but very limited - for example, you can't call most functions from inside a loop. We don't have a high-level instructions for loop because they are pretty rare

Author: kobigurk
Content: Ok I see, thanks! Will have to see the generated assembly at some point to digest it

Author: kobigurk
Content:
Alright, if I understand correctly the idea is to imitate the frame that you get when doing tail recursion but without the extra elements you would usually get

This is probably related to the Cairo language syntax more than anything else - why do I need the wrapping LoopFrame? Can I store felt* in the array instead? Or is it because I can‚Äôt calculate the sizes of such things?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: You can generate the low level instructions using the --preprocess flag.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The frame struct is just a nice way to pack things. The idea of looping requires that every time you start the loop, you'll be able to acess the current loop variables in the same way. We do it by placing them at the top of the stack before the loop and at the end of each iteration.

Author: artemyurchenko
Content:
Hi, 
why is the reference revoked in this case? Replacing `local` with `tempvar` leads to no revocation.
```
local a = 5 # a refers to [fp + 0]
local b = 6 # b refers to [fp + 1]
if a + b == 10:
    local a = a + 5 # _here_ a refers to [fp + 2]
else:
   local a = a + 6 # also refers to [fp + 2]
end
serialize_word(a) # reference revoked!
```

Author: perama
Content:
I think it is related to:
- tempvars are based on ap and automatically increment ap
- locals are based on fp and do not increment ap

https://cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/consts.html

Author: perama
Content:
So the `if` statement is executing a `jump` instruction. The `ap` after the `jump` is not incremented by the use of `local`. You could manually do so with `ap += SIZEOF_LOCALS`.

Medium confidence so maybe someone else can chime in if I am wrong

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
As @perama wrote, local variables are allocated with respect to `fp`.  Cairo allocates a memory cell for each `local` variable. In this example it allocates a different cell *for each of the two branches*.
This means that after the `if` it doesn't know which `a` to take - the one of the first branch or the one of the second.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
You can solve it by declaring the local variable above the `if`:
```
local a2
if a + b == 10:
    assert a2 = a + 5
else:
    assert a2 = a + 6
let a = a2  # If it's important that it'll still be called "a".
serialize_word(a)
```

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Moving to `tempvar` worked because in both branches `a` was available at the same relative address (`[ap - 1]`)

Author: artemyurchenko
Content: I see, thanks @perama, @Lior Goldberg

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: L2's don't generally offer anything special in the way of MEV (the sequencer still has the power to determine order of execution). However, there are ideas on how to reduce MEV using time locks in StarkNet contracts, see e.g. the following https://twitter.com/YaelDoweck/status/1421800038683004932. Note that it isn't a part of the protocol, but a way for specific contracts to reduce MEV in a way that would not be possible on L1 due to gas costs.

In the longer run, when StarkNet will be decentralized, we will look into it

Author: artemyurchenko
Content:
Hi, I've encountered unexpected behaviour of implicit arguments.

```
func foo():
    let i = 0
    return bar{i=i}()
end

func bar{i}():
    return ()
end
```
This piece of code fails to compile with the following error: 
```
Error: code:39:5: Cannot convert the implicit arguments of bar to the implicit arguments of foo.
    return bar{i=i}()
    ^***************^
The implicit arguments of 'bar' were defined here:
code:42:10
func bar{i}():
         ^
The implicit arguments of 'foo' were defined here:
code:37:6
func foo():
     ^*^
```

Why can't implicit arguments be converted? Why is there even a need to convert implicit arguments of `bar` to implicit arguments of `foo`? It's `foo` that calls `bar`.

If I change `foo` a little bit, the error is gone: 
```
func foo():
    let i = 0
    bar{i=i}()
    return()
end
```

Thanks!

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Currently the syntax `return foo(...)` is implemented only for the case where the return value (and they include all of the implicit arguments, which are also return value) are exactly the same. This may be improved in the future, but currently, the solution is to split the call and return lines as you did in the second piece of code.

Author: jmall#4962
jmall#4962
Content: Is this expected?

Author: ethweitrader
Content:
I noticed this in the syntax section of the docs
```
_ (underscore, underline). A placeholder to handle values that are not used, such as an unused function return value.
```
Does this mean we shouldn't name "private" variables in starknet contracts with a leading _ as is convention often in Solidity? Maybe stupid question.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Yes, Cairo is slightly similar to python in the sense that you can't break lines everywhere. Just break the lines after the `(`. I suggest using the Cairo auto-formatter, so that you don't have to take care of these things manually.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
That's not a stupid question at all üôÇ
The text in the docs refers to the case where the entire identifier is `_`, not to the case where you start an identifier with an underscore.
For example `let (_, _abc) = foo()` - the first return value is ignored, the second is available in `_abc`
So you can use `_abc` freely

Author: hexcowboy
Content: i'm just curious why the decision was made to build a new language instead of using an existing language like Rust? as a developer, learning new languages is a major headache

Author: albist
Content: I know nothing about language but i'm curious, besides the number of people using it, is it possible for a language to be easier to use or more powerful than other?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
It's starts from the need to reinvent the instruction set (i.e. not use x86), which is due to performance (STARK is a very different world than the world of transistors). Then, you can't use existing compilers without writing a new backend for the instruction set. Writing such a backend can be done but it won't allow you to write extremely efficient code when needed. Other disadvantage has to do with it StarkNet: most programming languages don't natively support the concept of a contract (defining storage variables, external functions and so on).
Now, assuming you decided to write your own compiler because of the above, you can choose the syntax for the language. I agree that choosing a syntax very close to existing programming languages is preferred. Cairo was inspired by python (minus the indention-matters aspect) + the pointer notation from c. Rust is another good option, and eventually it's becomes a question of taste.
I do hope to see more and more languages that compile to the Cairo instruction set in the future (solidity is getting there soon with the warp project).

Author: perama
Content:
Don't worry about using hints if you are writing contracts. They are used in the backend (StarkNetOS) in whitelisted modules, but you cannot write hints manually in a contract. The reason for this is that it increases the threat surface for the prover.

If you write a custom Cairo program that performs standalone application logic and integrates with a custom Solidity contract and the  `isValid()` method on the deployed verifier contract, then you can use hints

Content: it looks like felts mean negative numbers can be represented as negative before they're compiled but on the network they're represented as large positive integers (correct me if i'm wrong, anyone) @cecco_

Author: cecco_
Content: I see and that makes sense. If I do `-3 + 3` it results in `0` as expected since it's a field.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Because it's a field both representations `[0, P)` and `(-P/2, P/2)` are valid. The numbers are taken modulo P, so you can think of -1 as P-1 and vice versa.
It's similar to uint64 vs int64 - the same bit representation can be used to describe the number -1 (int64) and 2**64 - 1 (uint64). (hope this explanation makes sense üôÇ )

Author: cecco_
Content: I think it makes sense now. What's the intuition behind `assert_nn(x)`? My intuition is that it checks that `x < P/2`.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: It checks that 0 <= x < 2^128. In particular it implies that x < P/2 (P is around 2^251). This check is done with the range check builtin (this is exactly what it knows to do). The exact range is usually not that important. It should be below P/2 as you said, and be large enough to allow writing code easily (for example, working with 8-bit CPUs is not that fun...)

Author: martriay
Content: agh I noticed the same and forgot to ask about it thanks for clarifying!

Author: martriay
Content: can anybody provide an intuition of what a field element is? I'm not familiar with the concept

Author: martriay
Content: I understand it's an algebraic structure but that's as far as I go

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: In our case it means that all the computations are done modulo a large prime number P. This means that as long as you work with numbers smaller than P you'll get the expected result (except for division if there is a remainder) but if you go over P a multiple of P will be reduced from the result so that you'll be in the range (-P/2,P/2)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: You can read more here: https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_cairo/intro.html#the-primitive-type-field-element-felt

Author: martriay
Content: ok then I'll guess the int/uint parallelism was accurate from a practical standpoint

Author: martriay
Content: but with a slightly different computational model behind it

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Mathematically you can say that working with uint64 is working modulo 2^64. So we simply work with a different number here.
(By the way, the fact that the number is prime is what makes it a field and it has a lot of mathematical properties because of that. But this is not that important for programming in Cairo :) )

Author: martriay
Content: understood

Author: martriay
Content: thanks ^^

Author: jmall#4962
Content:
hey,
for example if I have a code like this -
```
func bar{hash_ptr : HashBuiltin*}():
    local x  = 0
    local y = 0
    if x == 0:
        hash2(1, 2)
        tempvar hash_ptr = hash_ptr
        if y == 0:
            hash2(4, 5)
            tempvar hash_ptr = hash_ptr
        else:
            tempvar hash_ptr = hash_ptr
        end
    else:
        tempvar hash_ptr = hash_ptr
    end

    hash2(3, 4)
    return ()
end```
binding references at every if condtion is kind of messy üòÖ , is there workaround?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: I'll just comment that the first tempvar is not necessary (at the first if, the reference is defined relative to fp). What's important is that at every usage of the hash_ptr reference, there will not be conflicting bindings from different branches. Here you solved this by having each branch rebind hash_ptr to [ap-1]. I'll leave it to @Lior Goldberg to suggest better syntax.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Fact registry is a pattern where you prove something to the Blockchain and it records the fact that this was proven, and allows future transaction to verify that it was proven. There can be many fact registry contracts, for different things you want to prove. For example, we use a lot of different fact registry contracts inside the STATK verifier

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: If you have a lot of branches where in one side you hash and in the other you don't, you'll have to do the tempvar trick as you did (as @FeedTheFed | StarkWare  mentioned one of them is unnecessary). This will be solved in future versions of Cairo :)

Author: killari.
Content: ah I see, why do you need to have multiple such contracts? They are not identical for each problem?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: It's for different parts within the STARK protocol (for example, verifying that some value is a leaf in a Merkle - this can be a fact registry contract)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: You can read about this pattern here: https://medium.com/starkware/the-fact-registry-a64aafb598b6

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: We use it inside the STARK protocol so that we can split one proof into several transactions.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: But SHARP uses the fact registry model as well, I think you referred to this specific fact registry. This contract stores a fact for each Cairo program that SHARP proved

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content:
@monkeyontheloose.eth there are few teams working on stuff related to StarkNet.
Infrastructure efforts - 
1. Erigon team are expanding their client to support StarkNet, it is called Fermion. 
2. Equilibrium team are building another full node implementation in Rust.
3. Nethermind are building Voyager which is StarkNet block explorer.
4. Nethermind are also working on Warp, which is a transpiler from solidity to Cairo. @Greg Vardy 
5. Open Zeppelin are working on standard contracts implementation. @martriay 
6. @daniel.kroeni and Markus are working on a compiler from Idris to Cairo.
7. ShardLabs are working on a HardHat plugin that will support StarkNet.

Application efforts - 
1. Snapshot are working on a voting system on StarkNet.
2. There is an active proposal to the Maker DAO to fund a team that will expand the Maker protocol to StarkNet.
3. We are working on similar proposals to few other high calibers DeFi applications on Ethereum.
4. @perama is working on a Dope Wars implementation on StarkNet (among many other amazing things he's doing in the Cairo ecosystem)

Author: elpoulpito_gg
Content:
By using Cairo you'll be able to use the starknet engine on a lower level than with a transpiler, and you'll be able to do the same things, but for a lower cost.
What do you mean by "real execution bandwidth"?
Eventually, like has been seen for most public network, as usage ticks up, the cost for execution will tick up. So even if in the beginning it is cost efficient to run your transpiled code; eventually, costs will creep up, and systems that were built from the ground up in Cairo will be 30x more efficient than yours.
I'll add that these Cairo native programs may be 30x cheaper... Or 30x more powerful. They may implement functionnalities you can't dream of in the EVM because it's too expensive

Author: cecco_
Content: I've been thinking how to organize Cairo projects so that they can be easily shared. I think sticking to a python-like structure makes it easier to share using PyPi. Developers can publish both their Cairo files (like `@uniswap/core`) and helper code (like `@uniswap/sdk`). With this structure users can then import the code like they do with StarkWare libraries (`from cairoswap.router import xxx`). I think a solidity like structure would make everything more complex. Any thoughts?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: I like this idea üòÄ  This way you can use `pip` for versioning.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
You should use a slightly lower-level syntax to get the return values (e.g., if it's not only felt):
```
let res : ReturnStruct = invoke(func_ptr=func_ptr, n_args=n_args, args=args)
```
where `ReturnStruct` is a struct with the return values and then you can access `res.x` (assuming `x` is a member of `ReturnStruct`)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: You can read more here: https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/functions.html#return-values

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Is it possible to build a Cairo program that has a secret input, where the proof can be validated without knowing the secret input?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: e.g., `proof = f(publicInput, secretInput) => publicOutput`

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Then the proof validator would validate that the function `f` was run against `publicInput` and an unknown `secretInput` and returned `publicOutput`.

Author: perama
Content:
I think the answer is yes, this is possible, but not with current architecture.

My understanding is that the system would require two changes:

- Some aspect of the proving system is modified to gain full zero-knowledge privacy. At present, a proof leaks some information that prevents full privacy of a program lifecycle. To extract that information would be difficult, but theoretically possible, with the current proving system. This aspect is not currently implemented because the focus is scaling not privacy.
- You have a proving node locally (rather than using a network Operator), and you generate a proof that is then passed to the network for aggregation. 

(I could be wrong on this)

Author: sky.cactus
Content: (2) seems like just an implementation detail, unless I'm missing something?

Author: perama
Content: But I also think that it is possible to build a mixer-style application, similar to Tornado.cash on L1, with today's system architecture

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Yes, in fact this already happens in most of the StarkEx environment - the verifier is unaware to the transactions included in the batch, just to the merkle roots before and after the batch. In this case the transactions are a sort of "secret" input.
Note that this is not zero knowledge, in the sense that there is no mathematical proof that you can't extract that data from the proof, but it can be made ZK with small changes to the implemented STARK protocol.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: "Small change" for some random dapp developer, or "small change" for as expert in zero knowledge system development?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: You have to be familiar with zero knowledge and the STARK protocol to do that üôÇ

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Imagine, for example, layerd zkRollups, where you have rollups within rollups.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: That's basically what recursive proofs are (and implementing a STARK verifier in cairo is one way to go about it). Very roughly, instead of directcly proving to a verifier V that a program C results in output O, you prove to V that the program V itself accepts the input (C,O).

Author: perama
Content:
I am exploring the modular layout for contracts being pioneered here:

https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/blob/main/contracts/Ownable.cairo

Where `MyContract` imports the function `only_owner` from `Ownable.cairo` like so:
```
- MyContract.cairo
    - Ownable.cairo (contains: 'only_owner' function, 'owner' storage)
```
The compiler is not enjoying that `Ownable` uses the `pedersen_ptr`:

```
Unexpected implicit argument 'pedersen_ptr' in an external function.
```

Is there some trick to allow this setup to work?

Author: perama
Content: I'm not proud of it - but I added `pedersen_ptr` to every single function as an explicit argument and return value, and then for the storage reads I used the `with pedersen_ptr:` format. The compiler now has the same error, but for `range_check_ptr`. So I am left with thinking: Modular contracts are perhaps possible, but not cleanly for now.

Author: perama
Content:
Additional context for my exploration is here:

https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/issues/4

Author: aundumla
Content: Is there a simple/intuitive explanation why Cairo nondeterministic computation model is 'better' choice for STARK platform?

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: Naively, division is Cairo are a multiplication where you provide the divisor as a witness. You are verifying the division not computing it. So, verifying a/b=c <=> to a = b.c

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: But for instance, there are cases where two solutions exist for the same problem

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: a**2 = 1 has two solutions

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: For such a program, Cairo would have two different valid traces

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Any prover-verifier communication is by nature nondeterministic - the prover is trying to convince the verifier that some witness exists. Nondeterministic programming is stronger than the usual deterministic case. For example to compute the square root of a number you need a relatively costly algorithm in the deterministic world. But in the nondeterministic world, you only need to verify that output^2 = input - so one multiplication operation.
Another example is searching for a value in an array. If the item is in the array you can "find" it in O(1) operations, by the prover simply pointing out the required index to the verifier.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: However, user-defined nondeterministic programming is not allowed in StarkNet, becuase it creates many problems (how will you know the sequencer won't use a different hint? how will the sequencer know the hints are safe to run and indeed satisfy the Cairo program?)

Author: cecco_
Content: The documentation for builtins and revoked references (https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/builtins.html?highlight=revoked#revoked-implicit-arguments) mentions that one solution is to rebind using a temporary variable _at the end of the branch_. Why does it have to be at the end of the branch? (Just curious to understand more about Cairo internals)

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: The point is having the bindings from each branch agree with each other. If you rebind at the start, and one branch progresses ap while the other doesn't, then the bindings no longer agree. The situation is "worse" if the reference is lost in one of the branches, e.g. by calling a function.

Content: On way to think about it is that a reference exists in the current context. If you go to another context - such as a calling into another function - the reference loses its meaning. You can specify that you wish the context to persist by using a local. In this way, when you call into another function, when you return, it will persist

Author: perama

What's interesting is that the range check pointer is used twice in the IF part, and it is happy without @jmall 's additional tempvar in the IF section. 

I think it's like:

We are entering an IF-ELSE section: In the IF section, we are expecting the implicit return of the `range_check_ptr`. So we also expect that in the ELSE section. 

You can replace the else section with a dummy assert_in_range and it is happy with that

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: I'll try to give a more complete but still hand wavy explanation of builtins. A Cairo program is eventually translated to constraints on the execution trace. Builtins are a way to have custom-made constraints implementing specific functions that interact with your native Cairo code. Consider the hash builtin for example, from the perspective of a Cairo developer, he's just placing x,y in the memory segment pointed to by hash_ptr, and to him this is equivalent to calling hash(x,y). Behind the scenes what you get are some special contraints on memory cells around x,y that make sure that some other third cell z is in fact the result of hash(x,y). The same goes for range checks, rather than calling a function which checks that a<=b (whicj is hard in finite fields), you simply place the values of a,b in a designated memory segment on which specific range check constraints will be applied. To be able to use this trick more than once in the same program you're going to need to keep the builtin points updated, otherwise you're overriding cells.

Author: perama
Content:
It is still a function, but some functions use both normal values and values that are best managed separately in the trace.

An analogy might be to imaging the trace as excel spreadsheet:

The program is broken down into small steps, and each step goes into the spreadsheet in a new row.
The proof is constructed by performing checks on these rows (not necessarily starting at the top and working to the bottom). 

Sometimes a new row has something that is a bit different (such as calculating a hash). 

The way that the row-checks are performed, it makes more sense to put all the hashes in a dedicated hash-only column. Then, they can be handled in a special way, separate from the other columns in the trace. Each builtin might have its own column. 

So when you call a function that does a hash operation you say 'I am going to need the hash column' and you pass the pointer in the curly brackets. The program then knows to use the appropriate special column in constructing the trace. If you say you are going to pass the value - but don't, or if you have an IF-ELSE section where you could end up either passing or not-passing the builtin, then the compiler lets you know

(Analogy only, hopefully it's not outright incorrect or misleading)

Author: perama
Content:
This is what is under the hood:

```
# Appends a single word to the output pointer, and returns the pointer to the next output cell.
func serialize_word{output_ptr : felt*}(word):
    assert [output_ptr] = word
    let output_ptr = output_ptr + 1
    return ()
end
```

Author: perama
Content:
I previously took a look at the `split_felt` family. First at what splitting was, and then at how it is useful. (I had noted that it might be used for tree-based operations, but that may be incorrect on second pass).

Now I see that it forms the basis for the `is_nn` check. 

So looking at that, I am thinking that: Because field elements are taken modulo P, how do you know if something is negative or positive? You take the modulo. But in the range [-P, P] you can take the modulo and find a positive value in the range. That is, -1 has a valid positive field element equivalent after the modulo. So is -1 one negative or not? I think yes: with the reason that the field range redefined as [-P/2, P/2] gives some negative and some positive numbers. So not we can set a rule: it is negative if when you find the positive field equivalent in the range [0, P], and the value is in the range [P/2, P] 

Or that, when split into `high` and `low` parts, a field element is negative if high is greater than P/2, or ~RC_BOUND as defined in the math library.

I have probably completely butchered this, I'd love to hear so if I have 

https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/cairo/lang/cairo_constants.py

https://perama-v.github.io/cairo/background/integer_lift/

Author: spapini#3824
Content:
About all the felt comparison questions.
assert_le_felt, lifts both felts to the range [0,P), and compares as integers.
it's more expensive.
assert_nn checks that the lift is in [0,2^128)
assert_le(a,b) checks that b-a is in [0,2^128). That does means we might wrap around the field in this check. So you need to be careful when using it. If you know/verify that the felt are not in big range, then you should be ok.

Content: Not in dex, but our perpetual code for dydx does. fixed point is basically integers, where you need to signed_div_rem after multiplying

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: You're right in saying that there is no notion of positive/negative in a field. If we associate the field elements with 0...P-1 then all the elements can be said to be positive. That's why we only ever ask if an element is in a given range, and is_nn(value) actually checks that 0<= value <= 2**128. Now the answer to the question "is -1 negative" (when we think of negative as outside the range I mentioned before) is independent of our interpretation of the field elements. If we think of them as [0...P-1] then -1 = P-1 > 2^128 and If we think of them as [floor(-P/2),floor(P/2)] then the answer remains the same.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
No, as you guessed it doesn't support that yet. One option (in addition to @cecco_ 's suggestion) is to get an array of felts and convert it to (or, treat as)  an array of structs (assuming simple structs without pointers). Something like:
```
func arr{range_check_ptr}(a_len : felt, a : felt*):
   let b_len = a_len / T.SIZE
   assert_nn(b_len)  # This will make sure a_len is divisible by T.SIZE
   let b = cast(a, T*)
   ...
end
```

Author: dairaemma
Content: @guiltygyoza Not sure specifically about Cairo or Starks, but in other proof systems, independent is_not_zero operations are expensive because you need to compute a field inversion for each one

Author: dairaemma
Content: But there's an optimization that can reduce the per-operation cost to that of a multiplication: multiply together all of the variables you wanted to check, and then check that the product is non-zero

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Just a comment, if you're measuring proving resources and not execution time, then is_not_zero has the complexity of roughly one multiplication operation (the inverse can be given as a hint).

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: @guiltygyoza Ignore my previous comment, is_not_zero is implemented via an equality check, which is eventually an opcode with a corresponding constraint. There are no inverse games here

Author: ericglau
Content: I'll see if I can add a check to help avoid those kinds of issues. https://github.com/ericglau/cairo-ls/issues/5

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: See my previous comment, since in any case you would need to allocate memory for every value you wish to know is non-zero, multiplying them would only require more cells, while asserting they are all non-zero is just adding an additional constraint for each of them.

Author: guiltygyoza
Content:
@FeedTheFed | StarkWare  @Daira Emma  I'm applying the idea of multiplying variables together before checking the product is_not_zero. Here are the results:

previously:
~800 lines of
` let (local bool_xx) = is_zero (x-<some felt value>)`
followed by 1 line of
`tempvar sum_of_product = bool_xx * bool_yy * <some felt value> + bool_xxx * bool_yyy * <some felt value> ...`
(about 150 products are summed together)

now:
~150 lines of
` let (local bool_xy) = is_zero ( (x-<some felt value>) + (y-<some felt value>) )`
followed¬†by 1 line of
`tempvar sum_of_product = bool_xy * <some felt value> + bool_xxyy * <some felt value> ...`
(the same 150 products summed together)

pytest runtime for 1 compute-intensive external invoke:
previously / 97 sec
now / 27.93 sec

pytest runtime for 1 compute-intensive external invoke followed by 9 calls to read storage variables:
previously / 648 sec
now / 76.09 sec

Significant speedup is observed.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: @guiltygyoza , these numbers seem high... Is it possible that this includes the compilation time? (which is known to be slow and will hopefully improve in the next (non-minor) version

Author: dairaemma
Content: Are you sure those are equivalent? You need a product of the "x - ..." and "y - ...", not a sum

Author: dairaemma
Content: Note that the cost saving, if any, would be in computing the witness

Author: guiltygyoza
Content:
Got it. Now measuring only the execution time:
```
    from timeit import default_timer as timer
    
    ...

    time1 = time.time()

    ret = await contract.compute(x=x, y=y).invoke()

    time2 = time.time()

    for y in range(3):
        for x in range(3):
            ret = await contract.view_storage(x=x, y=y).call()

    time3 = time.time()
```
result:
```
> time2-time1: 2.7322532079999995 sec
> time3-time2: 47.982711542000004 sec
```

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: still curious why the view calls take so long.

Author: guiltygyoza
Content:
@Daira Emma not equivalent, yet sum is required instead of product, because I'm using `is_zero` (a wrapper function for is_not_zero that inverts its result 0<->1), not is_not_zero itself. I think the correct optimization, instead of simple sum, is to use sum of absolutes. Proof:

```
Claim:
is_zero(x-a) * is_zero(y-b) == is_zero( abs(x-a) + abs(y-b) )

Proof by exhaustion:
x=a, y=b => 1*1=1 == is_zero(0+0)=1
x=a, y!=b => 1*0=0 == is_zero(0+pos)=0
x!=a, y=b => 0*1=0 == is_zero(pos'+0)=0
x!=a, y!=b => 0*0=0 == is_zero(pos'+pos)=0
where pos and pos' are some positive numbers (not considering the modulo that comes with felt values)
```

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: (there are other ways than using `abs` to make the optimized version equivalent to the pre-optimized - by changing the domain of a and b, each of which comes from a specific encoding scheme that can be designed. Still, thank you so much @Daira Emma for the idea!)

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: @Lior Goldberg @Daira Emma  @guiltygyoza  I might be off here, but I think that is_zero and is_not_zero are both efficient so there's no need to minimize in this regard. IIUC is_not_zero translates to a conditional jump, which does not use more trace cells as the existing constraints on pc already cover conditional jumps.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Any conditional jump is implemented in the Cairo CPU using the inverse @Daira Emma referred to. But since it's only computed during the actual proof generation I don't think it's the bottleneck here

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: I'd be happy to see the Cairo code to understand why it takes so much time

Author: guiltygyoza
Content:
@Daira Emma @FeedTheFed | StarkWare @Lior Goldberg updates: 

with Lior's reminder of using the default_dict, I replaced all sum-of-products & is_not_zero's with entry insertion into a dictionary. It is quite performant:
- I am able to pack 3110 entry insertions into a function. (previously with >300 of sum-of-products I would trigger exception on maximum recursive depth reached such that the contract wouldn't compile)
- The contract, with the function above and nothing else, takes 82 seconds to compile and deploy.
- 100 random queries to the dictionary yielded an average query time of 5.08 sec, minimum 4.86 sec and maximum 6.54 sec.

Thank you Lior for this timely reminder!

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: I see that you didn't call default_dict_squash in tic.cairo, consistency of read-write-updates is only guaranteed if squash is eventually called (otherwise a malicious prover can cause read to return a value that does not exist in the dictionary).

Author: aundumla
Content: I had a look at the cairo implementation. What is not clear are the reasons for providing this particular set of builtins. I.e. why range_check builtin is limited to 2^128?

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: I am using the default_dict as a read-only reference  (the dict is written to in the contract internal function with constants). Still, thanks for the reminder!

Author: perama
Content: I think the vulnerability persists, because the library module populates the dictionary with a hint. So without a finalize(), they could mal-populate a different value

Author: guiltygyoza
Content:
Take this toy function as an example:
```
func internal_lookup {range_check_ptr}(k:felt)->(v:felt):
    alloc_locals
    let initial_value = 0
    let (local dict) = default_dict_new(default_value = initial_value)
    default_dict_finalize(
        dict_accesses_start = dict,
        dict_accesses_end = dict,
        default_value = initial_value)

    dict_write {dict_ptr=dict} (key = 5, new_value = 10)
    dict_write {dict_ptr=dict} (key = 7, new_value = 20)
    dict_write {dict_ptr=dict} (key = 9, new_value = 30)

    let (v) = dict_read {dict_ptr=dict} (k)
    return (v)
end
```
If `internal_lookup()` can never be called from external, and that the function that calls `internal_lookup()` guarantees that the `k` passed in would also be in [5,7,9], would the vulnerability persist?

Author: perama
Content: I believe so. I think just before the read operation finalize should be called

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: but with 5:10, 7:20, 9:30 written to the dictionary, what `default_value` would I pass to a `default_dict_finalize` afterwards? I may be missing something obvious.

Author: perama
Content: The default value used initially, in this case `0`. The default value is just for any key that does not yet have a value

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: yes, suppose I'm the one proving the state update which included a call to the external function making use of internal_lookup, then unless squash is eventually called nothing constrains me from returning any value for v.

Author: perama
Content:
What's the best way to add a value to the start of an array?

e.g., I have an array `my_array` that I want to pass to `hash_chain`. It expects the first value to be `len`. 

```
let arr_with_len = alloc()
assert arr_with_len[0] = len
assert arr_with_len[1] = # TODO. Perhaps cast?
let (hashed) = hash_chain(arr_with_len)
```

(Post-hoc edit: hash_state was the library I actually needed, and that keeps the length and array separate, so the above is not an issue)

Author: perama
Content:
Oh I think it's just: 
```
assert &arr_with_len[1] = my_array
```

Content: I think that this will just fail, arr_with_len is a newly allocated address so no reason that its address will be related to my_array.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
There's a reason, but not a good one üôÇ
More than 127 bytes requires more code as the keccak permutation should be applied twice (or more, depending on the input size) instead of only once.
We simply didn't get to implement it.
We'll do it in the future, unless  someone from the community wants to take it as a challenge üôÇ (should be familiar with how keccak works and with Cairo)

Content:
```let (quotient, remainder) = unsigned_div_rem(dividend, divisor)```

so the pythonic modulo  `res = 5%2` becomes:

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Nice! üéâ 

I haven't read it thoroughly, but here are some comments:
1. https://github.com/marcellobardus/keccak-cairo/blob/b864695fc182da8fa3c0b721152c91bc74bd9d9b/keccak/keccak.cairo#L148 - I think you need to assert that 0 <= n_bytes_in_current_block < 136, because you used a hint to determine n_bytes_in_current_block.
2. Each call to packed_keccak_func can handle 3 keccaks in parallel, I don't think you're using that, right? If you don't, you'll pay 3x more than needed.
3. https://github.com/marcellobardus/keccak-cairo/blob/b864695fc182da8fa3c0b721152c91bc74bd9d9b/keccak/keccak.cairo#L143 - You can use the tail recursion syntax `return recursive_keccak(...)` (it won't change the compiled code, it'll just be slightly shorter)

Author: 0xmarcello
Content: Parallel execution üëÄ? Where do I read more about it?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Since all packed keccak does is bitwise operations, and we have 251 bits in each felt, you can put 3 words (from 3 different instances) in each felt.
See the finalization code in https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-examples/blob/master/keccak/keccak.cairo, which uses the keccak_ptr array and creates sets of 3-instance chunks.
My suggestion is not to rewrite this part, but simply use it - so that whenever you want to compute the keccak permutation you register in the keccak_ptr array (you'll need a hint to compute the result, as done in the original keccak function) and at the end the programmer calls finalize which actually does the keccak verification.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
So you split the computation into two parts:
1. Whenever you need to compute the keecak permutation you guess the result using a hint and register both in a keccak_ptr array.
2. At the end of the program the users calls the existing `finalize_keccak` which verifies the guesses that were done in part 1.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
ap, fp and pc are the registers of the Cairo CPU (like rax, rbx, ... in x86). Since this is pretty low level, and isn't really necessary in order to write Cairo programs, you probably won't find video resources about it.
You have the explanation in How Cairo Works (the one you already found) and it's also explained in the Cairo whitepaper (https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/1063).

Author: Nick Ulven#5084
Content:
```
    def _get_function_args(self, function_abi: dict) -> Tuple[Dict[str, dict], Dict[str, Type]]:
        """
        Given a StarkNet contract function abi, computes the arguments that the python proxy
        function should accept. In particular, an array input that has two inputs in the
        original abi (foo_len: felt, foo: felt*) will be converted to a single argument foo.
        Returns an ordered mapping from the argument name to the input abi.
        """
        args: Dict[str, dict] = {}
        type_annotations: Dict[str, Type] = {}
        last_name: Optional[str] = None
        for input_entry in function_abi["inputs"]:
            name = input_entry["name"]
            if input_entry["type"] == "felt*":
                # Make sure the last argument was {name}_len, and remove it.
                size_arg_name = f"{name}_len"
                assert (
                    last_name == size_arg_name
                ), f"Array size argument {size_arg_name} must appear right before {name}."
                size_arg = args.pop(size_arg_name)
                type_annotations.pop(size_arg_name)

                actual_type = size_arg["type"]
                assert (
                    actual_type == "felt"
                ), f"Array size entry {size_arg_name} expected to be type felt. Got: {actual_type}."

                type_annotations[name] = List[int]
            elif input_entry["type"] == "felt":
                type_annotations[name] = int
            else:
                raise NotImplementedError
            args[name] = input_entry
            last_name = name
        return args, type_annotation
```

From https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/starknet/testing/contract.py. Looks like the testing framework doesn't know how to accept structs as inputs yet. Do you know when this will be available?

Author: roboteddy
Content: a "dumb" question: on starknet, I assume that each function invocation is like running a cairo program anew ‚Äî is that right? i.e. the stack does not persist between invocations, so if I wrote a pointer to a `@storage_var`, the memory it pointed to would not still be around during a subsequent invocation

Author: perama
Content: Each time you go to a new function your get a new frame pointer `fp`. The `@storage_var` will persist, these data are secured on L1. Accessing it in a second transaction will be a `read()` operation that sets the value from storage into non-persitent memory, e.g. the next available memory cell.

Author: perama
Content:
A nice way to see the memory of a Cairo program (not contract) is to:

Strip out the decorators and storage, add a `main()` function and them run from the CLI with the `--tracer` flag. This will open a webpage on local host that you can walk though you program with, exposing variables, fp ap

Author: guiltygyoza
Content:
following `colliding definitions for the same reference causing reference to be revoked` with this code:
```
func foo(x):
    jmp x_not_zero if x != 0

    x_is_zero:
    let (local y) = heavy_computation_1()
    jmp done

    x_not_zero:
    let (local y) = heavy_computation_2()

    done:
    # Here, y is revoked, and cannot be accessed.
    ret
end
```
What would be the go-to design pattern if I need `y` in `done`?
I know I can always use `y = bool_condition * y_value_1 + (1-bool_condition) * y_value_2` where the two bools are mutually exclusive, but then both of the y values will get computed. If using if-else I assume one of the two can be skipped leading to better performance.

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: (context: in my case one of the computation would be collision handling, which is quite expensive and I don't want to run it if collision did not occur)

Author: perama
Content: Before `jmp x_not_zero` can you define y: `local y`, then replace the `let (local y)`'s with `assert y`?

Author: perama
Content:
```
func foo(x):
    local y
    jmp x_not_zero if x != 0

    x_is_zero:
    let (res) = heavy_computation_1()
    assert y = res
    jmp done

    x_not_zero:
    let (res) = heavy_computation_2()
    assert y = res

    done:
    # Here, y is revoked, and cannot be accessed.
    ret
end
```

Author: perama
Content: (added `res` to capture the return value)

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: interesting. using `local` before entering the branch, and using `assert` to assign value works. why is this?

Author: perama
Content:
While the program will only execute one limb, it will perform a check that the limbs are not conflicting. 

So one limb creates a new local variable called Y. The other limb also tries to create a new local variable Y. Locals cannot be rebound, and you have a situation where the program structure has two locals of the same name.

Author: perama
Content: Whereas if you first define the local then no matter which limb you go down, the local that you end up using points to the same place in the program

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content:
Contracts' storage is initialized to be 0, like in Ethereum (IIRC). This is how the storage root can be computed. The `storage_var` just access a psuedo-random storage cell by hashing the name of the storage var and the input(s).
You can see it here in python - https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/starknet/public/abi.py#L29
Or here in the autogenerated code of the storage_vars  in Cairo, thought it's a bit harder to understand - https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/starknet/compiler/storage_var.py#L164

Author: perama

Author: perama
Content:
At the moment I am thinking that the function can return a hard coded set, with a flag to inform the caller of the user count per day. 

E.g., return 5 user_ids plus a user_count per day: So (5 + 1) * 5 = 30 felts. Unused slots are 0, any count > 5 lets you know you should call the contract for more data.

Author: roboteddy
Content: also, this is silly/bikeshedding, but does anyone have a favorite convention for distinguishing between a `storage_var` and the value stored inside of it? e.g. I saw argent's approach is `let (amount) = _amount.read()`; I've been using e.g. `let (amount) = amount_var.read()`; openzepplin uses `let (_amount) = amount.read()`.

Author: pscott1337
Content: Yeah I‚Äôve been using OpenZeppelin‚Äôs style but would indeed love to have this standardized üòÑ

Author: pscott1337
Content:
amount_var is better but a lil‚Äô bit too verbose imho and in a big code base you‚Äôll have lots of _var everywhere‚Ä¶
Maybe we should be playing with capitalization instead ?

Author: roboteddy
Content: I kind of like Argent's style, since it makes the underscores more rare. but you may also sometimes want to use an underscore to prefix an argument in a function signature... which would overload the meaning of a prefixed underscore. agree `_var` is too verbose

Author: cecco_
Content: I'm using argent approach as well. I like it because it's consistent with naming private functions the same way.

Author: martriay
Content: I like Argent's approach for the same reason stated by @cecco_, but ended up stumbling upon what @RoboTeddy says: you'll end up using `_` as a prefix in other places, and that makes things confusing, so I ended up with my approach ("OpenZeppelin's") which is to think about `_`-prefixed variables as internal _relative to functions_. This is, an underscore prefix means this variable is private to this function only, so no clashing with storage vars/private-to-module vars, etc

Author: martriay
Content: it's an easier naming rule to me, both to use and to read

Author: roboteddy
Content: another possibility is to use argent's style, and if you would use a `_` locally for some other reason, instead use `__` locally. (this need might be somewhat rare and hence not too awkward)

Author: martriay
Content: sure that works

Author: martriay
Content: but I don't like it :p

Author: roboteddy

Author: roboteddy

Author: martriay
Content: and by the opposite I mean there's lots of semantics in code: function names, variable names, variable scope, types, conventions and all of that has meaning not just for the compiler but for developers and auditors

Author: martriay
Content: sometimes an inattentive auditor may assume a function does what the name says, but it may be doing something different, or something more than just what the name suggests

Author: martriay
Content: same with conventions, an auditor has to overcome believing that something with an underscore is actually private

Author: martriay
Content: that's the rationale behind MakerDAO's codebase

Author: roboteddy
Content: hmm I'm finding it time-consuming to prevent problems with revoked references, because (a) the compiler seems slow, so there's a long feedback loop, and (b) due to implicit args it's not obvious which functions are going to lose track of which references. anyone have tips?

Author: roboteddy
Content: (one can imagine writing a program to handle it automatically/statically/invisibly... maybe the compiler will, at some point?)

Author: perama
Content:
It is a challenge. I have sometimes passed all the pointers to each function (implicitly) with the intent of later paring them down if they are not needed.  

I imagine this adds cost to the operation of the program, but not sure to what extent.

Author: roboteddy
Content: ah yes, nice hack for during development. I also have trouble with my own references being revoked, not just the implicit ones... but I suppose passing in all implicit refs would help cut down on noise! re: costs: I suppose after we know tx fees, we can check to see how much extra tax we're paying... I guess for each extraneous argument, we end up with two additional writes to application memory (a push onto stack before calling the fn, and a second one right before the fn returns).

Author: perama
Content: The alternative is to have the variable saved as a local (rather than the feed-though everything method) which might incur some small cost. I think if you are using loops then it is better to not pass all the variables.

Author: roboteddy
Content: I guess during development, could (a) feed through all the implicits all the time, and (b) always use locals for your own explicit references. then zero problems with revoked references during dev, and could pare down later per your point

Author: roboteddy
Content: and I suppose (a) would also mean you can keep a single implicit argument list `{syscall_ptr : ..., ... ,... }` and use it everywhere, rather than having to hand-roll it for each function ‚Äî again faster during dev

Author: perama
Content: Yeah I don't think using locals for everything is the best approach, but I guess it depends on your program

Author: guthl_starkware

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Forget about circuits, we are doing uniform computation. We're proving the execution of arbitrary programs, so roughly, the starting point of the protocol is the consistent execution trace of a Cairo program (think of it as a table where each row represents a step in the computation and a column can represent the contents of a register).

Author: unsupervised.learner
Content:
Thanks for the response.

I am working on the design of a zk system for solana chain where off-chain computations are bundled and verfied with an onchain state transition, and am investigating the tools available. I understand your SHARP verifier is implemented for Ethereum? It is looking like I will have to use less powerful tools to make this happen for my use case.

Author: jofarnold
Content: My use case is also validating off-chain so super interested in this.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Our verifier is implemented in solidity, yes. In SHARP, basically, we prove the execution of one specific program that loads different programs from memory and executes them. The advantage of uniform computation is that your protocol is oblivious to the complexity of the program/number of programs you're proving (it would obviously require more proving/verification resources, but there are no hard coded limitations in the protocol). The Circuit based way of doing this was having one huge CPU circuit and feeding it a large number of programs. Generally speaking I don't think that your use case requires less powerful tools.

Author: unsupervised.learner
Content: I would rather use a more general system like Cairo, but I need a verifier on Solana and I need to optimize the size and complexity of the verification. So it's looking like my best bet is still handcrafted circuits

Author: martriay
Content:
I have a few doubts about non-deterministic programming. I get the intuition that Cairo programming equals to adding restrictions to a circuit, so it's only good for verifying that a computation was done correctly.

so far, so good.

Now, I'm trying to identify where in the language the nondeterminism "leaks out" but couldn't yet put my finger on it (This could be partially because I'm working on StarkNet which is stateful, and therefore has a different flavor)

At the beginning I thought the lack of try/catch was a good example, but then I noticed that if Cairo is turing complete, nothing really should prevent me from doing A if a signature is valid or doing B otherwise. Currently this is not possible because the building blocks (Cairo + builtins) work as asserts, e.g. `verify_ecdsa_signature`, which will only fail. I get the circuit analogy and that you either "pass the circuit" or not. And I know the answer goes in the line with the idea that this programs have to be *proved*, not executed. Nevertheless, I'm having a hard time trying to convey this idea to people.

Author: martriay
Content: **tl;dr**: what prevents me from changing the circuit so it returns 1 if it passes, 0 if it doesn't?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
My suggestion: forget about circuits. Have a Von Neumann architecture in mind and think of Cairo as the language to express programs in this architecture. So far things are pretty normal, except that Cairo was designed with the purpose of being able to succinctly prove execution. It is easy to say what does it mean for a program to execute correctly when every memory cell is fixed (e.g. the statement jmp x if [y] = 10 should change pc to x only if the value of the memory in address y is 10). However, if I just give you the program code, and I say that the output is 7, what does this mean? With one initial memory assignment, the output might be 7, and it can be different in a different assignment. This is where nondeterminism appears in Cairo, if my program acts based on an unassigned value of the memory, it remains up to the prover what to put in that cell before he starts proving the correct execution. This concept does not arise when you're just running programs on your favorite Von Neumann architecture because the memory is deterministic, you're not proving anything but merely acting based on the current values.

As for your example, the ECDSA builtin knows how to do the following: take three values in memory r,s,m, and verify that (r,s) is a valid signature for m. You could also implement "(r,s) is not a valid signature for m", which simply runs the same algorithm but asserts inequality in the end. Technically you could have the builtin return 0/1.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: See my edit about ecdsa, apologies. To elaborate a bit, a builtin is just hardcoded constraints on some part of the memory. Suppose that the final step in signature verification is asserting [x]=[y] (where the preceding constraints make sure that [x],[y] were computed according to the ECDSA verification algorithm), you could remove this constraint and add a cell z with constraints [z]=[x]-[y]. Now z is non zero iff the signature is invalid.

Author: Henri#6408
Content:
The objective with hints is to be able to provide Cairo with external values, that are calculated on the fly by the prover.
It allows you to say to Cairo "run this python code and input that value" instead of saying "input that specific fixed value" 
From the point of view of the proof both are the same. 
From the point of view of the prover, it allows parametrizing things a bit easier
Again, note that this is not possible in Starknet

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: The first example has only two cairo instructions, while the second has 3. Look at the second program, it clearly executes successfully since in the third line [ap-1] is 25 and [ap] is 5. Now take a look at the first program (forget about the hint, it does not affect the bytecode). I see a program that will run successfully only if [ap] is the root of 25, so if someone proves to me that he successfully ran that program, I know for example that he is in possession of sqrt(25).

Author: roboteddy
Content: (just a small technicality) I think the execution pointer is `pc` ("program counter"). `ap` is is the "allocation pointer" ‚Äî it's just a pointer to where the next empty memory cell is. so if you write a value to where ap currently is, you generally want to also increment it, so that it continues to point to an empty memory cell

Content: you need to get the address with &

Author: guiltygyoza
Content:
actually I was just looking at this for reference:) Finally getting it to work - two discoveries for me:
(1)
The following doesn't work because `Expression has no address.`
```
    local player : Player = Player (
        pos = &Position(x=123, y=456), # <====
        id = 0
    )
```
The following also doesn't work because of the same reason `Expression has no address.`
```
    let pos : Position = Position(x=123, y=456)
    local player : Player = Player (
        pos = &pos,
        id = 0
    )
```
The following works, using `local` for `pos`:
```
    local pos : Position = Position(x=123, y=456)
    local player : Player = Player (
        pos = &pos,
        id = 0
    )
```
(2)
first time getting `Using the value of fp directly, requires defining a variable named __fp__.` Using https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/blob/2c2e1bb745985c600643d0498682ab2498b64b89/contracts/Account.cairo#L171 I'm able to get this to work. So the entire working code now reads:
```
    alloc_locals
    let (__fp__, _) = get_fp_and_pc()

    local pos : Position = Position(x=123, y=456)
    local dummy : Player = Player (
        pos = &pos,
        id = 0
    )

    return (dummy.pos.x)
```
The above function returns 123.

Content:
For `assert a = b`

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Yes, but the problem is that it may make the code harder to read, instead of easier. The reason is that there's no good way to enforce that an assignment is really an assignment and not an assert. So one programmer may choose to always use assert, another may choose to always use assign, and another may use it correctly most of the time, but make a mistake from time to time (which the compiler won't be able to detect üò¶ )... This will make reading code other wrote very difficult

Content: You can disassemble the data field, and get textual instructions. But you won't see functions, if blocks, comments etc. It's up to you to try to understand what's going on. assert my_dict.key = my_key
assert my_dict.prev_value = value
assert my_dict.new_value = value

```
