Author: 0xcchan
Content: Sorry can I understand why Cairo needs to be separated from solidity? I get the execution of business logic off chain and SHARP for zk roll ups. But can‚Äôt I also use other languages like Turing complete Langs like python and Java ? Is the only competitive advantage for CAIRO, the use of SHARP?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Cairo was designed with the purpose of succinctly proving the execution of programs. This is not the usecase for most (any other?) programming language.

Author: 0xcchan
Content: yea but thats through SHARP right for the verification which is the main feature of CAIRO? and because SHARP isnt open sourced its quite hard to understand how this STARK rollup works in code

Author: 0xcchan
Content: and just curious are there plans to make CAIRO an evm lang? from what i understand its a bridge for business logic to solidity.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
Understanding STARKs is not necessary for development. I think that when dealing with provable programming, the STARK protocol is (somewhat) analogous to transistors, who you completely trust when doing regular programing (no bit will magically flip during the computation). As a developer, you can dive into the details of Cairo and the CairoVM (analogous to EVM), without going into STARKS. Additionally, SHARP being open sourced will only help you produce proofs, but will do little in the way of ensuring you of safety (for this you need a very good understanding of the protocol + examining the L1 verifiers, which technically you can do today).

As for your other question, Cairo is not EVM compatible, but the WARP team are developing a solidity -> cairo transpiler that will preserve the program's semantics.

Author: 0xcchan
Content: That‚Äôs great. Appreciate your response. Tryna pick up this new lang which I‚Äôm sure is gonna be the future

Author: orland0x
Content: following from this,  is there an advantage of rewriting contracts in cairo rather than just using the solidity transpiler? I'm assuming you can get more efficient code if you work directly with cairo?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: indeed. The transpiler (when it reaches production and is able to handle arbitrary contracts) will have some overhead. Can't really give an estimate at this point, perhaps @Greg Vardy could elaborate further.

Author: laurip
Content: Is it even possible to transpile contracts fully into Cairo, from Solidity? They have such different paradigms

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: You can (at the cost of a real overhead) but the overhead is still TBD. @Greg Vardy will be much better to reply for this

Author: Tom Brand | StarkWare#1971
Content: You also have the advantage of designing your system with L2 constraints in mind rather than EVM constraints. e.g. - computation is really cheap, so you might want to change your business logic to take this into consideration.

Author: orland0x
Content: Thanks, im quite interested in finding out more about these constraints. Would certain operations translated to starknet be particularly expensive due to greater computation required to generate a provable version of the operation?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Yes, certain operations which are cheap in x86 are expensive in Cairo (or STARK/SNARK proofs for that matter. keccak and sha2 for example), and vice versa (for example, hash functions such as mimc, rescue and poseidon)

Author: zmhh#4661
Content: It sort of seems like a separate memory and the program automatically checks all values in addresses in the range check memory are 0 <= x < 2**128

Author: kassandra.eth
Content: could you write a little example cairo program that shows this? Feel like I just need one example. I'm confused because I assumed it would be like a range check method

Author: kassandra.eth
Content: e.g. something sort of like `[newMemoryAddress] = range_check(x)`. but its more interesting than that (as always!)

Author: zmhh#4661
Content: there is a *stdlib function that does it for you from starkware.cairo.common.math import assert_nn_le

Author: zmhh#4661
Content:
this seems to demonstrate it 

```
%builtins range_check

func main{range_check_ptr: felt*}():
    assert [range_check_ptr] = 5 #program will fail if this is neg or >=2**128
    let range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr + 1
    return ()
end
```

Author: zmhh#4661
Content:
This seems to explain the memory aspect https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/builtins.html

```
Builtins are predefined optimized low-level execution units which are added to the Cairo CPU board to perform predefined computations which are expensive to perform in vanilla Cairo (e.g., range-checks, Pedersen hash, ECDSA, ‚Ä¶).

The communication between the CPU and the builtins is done through memory: each builtin is assigned a continuous area in the memory and applies some constraints (depending on the builtin definition) on the memory cells in that area...

Cairo code may read/write from those memory cells to ‚Äúinvoke‚Äù the builtin. The following code verifies that hash(x, y) == z:
```

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Cairo instructions eventually translate to algebraic constraints on the computation trace. It is not trivial to express "cell x is in the range [0,M]" with polynomial equalities. Common and heavier operations such as range checks are not actually written in native Cairo, but with tailored constraints (analogous to pre-compiles).  The way that it's implemented is roughly by having a dedicated memory segment where the range check constraints are applied, hence from the developer's perspective, to apply range checks he just needs to place the value at a specific place in memory.

Author: martriay
Content:
don't get confused: accounts are not public addreses. It is the case on ethereum, yes, that account addresses are a hash of the public address which is derived from a private key.

Now, account addresses are not accounts. An account has an address, a balance, and an authentication mechanism. What you're referring to is only a private/public key pair, a building block of accounts. The fact that the lastest StarkNet release supports sending signatures in a privileged way (instead of calldata as it used to be) is not enough to make an Account model in the system.

Put differently: just by deriving a public key from a private key, doesn't get you an address onchain, nor a balance, etc (note than in Ethereum, the public key is not your address either, but a hash of the public key). You still need an authentication mechanism, which is not implemented at the StarkNet level but at the smart contract level. Enter then the Account contract:

https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/blob/main/contracts/Account.cairo


Just to further illustrate the point, you still can send transactions without signing any message, as long as someone (e.g., an Accoun contract) ends up paying for the transaction. This is not possible on Ethereum, where every tx has to be signed by an native ethereum account.

Author: martriay
Content:
you can read more about it here:
https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/blob/main/docs/Account.md

https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/577d7a5ca085fc76fb1cb18e04d94991127e3724/src/starkware/cairo/common/uint256.cairo#L41-L42

Author: roboteddy
Content: I agree it looks like a check for `0` or `1`

Author: roboteddy
Content:
if one function is calling another function, the called function should be able to return two values: a length (size of array) and a pointer to where the array begins. see for example`get_claimed_votes` in https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_cairo/voting.html (although ignore the python hints ‚Äî those aren't supported on starknet anyway).

if however you're talking about an `@external` or `@view` function returning a variable number of values through the starknet gateway, then I'm not sure whether it's supported. if it is supported (which I'm a bit doubtful of), I'd speculate it works similarly to passing an array in calldata (https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_starknet/more_features.html?highlight=array) ‚Äî e.g. returning `(varname_len : felt, varname : felt*)`

Author: perama
Content:
Here is an example of a contract the accepts and produces an array:

https://perama-v.github.io/cairo/examples/array_returns/

```)

Content: I'm looking at using cairo to build a private name registry, whereby users can register names and then prove their ownership of them, without revealing their address

Author: liamz4799
Content:
I've got some technical Q's off the bat:
1. I notice there are builtins for ecdsa, sha256. Is sha256 performant? It was my understanding that these were infeasible in ZK proofing systems (though this understanding is 2019-old). 
2. Are the proofs generated by cairo programs that use ecdsa still private? e.g. if I were to prove a signature was valid, then would the pubkey be revealed?

Author: guthl_starkware
Content:
Defined efficient? 
They are Practical yes efficient no. If you can use something else, you should üôÇ

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: Nothing would be private unless you used a zk model on top of it

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: But you could efficiently implement bulletproof on top of StarkNet. Which makes me think that if someone wants to do that, we should talk üôÇ

Author: liamz4799
Content: Haha yeah definitely

Author: liamz4799
Content:
> A Cairo program may have a secret input (called ‚Äúprogram input‚Äù) and a public output (called ‚Äúprogram output‚Äù).
arrr :/ what does "private" mean in this doc then? https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/program_input_and_output.html

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: And ECDSA is efficient üôÇ

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: We are just using a different ECDSA (Pedersen hash + starkCurve)

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: That‚Äôs true for Stark but not for starkNet. We keep data private for cost reasons (like calldata on the L2) but the data will be shared with block explorer etc‚Ä¶

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: StarkNet is not zero knowledge tx environment (as opposed to ZK money for instance). But you can implement zk on top

Author: liamz4799
Content: Interesting

Author: liamz4799
Content: haha this was a blindsight on my behalf. I always assumed zero knowledge rollups implied the entire proof was private, but obviously a ZK general purpose VM is quite the undertaking

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: They are not. They target the same experience than regular chains aka blocks explorer and others

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: ZkTx would ruin that experience for most people (and also create a scalability overhead too)

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: But my point holds. If you want to implement, happy to chat about that üôÇ

Author: liamz4799
Content: will keep it in mind üôÇ

Author: killari.
Content: How does Cairo achieve inequality, bigger than/smaller than operations in the polynomial side? One could list every possible option in the polynomial, but that sounds really cumbersome, is thats how its done?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: No, that would end the world. One bad way of achieving this is "just sending" the value, and have the verifier examine it himself (it would increase the proof size by transmitting intermediate values you don't really care about). I'm writing "just sending" because it's more complicated than it looks. The verifier sees a proof that the prover holds a valid execution trace of a program P. Among other things, he sees a commitment to that trace. If, as part of the computation, I apply a range check to cell (i,j), then what good would it do the verifier if I send him some value which is < BOUND, the naive approach would require me to open the commitment at this location. Luckily, we don't really have to transmit/reveal those values, we can apply some tricks and add a few constraints that would ensure this. You can read about the actual constraints in 9.7 here https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/1063.pdf (this section talks about how to prove that certain cells contain some given data, but the constraints involved are very simillar to what's required for range checks, see 9.9).

Author: julien.argent.xyz
Content:
When I obtain the signatures for a transaction using `get_tx_signature` can the signature array be extended, e.g. can I do:
```
let (sig_len : felt, sig : felt*) = get_tx_signature()
assert [sig + sig_len] = 5
``` 
to add an element? Or do I need to make a copy first then add the element?

Same question if I have an array as one of the arguments of a method; can I e.g. add an element as above?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: I think that you can but you better be careful with that. get_tx_signature is eventually just a function that returns the signature, so right after calling it the returned signature is near ap (spread from ap-len to ap-1). So I think you could concatenate things to the signature just by [ap]=x, as long as it's your first usage of ap since activating the system call.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: There's is_le https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/7712b21fc3b1cb02321a58d0c0579f5370147a8b/src/starkware/cairo/common/math_cmp.cairo#L37 which does exactly that

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Implicit arguments are a way to handle values that are maintained throughout the code, without explicitly passing them and returning to/from every function. For example, if you have a state variable that is evolving throughout several functions, it is probably more convenient to have it as an implicit argument. Read more here https://cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/builtins.html#implicit-arguments. Regarding what exactly are pedersen_ptr, range_check_ptr - read the above page from the beginning.

Author: mottyl
Content:
I'm trying to understand why the following code fails to compile.
I get the error:
`While trying to retrieve the implicit argument 'output_ptr' in:   return ()`
`Reference 'output_ptr' was revoked. func main{output_ptr : felt*}():`

The if statement is the problem, but why? output_ptr was re-binded... 
Is there a way around it?

```
%builtins output

from starkware.cairo.common.serialize import serialize_word

# Returns a^3 for a != 0 and 1 otherwise.
func foo(a) -> (res):
    return (res=a * a * a)
end

# Outputs the value 10^3 + 5^3.
func main{output_ptr : felt*}():
    alloc_locals
    let (local x) = foo(10)
    let (local y) = foo(5)
    serialize_word(x + y)
    
    local output_ptr : felt* = output_ptr
    let (y) = foo(6)
    
    if x == 0:
        serialize_word(x + y)                
    end
    
    return ()
end
```

Author: 0xsean
Content: Thanks!

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
The if is the problem. The return () syntax adds the implicit arguments to the return values, so there output_ptr is needed. However, there is a conclict about which value to return, should it be the binded value from the x == 0 branch (which is [ap-1], since output_ptr is implicitly returned by serialize word) or the binding from the x == 1 case (the local variable). To solve this you need the bindings to agree across all branches, one common way to solve this:
```
    if x == 0:
        serialize_word(x + y) 
        tempvar output_ptr = output_ptr               
    else:
        tempvar output_ptr = output_ptr
    end
```
In the above, regardless of the value of x, output_ptr is bound to [ap-1] (tempvar is syntactic sugar for placing a value in ap and then defining a reference to it)

Also, since 0.5.2, you don't need ``local output_ptr : felt* = output_ptr``, as the compiler now handles rebindings due to function calls when you use the alloc_locals instruction.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Asserting that the carry is either 0 or 1 (only solutions for x^2-x = 0). remember that you only control what goes on in the cairo code, and eventually your proven statement on L1 is "cairo program P executed correctly with output O". You can put whatever you want in the memory using hints, but it doesn't strengthen the proven statement unless you verify stuff in Cairo.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: we do have some docs on hints https://cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/hints.html üòâ

Content:
Would it make sense to add `assert_` functions to the `uint256` library?
Example: https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/blob/980479d6345c5f43c5bb1808eaab8316332df49a/contracts/token/ERC20.cairo#L292-L293
Here they use `uint256_le` which is evaluated using `is_le`. `is_le` is fairly complex compared to `assert_le`.

Author: aundumla
Content: What is `@known_ap_change` for?

Author: roboteddy
Content: looks like it's some kind of hint to the compiler that it should be able to figure out how a function changes the `ap` register. in general the compiler tries to automatically track how `ap` changes during a function call, but depending on the function it doesn't always succeed (for example, `if` statements and jumps can cause it to lose track). here's an example of it being used in the wild: https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/7712b21fc3b1cb02321a58d0c0579f5370147a8b/src/starkware/cairo/common/uint256.cairo#L119 ‚Äî I'm not sure why the compiler doesn't just always try to deduce how `ap` changes... maybe it's an efficiency thing, and it only tries in certain cases if the decorator is present? I'm not sure.

Author: roboteddy
Content: (in general, if the compiler loses track of `ap`, it can cause 'revoked reference' problems to show up which necessitate using locals)

Author: martriay

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: You can only statically deduce changes in ap in certain cases, in the general case this is equivalent to the halting problem. Note that since 0.5.2 you don't have to take care of revoked references due to function calls (compiler does it for you when you use alloc_locals).

Author: aundumla
Content:
What is the difference between:
`[range_check_ptr] = x`
and:
`assert [range_check_ptr] = x`
?

Author: orland0x
Content: Do delegate calls exist/Any plans for adding them?

Author: aundumla
Content:
Why then it is used in uint256_signed_nn:
https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/8eb95584679afef5ad26b98bf32c18bc30d4fe28/src/starkware/cairo/common/uint256.cairo#L118
```
@known_ap_change
func uint256_signed_nn{range_check_ptr}(a : Uint256) -> (res):
    %{ memory[ap] = 1 if 0 <= (ids.a.high % PRIME) < 2 ** 127 else 0 %}
    jmp non_negative if [ap] != 0; ap++

    assert [range_check_ptr] = a.high - 2 ** 127
    let range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr + 1
    return (res=0)

    non_negative:
    assert [range_check_ptr] = a.high + 2 ** 127
    let range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr + 1
    return (res=1)
end
```
?
ap will be incremented in every case, right? it should be possible to deduce this by static analysis.

Author: aundumla
Content: Delegate calls do exit. See: https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/8eb95584679afef5ad26b98bf32c18bc30d4fe28/src/starkware/starknet/common/syscalls.cairo#L57

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Indeed, `keccak` by itself is not sound - it uses hints to "guess" the result and returns it, without checking. But it records the input and output in the given `keccak_ptr` argument. Later `finalize_keccak` should be called to verify that output was indeed the keccak hash of the input. When used this way, they are sound. The reason it's written like this is to allow some parallelization - keccak is a bitwise function that works on 64-bit words. But Cairo works with 251-bit words, so we can compute keccak on 3 instances in parallel (like SIMD). This means that if you use 3 keccaks it costs only one invocation of the `packed_keccak` function.

Author: milan3774
Content:
how can I prevent reference revoking? I've been struggling with this for a while, I have the following contract:
```
%lang starknet
%builtins pedersen range_check

from starkware.cairo.common.cairo_builtins import HashBuiltin

struct TablePlayers:
    member p1 : felt
    member p2 : felt
    member p3 : felt
    member p4 : felt
end

struct Table:
    member idx : felt
    member players : TablePlayers
end

# 0-indexed "array" of tables (i.e. first table is at index zero)
@storage_var
func tables(idx : felt) -> (table : Table):
end

@external
func join_table{syscall_ptr : felt*, pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*, range_check_ptr}(
        new_player : felt, table_idx : felt) -> (seated_at : felt):
    alloc_locals

    let (table) = tables.read(table_idx)
    assert table.idx = table_idx

    local p1 = table.players.p1
    local p2 = table.players.p2
    local p3 = table.players.p3
    local p4 = table.players.p4

    # assign the player seat at a table
    if table.players.p1 == 0:
        local p1 = new_player
        jmp player_seated
    end
    if table.players.p2 == 0:
        local p2 = new_player
        jmp player_seated
    end
    if table.players.p3 == 0:
        local p3 = new_player
        jmp player_seated
    end
    if table.players.p4 == 0:
        local p4 = new_player
        jmp player_seated
    else:
        return (-1)
    end

    player_seated:
    let updated_table = Table(idx=table.idx, players=TablePlayers(p1=p1, p2=p2, p3=p3, p4=p4))
    tables.write(table_idx, updated_table)
    return (table_idx)
end
```

this is the error I currently have:
```
contracts/casino_example.cairo:57:70: Reference 'p1' was revoked.

Author: milan3774
FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
Point is that you can't statically know from where you will jump to player_seated, and the line initiating Table needs to know the addresses of p1,p2,p3,p4. Which to use, those at the beginning or the addresses of the variables inside the ifs? A workaround (which unfortunately also take a few extra lines) is the following:

```
    if table.players.p1 == 0:
        tempvar p1 = new_player
        tempvar p2 = table.players.p2
        tempvar p3 = table.players.p3
        tempvar p4 = table.players.p4
        jmp player_seated
    end
    if table.players.p2 == 0:
        tempvar p1 = table.players.p1
        tempvar p2 = new_player
        tempvar p3 = table.players.p3
        tempvar p4 = table.players.p4
        jmp player_seated
    end
    if table.players.p3 == 0:
        tempvar p1 = table.players.p1
        tempvar p2 = table.players.p2
        tempvar p3 = new_player
        tempvar p4 = table.players.p4
        jmp player_seated
    end
    if table.players.p4 == 0:
        tempvar p1 = table.players.p1
        tempvar p2 = table.players.p2
        tempvar p3 = table.players.p3
        tempvar p4 = new_player
        jmp player_seated
    else:
        return (-1)
    end
```
Note to delete the local variables above. Now p1,p2,p3,p4 are always at ap-4,ap-3,ap-2,ap-1 regardless of which branch is chosen at runtime

Author: 0-one-0#0605
Content:
consider this branch
if x == 0
    y = hash(x)
else
    y = 0
By looking at the runtime/cost, an observer can deduce if x is 0 or not.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Note that the Cairo paper does not discuss properties of the proof system, but focuses on what is the proven statement and expressing it via algebraic constraints. You can prove the execution of a Cairo program in zero knowledge or not (which I think was the issue you hinted at). For example, the protocol that we're currently using is not zero knowledge. That said, even if you want to consider the zk variant, deducing that y=0 from the number of steps is not a problem. A violation of zk properties only occurs if I can extract additional information from the proof itself (specifically, information that I could not have extracted by looking at the input alone). Here, the information is extracted just from the statement (program + number of steps), so no threat to zk.

Author: calabashsquash
roboteddy
Content:
the compiler loses track of refs due to `if`s and jumps. can be worked around by arranging things so that `ptr` refers to the same location in memory no matter which branch of the `if` statement is taken, like so:
```
if [ptr] * 2 == 0:
    serialize_word(123)
    tempvar ptr = ptr
else:
    tempvar ptr = ptr
end
```
if you find this confusing/annoying, don't worry, it's not you üôÇ

Author: roboteddy
Content: another option I believe would be to make `ptr` a local, using `alloc_locals` at the top of your function, and then `let (local ptr) = alloc()`. The compiler won't lose track of locals due to ifs/jumps

Author: calabashsquash
Content:
When does `assert` set a value, and when does it do an assertion to guarantee a statement is true?

I thought it was always the latter but the `assert dict.key = [tile_list]` here: https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_cairo/dict.html#preparing-the-list-of-dictaccess-entries is setting a value.

Author: roboteddy
Content: memory in Cairo is write-once and then immutable for the whole rest of the program execution, so if a value is not yet set, then `assert` will set it; if the value is already set, then `assert` will guarantee that it has the givenv alue

Author: calabashsquash
Content:
What is the point of a hint such as the one here: https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_cairo/program_input.html#hints ?
Why not just set x to 5? Or is it just a trivial example for simplification?

I'm struggling to understand the usefulness of hints

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
hints allow you to delegate more complex computations outside the actual Cairo program, and only verify the result in Cairo. In this example, suppose you want to find the root of a given input in a Cairo program. One way is just finding it yourself, and the other is simply getting it from a hint and then verifying that squaring the hint results in your input.

Note that the bytecodes of the programs are different, one explicitly sets 5 to some memory cell, while the other doesn't touch this address and allows the prover to substitute whatever he wants before proving.

Author: calabashsquash
Content:
Down the bottom here: https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_starknet/user_auth.html#what-if-we-have-an-invalid-signature
it says
```
Note that if we only changed the signature (keeping the amount 4321), the transaction‚Äôs hash would have stayed the same. Since a transaction with this hash was already sent to the StarkNet, the second transaction would have ignored, it would not have been possible to query its status.
```
Is this saying you can not send the same TX twice?

Author: roboteddy
Content: that's right. in practice, real account contracts will have a `nonce` which is incremented for each tx, preventing such duplicates. I think someone from starkware even mentioned that they might end up requiring account contracts to have such a nonce

Author: hubsmoke
Content: The current OpenZepplin account standard increments the nonce only AFTER a successful hash validation https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/blob/4bb1328f79739d60140af1e16a52928e72352a38/contracts/Account.cairo#L173

Author: hubsmoke
Content: ~~Not 100% sure on this, but perhaps this needs to be re-ordered or else your entire Account contract gets hosed for a particular operation if you fail to sign correctly once~~

Author: hubsmoke
Content: If I am correct this means a malicious actor can pre-emptively lock you out of a valid transaction

Author: hubsmoke
Content: I was able to replicate this problem with the OpenZepplin contracts. Basically, with this knowledge a malicious actor can lock out pretty much any deployed Account contract by spamming invalid signatures for otherwise valid transactions. Started a discussion here, I proposed a solution by reordering when the nonce is updated, but that won't fix the problem. The real solution is for StarkNet to correctly support resubmitting rejected transactions or Account contract accepting nonces > current_nonce Edit: made issue here: https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/issues/112

Author: hubsmoke
Content: A better workaround than the above PR is for signer to increase their nonce with a different transaction and then go back and resubmit their original transaction that was previously rejected with the new nonce

Author: hubsmoke
Content: In the immediate term, if an Argent-X user encounters this, they will feel entirely confused if, for example, a malicious actor spammed the network with invalid signatures for common transactions such as minting test tokens

Author: calabashsquash
Content: If somebody is falsely signing transactions and submitting them on somebody else's behalf, why does that even affect their nonce in the first place?

Author: calabashsquash
Content: idk if that's a silly question but why not keep the nonce unmodified if that happens

Author: hubsmoke
Content: I think you're correct, the nonce does not get modified if the transaction fails, which is good

Author: hubsmoke
Content: So in that case, the OpenZepplin contract should be modified to  accept nonces greater than the current_nonce, not just == current_nonce

Author: calabashsquash
Content: Does that negate the issues you've listed above?

Author: peteris.
artemyurchenko
Content: It seems that parens around `masked / WORD` are treated not as a tuple constructor, but rather as a utility for specifying the order of evaluation as in `1 / (2 / 3)`. Thus, the second line should be `let res = (masked / WORD)` or `let res = masked / WORD`

Author: peteris.
roboteddy
Content: try `tempvar (masked) = bitwise_and(packed, MASK2)` ‚Äî return values from functions need to be unwrapped using parens

Author: roboteddy
Content: and you'll probably want just `let res = (masked / WORD)`, since division isn't a function, there's nothing to unwrap

Author: roboteddy
Content: (this one doesn't work because each function call has to be on its own line, rather than nested inside another expression)

Author: machilassab
Content: Hello there - how do you know which pointer to add to a function signature? Namely syscall_ptr, range_check_ptr, etc.

Author: cecco_
Content: I usually check what builtin arguments the function expects by looking at their code.

Author: machilassab
Content: thanks! I was actually looking for a way to infer those arguments from the code. Like "if the code handles hashes, one should use pedersen_ptr"

Author: cecco_
Content: So builints are basically pointers to memory locations thst you use to communicate with the Cairo cpu. Low level functions write to these memory locations to perform tasks like range check, hashing etc. For example see how `assert_nn` writes to `range_check_ptr` so in that case you know you need to pass that builtin. https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/cairo/common/math.cairo

Author: hau.hau.hau
Content:
hey i'm new to starknet and starting picking up some cairo earlier today. one thing i'm still confused about is this: my understanding of zkps is that we can demonstrate to a 3rd-party that something is true. 

for example, in this example we have write our own constraint that x*x = 25 without revealing what x is.
```
func bar() -> (res):
    alloc_locals
    local x
    %{ ids.x = 5 %}  # Note this line.
    assert x * x = 25
    return (res=x)
end
```

however, according to the cairo docs, "The Cairo proof system is used to prove that a certain program runs successfully." this seems like a big jump, what are the "constraints" to show that a program "ran successfully"? thanks a ton!

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/1063.pdf
margins are too narrow here

Author: hau.hau.hau
Content: gotcha thanks, i'm reading through the cairo section right now. what's the tldr from your perspective? not like a comprehensive definition but more of what does "run successfully" actually mean

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: "program P executed successfuly with output O", that is, when executing P line by line according to Cairo's semantics (e.g. when you have a 'jump' command the pc register changed to the jump parameter), you eventually return (that is, did not fail any assert along the way) and output_pointer points to O.

Author: hau.hau.hau
Content:
does anybody know why this works as intended:
```
func main{output_ptr: felt*}():
    serialize_word(1212312)
    serialize_word(4321)

    # test out division
    serialize_word(6/3)

    # confirm 7/3 result
    [ap] = 7/3; ap++

    # serialize_word([ap])
    [ap] = 3; ap++
    [ap] = [ap-1]*[ap-2]; ap++

    serialize_word([ap-1])

    # ret vs return?
    return ()
end
```
but this fails?
```
func main{output_ptr: felt*}():
    serialize_word(1212312)
    serialize_word(4321)

    # test out division
    serialize_word(6/3)

    # confirm 7/3 result
    [ap] = 7/3; ap++

    # serialize_word([ap])
    [ap] = 3; ap++
    [ap] = [ap-1]*[ap-2]

    serialize_word([ap])

    # ret vs return?
    return ()
end
```
this is the error but i'm not sure what exactly is causing it, is it related to immutability?
```
cairo-compile test_main.cairo --output test_main_compiled.json
cairo-run \
        --program=test_main_compiled.json --print_output \
        --print_info --relocate_prints --tracer --layout=small
test_main.cairo:23:5: While trying to retrieve the implicit argument 'output_ptr' in:
    serialize_word([ap])
    ^******************^
/Users/bryan/miniconda3/lib/python3.8/site-packages/starkware/cairo/common/serialize.cairo:2:21: While expanding the reference 'output_ptr' in:
func serialize_word{output_ptr : felt*}(word):
                    ^****************^
test_main.cairo:14:5: While trying to update the implicit return value 'output_ptr' in:
    serialize_word(6/3)
    ^*****************^
/Users/bryan/miniconda3/lib/python3.8/site-packages/starkware/cairo/common/serialize.cairo:2:21: Error at pc=0:22:
An ASSERT_EQ instruction failed: 7 != 2:3.
func serialize_word{output_ptr : felt*}(word):
                    ^****************^
make: *** [test_main] Error 1
```

Author: roboteddy
Content: Haven't looked closely but I'm guessing that because `ap` isn't advanced on this line`[ap] = [ap-1]*[ap-2]`, that the final `serialize_word` is attempting to write the implicit return arg `output_ptr` to a memory cell that already was written to

Author: roboteddy
Content: I think ideally you want `ap` to always point to an uninitialized memory location, and that invariant is broken by the `[ap] = [ap-1]*[ap-2]` line

Author: hau.hau.hau
Content: ah i see, that makes a lot of sense

Author: roboteddy
Content: if you have some integer expression, say `5` or `ap`, and you want to access *the value that is in memory at the location identified by that expression*, you can do so by "dereferencing" the expression using square brackets, as in `[5]` or `[ap]`. I'm not sure why you're getting an error in your code, can you paste the surrounding code as context? it might be because there's a linebreak after the semicolon and `ap++` ‚Äî those should probably be on the same line.

Content:
``=`` statement doesn't handle complex expressions (compiler thing), the same thing is achieved with
``tempvar x = 23*[ap-2]``

Author: loaf1337
Content:
How would one increment a local var

eg:
``
local len

If X == Y
     len = 1
end
If X_1 == Y_1
    len = 2
end
``

Author: roboteddy
Content: what you have written would work, actually! the `if` statements just need a colon after them, e.g. `if X == Y:`

Author: roboteddy
Content: note that because memory in Cairo is immutable, strictly speaking you won't be incrementing `len` ‚Äî instead, you'll be rebinding the label `len` to the value `2`. has the same consequence, though!

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: can you show your code? https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/segments.html?highlight=relocatable#relocatable-values like teddy pointed out, it seems that you return a relocatable value, which in starknet makes no sense (callers are other contracts, they don't share your local memory)

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: like teddy said, memory in Cairo is write once, so you can't increment once you already have a value, only define a new variable (I think you could have the same name, but another 'local' declaration or a reference like teddy suggested is required)

Author: milan3774
Content:
@FeedTheFed | StarkWare @RoboTeddy I took an example from the Cairo whitepaper (sec 8.4), here's the full function I started with:

```
@external
func get_regs() -> (res : felt):
    get_registers:
    call get_ap
    ret

    get_ap:
    ret

    call get_registers
    ret
end
```
I was trying to get the actual values of the registers, I tried various ways to no avail ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Note that the paper does not take StarkNet contracts into account, only native Cairo. What I think happens is that since you're using the more low level ret rather than return (see https://cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/functions.html?highlight=ret#function-arguments-and-return-values), the return value is expected to be in ap. Since you don't put anything in ap, and it contains a relocatable address, you're not allowed to return it. I'm guessing it will not throw this error if prior to ret you will put values in ap. Additionally, see this for obtaining the value of the registers https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/cairo/common/registers.cairo (note that it makes no sense as the return value of external functions).

Author: roboteddy
Content: worked this out over DMs ‚Äî for anyone who's interested, `PRIME - x` behaves like `-x`, e.g. if you want to pass `-3` into a function, use `PRIME - 3` where `PRIME` is the cairo prime, aka `3618502788666131213697322783095070105623107215331596699973092056135872020481`.  We might want to consider making libraries like starknet.js and the `starknet invoke` / `starknet call` commands handle this automatically

Author: peteris.
Content: what's the difference between `rc_bound` and `PRIME` in `unsigned_div_rem` https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/fc97bdd8322a7df043c87c371634b26c15ed6cee/src/starkware/cairo/common/math.cairo#L240 ?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: prime is the size of the field, bound is the range check bound (when applying a range check on x, what is checked is that 0<=x<=rc_bound)

Author: peteris.
Content: @FeedTheFed | StarkWare got it and the `rc_bound` would be 2^128?

Author: roboteddy
Content: if you're compiling for StarkNet ‚Äî `%[...]` hints aren't allowed there except the ones inside the standard lib that are whitelisted. The reason is that these hints can contain arbitrary python code, which would pose a security problem for the sequencer which has to execute them. you should be able to import the `keccak` implementation which is part of the standard library, but it looks like that version is unsafe (relies on sequencer to be honest): https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/cairo/common/keccak.cairo

Author: roboteddy
Content: @FeedTheFed | StarkWare  @Lior Goldberg can Starkware can add https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-examples/tree/master/keccak to the standard library so it can be used inside StarkNet? (it has hints)

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: I think they're whitelisted and you can import keccak, @max_gillett  was referring to the keccak example

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
We will add keccak to the standard library, but it'll take some time. But it doesn't mean it can't be used in StarkNet. As @FeedTheFed | StarkWare said, its hints are already whitelisted, so for now you can copy the files to and import them.
The cairo-examples repo contains a script that deploys such a contact

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: I'll fix that. @max_gillett thanks for letting us know

Author: dewi-tim#8251
Content: So the hints themselves (not the library functions) are whitelisted, meaning they can be used wherever?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: yep, though they're probably cotext specific so I wouldn't expect them to have much use elsewhere.

Author: 0-one-0#0605
Content: I have two questions: one about hints and one about builtins: First, can we use any installed python module in the hints or there are limitations? Second, is it possible to design our own builtins? If yes, is there any documentation on that?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
Hints are whitelisted in the protocol level, to avoid malicious actors taking advantage of the ability to execute arbitrary code.

Re hints, unfortunately, builtin implementation is not documented yet, and it is not possible to add custom builtins (the process of writing a new builtin is highly non-trivial).  One can imagine that once the protocol is completely decentralized adding a builtin could be a governance decision or something of the sort.

Author: guiltygyoza
Content:
Recursion works fine, but I'd like to know if jmp-based looping is generally possible & more readable. Example, in Python 
```
arr = [ my_func(i) for i in range(start,end+1) ]
return arr
```

For Cairo I've tried:
```
let (local arr) = alloc()

# prepare index for looping
[ap] = start; ap++

iter:
let (ele) = my_func ( [ap-1] )
assert [ arr + [ap-1] ] = ele
tempvar diff = end - [ap-1] # <======= **

# prepare next index
[ap] = [ap-1]+1; ap++

# conditional jmp
jmp iter if diff != 0

return (end-start+1, arr)
```

But the line marked with `**` gives me the error: `unsupported operand type(s) for -: 'int' and 'RelocatableValue'`

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: what is end here?

Author: guiltygyoza
guiltygyoza
Content: (I swapped the problem-specific names with `start` and `end` ; obviously `end` won't make it as a variable name)

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: doc on relocatable value - https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/segments.html?highlight=relocatable I believe the above code represents a misuse of ap. still don't know if jmp-based looping with a looping index is possible. sticking to recursion in the meantime

sorry for the delay, you can look here for a jmp based loop example https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/fc97bdd8322a7df043c87c371634b26c15ed6cee/src/starkware/cairo/common/hash_state.cairo#L27

Author: kelemeno
Content:
Hey guys, I am trying to get a simple loop to work in cairo likeso:

tempvar iterator=10
tempvar sum=0

loop_start:
        let (local a, local b)=div (10, 5)

        tempvar sum=sum+iterator
        tempvar iterator=iterator-1
jmp loop_start if  iterator != 0 

If I remove the div function call, it works. However because of the div function call, the tempvar is dereferenced (I suppose, I observe the loop running forever), but when I try replacing tempvar with local, it doesn't work. Do you guys have any insight?

So my main question is, in a loop, when calling a function the ap pointer falls apart, so I would like to use fp, and I thought "local" would do the job. Do I have to use fp directly? that is the only way out that I see

Author: kelemeno
Content: I found this answer now, I will look at it, but I am not sure it solves the problem.

Author: kelemeno
Content:
Related question: in the docs, tempvar is said to be equivalent to :
[ap] = <expr>; ap++
let var_name = [ap - 1]
https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/consts.html#local-vars
Is there a corresponding command for local? I could not find it in the docs.

Author: kelemeno
Content:
I think I found a solution, save the values before the function call in ap, return the fp value with the function, with this fp value you can go back and restore the variables. Implementation:

    tempvar  sum=0
    tempvar iterator=10
    
    loop_start:
       
        [ap]=sum; ap++
        [ap]=iterator; ap++
        let (my_fp, a,  b)=add_one (100, 50)
        
        tempvar sum=[my_fp-4-2]
        tempvar iterator=[my_fp-4-1]
        tempvar sum=sum+iterator
        tempvar iterator=iterator-1  
    jmp loop_start if  iterator != 0

func add_one(x, y) -> (my_fp, q, r):
    let fp_and_pc = get_fp_and_pc()
    tempvar my_fp = fp_and_pc.fp_val
    
    return (my_fp=my_fp,q=x+1, r=y+1)
    
end

Author: kelemeno
Content: @guiltygyoza  @FeedTheFed | StarkWare What do you guys think?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: the short answer is you can't - you can't base loops on local variables because memory is write once, so you must use ap, and like you said, calling functions messes up ap so you're losing the loop variable.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: interesting trick, so if the function returns fp this is possible

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: thanks for pinging - I've been sticking to recursion as I think using ap and fp makes the code not very friendly and impacts readability.

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: that being said I think your trick shall work.

Author: kelemeno
Content: I tried it in the playground, it worked there. Thanks for the feedback guys!

Author: kelemeno
Content: Understandable, but I don't think you can always use recursion, in general you will need this kind of iteration.  (dynamic  programming maybe?)

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Theoretically you could always use recursion (some would say that's what you *need* to do anyway). In any case, I liked this trick

Author: eddie88#9316
Content: `assert` do two things: verify that two values are the same (as you may have expected), but also to assign a value to a memory cell.

Author: eddie88#9316
Content: If the values were previously set it will function as an assert statement. On the other hand, if the value on the left-hand side (in some simple cases it will work with the right-hand side as well) was not set yet, Cairo will set it, thus causing the assert to pass.

Author: rzhang139#8983
Content:
Hello! I'm having trouble understanding how assignments are used. Traditionally I understand how RHS always is stored in LHS variable, but say i have an assignment like this: 
```
func hash2(hash_ptr, x, y) -> (hash_ptr, z):
    # Invoke the hash function.
    x = [hash_ptr]
    y = [hash_ptr + 1]
    # Return the updated pointer (increased by 3 memory cells)
    # and the result of the hash.
    return (hash_ptr=hash_ptr + 3, z=[hash_ptr + 2])
end
```
why is it `x = [hash_ptr]`? Shouldn't it intuitively be `[hash_ptr] = x`? Because the x variable is stored in the memory cell where hash_ptr is pointing to

Author: roboteddy
Content: I think it would be a little more intuitive if it were written the way you wrote it, but the compiler seems to accept each and the statements have an equivalent interpretation because memory in cairo is write-once. You're kind of asserting that the LHS and RHS are equivalent; if you think of it this way, it might be more intuitive that it doesn't matter which order they're in.

Author: roboteddy
Content: (in this example, `[hash_ptr]` is the memory field that hasn't been written to or asserted about yet, so it ends up being the one that must take on the value of `x` in order to satisfy the constraint. this is my intuitive mental model, anyway, which seems to have been working in practice thus far!)

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: when you define a function ```func(a,b)->(c)``` you're returning a Tuple (even if it's only a single element wrapped in the parentheses). Let (a) = func(1,2) allows you to define a reference to the return value

Author: julien.argent.xyz
Content:
Looks like Cairo 0.7.0 supports passing array of structs to external methods, but the structs cannot contain pointers which is a big limitation. One of the clear use case for array of pointers is to enable multicalls in Account contracts in the form
``` 
struct Call:
   member to: felt
   member selector: felt
   member calldata_len: felt
   member calldata: felt*
end 

@external
func execute{
        syscall_ptr: felt*,
        pedersen_ptr: HashBuiltin*,
        ecdsa_ptr: SignatureBuiltin*,
        range_check_ptr
    } (
        calls_len: felt,
        calls: Call*,
        nonce
    ) -> (response : felt):
  # do something with [Call]
end 
``` 
which is not possible with the current implementation . We can work around that (e.g. by adding offsets to the struct and passing the concatenated calldata in another argument) but it will make the code less readable, so is this something that can be addressed? @Tom Brand | StarkWare @guthl | StarkWare

Author: machilassab
Content: Hello folks, since messages can't be added to assert statements in cairo, how do you recognize one assert from another while testing a given contract?

Author: 0xjon#0981
Content:
for now i look for the substring in the error message

I use this in python to test for expected asserts
```
"""Asserts if the given function does not return a StarkException error."""
async def assert_invalid(fn, expected_err_msg=None, err_log_msg_append=""):
    try:
        await fn()
    except StarkException as err:
        if expected_err_msg is not None:
            assert expected_err_msg in err.message, "Could not find error message:\nexpected: {}\nactual: {}\n".format(expected_err_msg, err.message)
        _, error = err.args
        assert error["code"] == StarknetErrorCode.TRANSACTION_FAILED
    else:
        raise Exception("Should not be able to execute fn." + str(err_log_msg_append))
```

Author: axiiiii
Content:
If assert fails in a function, does it revoke any changes the function made before the assert. For example:

```
...
storage_var.write(123)
assert usr = 0
...
```

Will `storage_var` have value 123 even if assert fails?

Author: 0xjon#0981
Content:
`storage_var` will not have value 123 if the assert fails.

transactions are atomic, which means that if anything fails, everything will be rolled back

Author: roboteddy
Content: you can use `--contract` and `--error_message` args, e.g. `starknet tx_status --network alpha-goerli --hash "0xlajdsfklasjdf" --contract path/to/your/compile/contract.json --error_message`

Content:
yes, this change was made at v0.5.2 https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/releases/tag/v0.5.2

In simple cases that do not involve if blocks and jumps, the compiler can automatically decide to create local variables for references that would have otherwise been revoked.
```

Author: chqrles
Content: `alloc_locals` is just `ap += SIZEOF_LOCALS` with `SIZEOF_LOCALS` being computed by the compiler as the sum of the size of every local in a function, to make sure that no ref based on `ap` will overwrite a local ref. I was just wondering, why without any local ref, just by adding `alloc_locals`, the compiler was able to overcome a revoked reference error, and the answer is that since the 0.5.2 update, the compiler automatically declare revoked refs as local if you add `alloc_locals` to your function

Author: anais#7001
Content:
Hello everyone! I have two questions regarding Cairo, I hope this is the right place to ask them. A little bit of context: I have been running some examples on the playground and I realised that right after the memory addresses containing the compiled bytecode for the program, there will be a few (2 or 3) cells containing what I think are addresses to "output" locations or the first address that is empty. Thus, when the return in the main updates the program counter, it gets to read those positions. The questions are:
- How are these positions computed? Meaning, how does the runner know where it will store outputs /ending position before running the program. It looks a bit like the snake that bites its tail. Is this related to the nondeterministic computation model?
- What is the halting condition? If the "final" next_pc indeed points to unallocated positions, perhaps the halting condition is: execute until current allocation pointer <= next_pc ... But in the paper I also found an example with an infinite loop at the end that tried to even the number of steps. 
Any help is welcome üòÄ

Author: martinkrug
Content:
I see now there's a specific thread for Cairo, so I'll let my question also here. Hope it's not considered spam.

Hi good people! I'm trying to code the logic of the game of chess in Cairo. It's already more or less working, at least in the sense that the code computes rightly the list of legal moves starting on a given (legal) position. But the computation time is anything but decent. I'm gathering ideas to make the computation more efficient, at least in the sense of faster... any suggestions on where to look at?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
IIUC the vm first executes the program without outputs (just collects them), and then decides in retrospect the start location of output_ptr (and also the end since it collected all the intermediate values sent to the output).

Re halting condition, I think that in the playground the vm just runs until pc reaches a certain address as you suggested (something along the lines of https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/64a7f6aed9757d3d8d6c28bd972df73272b0cb0a/src/starkware/cairo/lang/vm/cairo_runner.py#L278)
When actually proving the execution of Cairo programs the start_pc, end_pc, and #steps are part of the proven statement (definition 2 in the paper).

tagging @ilya.lesokhin who will know more

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: hhmmm which computation? verification if a move is legal? I don't think you should go over all legal moves, but just check that a given move was legal (if you're writing Cairo rather than a StarkNet contract then you have hints available, so you can get a hint if e.g. you're in check and what piece is causing it, and then verify it in Cairo). Other than checks you just need to know that the position the piece moved to is empty, and that the path was clear (e.g. if it's a rook move then I have at most 6 positions that I need to verify are empty).

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Actually you need to verify "not in check" as well so this gets trickier

Author: ilya.lesokhin
Content:
To prove a Cairo run the memory need to be continuous, with no gaps between the addresses.
But making the memory continuous when you don't know the size of each segment is difficult.
Our solution is to allow the runner to use (segment number, segment_offset) pairs rather than the field elements for addresses.
Once the run is complete we know the sizes of the segments, we assign an absolution address (a field element) to each segment and replace every (segment number, segment_offset) pair with a field element to create a provable run.
https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/64a7f6aed9757d3d8d6c28bd972df73272b0cb0a/src/starkware/cairo/lang/vm/cairo_runner.py#L328

```rb
@view
func get_distance{syscall_ptr : felt*, pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*, range_check_ptr}(
        xmin : felt, ymin : felt, xmax : felt, ymax : felt) -> (distance : felt):
    # Calculate an approximated ineteger distance between two Cartesian coordinates
    #
    #   Parameters:
    #       xmin (felt): value on the x axis of the first point
    #       ymin (felt): value on the y axis of the first point
    #       xmax (felt): value on the x axis of the second point
    #       ymax (felt): value on the y axis of the second point
    #
    #   Returns:
    #       distance (felt): Estimated distance between the two points
    let x_distance = xmax - xmin
    let y_distance = ymax - ymin
    let distance = sqrt(x_distance * x_distance + y_distance * y_distance)
    return (distance)
end
```

Content:
in cairo you only have values in the range [0,p-1], integers in the range [(p-1)/2,p-1] are "treated as" negative.

to use the number properly in python code you can use the as_int helper, example; https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/cairo/common/math.cairo#L298

Author: wraitii
Content: I've made a 'long string' system by storing a 0 / 1 in the LSB

Author: wraitii
Content: because Cairo elements can store 251 bits of data, but the last 4 are essentially free space (251/8 -> 31 and some)

Author: wraitii
Content: So you can just store 31 characters, then a 0/1 to mark the end of the string or not, and it's completely transparent as an array of felt

Author: wraitii
Content: I'm not certain it's much better than checking for 0-valued felt, but it works if you want to store arbitrary-length data neatly

Not in the strong sense of reusing the same frame, as memory is write once.

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: could you point me to the starknet OS contract that uses a dict of pointers? would love to learn from example

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
(I hope I understood the question)
For example: https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/starknet/core/os/transactions.cairo#L345
`global_state_changes` is a dict of `StateEntry` structs, which in turn contain a pointer to another dict (it would have worked the same if instead of `StateEntry` you'd have a pointer directly).
It works as follows: you "guess" (using a hint) the value of the main dict, compute from it the new value of the pointer, and finally call `dict_update` which verifies the guess and performs the update.
Note that due to the use of a hint you won't be able to use it as-is in StarkNet contracts (but I believe that it can be fixed by using `dict_read`, `dict_write`  and a default dict).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: @codemedian , we published the solutions here https://www.cairo-lang.org/the-cairo-games/puzzles/vol-2-solutions/ if you want to see them (though I recommend trying to solve them üòâ )

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: I see - https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/64a7f6aed9757d3d8d6c28bd972df73272b0cb0a/src/starkware/starknet/core/os/transactions.cairo#L373 casting `StateEntry*` to `felt` - thanks for the pointer! will experiment

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: testifying this works - https://github.com/guiltygyoza/cairo_exercises/blob/main/v0.7/pairwise/pair_struct.cairo while still not clear on why dictionary finalization is required i.e. at line 45 where I believe I should finalize the dictionary before returning

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Without calling `default_dict_finalize`, all the dict operations are not **sound**. This means that a prover may lie in values returned by `dict_read` for example.
A malicious prover can make the following code pass (unless `default_dict_finalize`) is used:
```
dict_write(key=0, value=17)
let (v) = dict_read(key=0)
assert v = 18
```
The way dict works resembles creating a log of the operations, and `default_dict_finalize` goes over it and makes sure it's valid and no one lied.
As to where it should be called - after all the `dict_read` and `dict_write` operations were completed (like a destructor)

Author: roboteddy
Content: I haven't understood your problem carefully, but it's likely that the starknet testing library returns `-1` as `P-1`. those two values behave the same way, because e.g. `(3 + (-1)) % P == 2`, just like `(3 + (P - 1)) % P == 2`. so a couple of options ‚Äî you could either specifically test for e.g. `assert l.result == (1, P-1)`, or you could write some kind of python test wrapper that returns `-1` instead of `P-1`.

Author: roboteddy
Content: or perhaps just `assert l.result == (to_felt(1), to_felt(-1))` and implement `to_felt`  to return e.g. `P+x` when `x<0`

Author: Deleted User
Content: Alright, thank you @RoboTeddy. Will the starknet testing lib always return P-n or could it also return negative values sometimes?

Author: roboteddy
Content: I suspect that as currently implemented it will always return `P-n`, but I'm not sure if they'll change it in a future version

Author: Deleted User
Content: Alright, I'll do something which should work in both cases

Author: Deleted User
Content:
In case this can help anyone:
```py
def felt_equal(v1, v2):
    """
    Checks if two felt vectors are equal.

    Args:
        v1 (int iterable): The first vector.
        v2 (int iterable): The second vector.

    Returns:
        bool: True if the two vectors are equal, False otherwise.
    """
    P = 2**251 + 17*2**192 + 1
    if len(v1) != len(v2):
        return False
    for x, y in zip(v1, v2):
        if (P + (x - y))%P != 0:
            return False
    return True
```

Author: roboteddy
Content: thanks for sharing the code! if you want I think `(P + (x - y)) % P`  can just be `(x - y) % P`

Author: guiltygyoza
Content:
following up on dictionary usage: how do I find out the size of a dictionary `dict` after making several writes to it? because I want to make a copy of it via
```
let (dict_copy) = default_dict_new (default_value = 0)
memcpy(dict_copy, dict, <size of dictionary>)
```

Author: roboteddy
Content: I think each write will advance `dict_ptr`, so as long as you keep track of the initial `dict_ptr` think you should be able to subtract to learn the length

Author: roboteddy
Content: looks like `default_dict_finalize` requires both the start ptr and the end ptr so it can use that trick: https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/cairo/common/default_dict.cairo#L34

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
You should at all times have a pointer to the start and end of the dictionary (otherwise you can't squash). The start pointer you keep from the initialization, and every dict operation returns a new pointer to the end of the dict (every operation, read/write/update only appends something to the array, this is why it might be easier to think of Cairo dicts as a log of operations, whose consistency is verified at a later stage).

If in some scope you only have access to the end of the dictionary, then you can perform dict operations but you can't know the size.

Author: codemedian
Content: Hey folks. On this page https://starknet.io/documentation/contracts/#contracts_storage it says that contract storage is limited to 2251 slots. Can anyone explain to me what exactly is meant by "slots" here? If a storage var can't have more than 2251 values, how will tokens be allocated to more than 2251 addresses?

Author: roboteddy
Content: whoa, first I've seen of a 2251 slot limit ‚Äî also interested to learn more

Author: roboteddy
Content: oh I bet it's a typo. it's probably supposed to be 2^251 üôÇ

Author: codemedian
Content: that would make a ton more sense, yeah üôÇ

Author: roboteddy
Content: definitely gave me a heart attack for a second üò¨ . And to answer your question about slots: a storage slot is a single non-zero felt value saved in storage. So for example `_your_storage_var.write(2, 4)` takes a single slot; `_your_storage_var.write(3, Uint256(10, 100))` would take two storage slots because the Uint256 has two felts as members, and `_your_storage_var.write(4, Uint256(10, 0))` would take one storage slot because there's one non-zero felt.

Author: codemedian
Content: is the "key" not counted?

Author: codemedian
Content: guess I could go read the code, but this here is faster/easier üòÑ

Author: roboteddy
Content: I think of the key as "part of" the storage slot. the key gets hashed down to an index which identifies the storage slot. each storage slot requires ~2 felts worth of space in L1 calldata (because have to record both the slot index and the slot value to L1 calldata)

Author: codemedian
Content: ah, right, that makes sense. so the key gets hashed to the where and it's considered "empty" if the contents are all zeroes

Author: codemedian
Content: thanks for clearing that up, appreciate it

Author: roboteddy
Content: (btw strictly speaking, it's not about "empty" vs "not empty" but about which state *changes* needed to be recorded in L1 calldata. If you write `var.write(1,3)` in one tx, and then in the next tx write `var.write(1,3)` again, there's no actual state change and so nothing needs to be written. `0` is a special case because uninitialized storage values are assumed to be `0`, so if you haven't written to key `10` before and you write e.g. `var.write(10, 0)`, you're taking a slot that was a `0` and setting to to be a `0` ‚Äî no actual diff required!)

Author: guiltygyoza
Content: following hyperstructure's immutability property (as opposed to using proxy pattern), we can have versioned libraries (e.g. @DarkosNightmare Influence's 64.61 fixed point arithmetic) deployed at publicly known address and callable (through contract interfacing) by every other contracts. need tooling to maintain a list of all address-library pairs plus function signatures. this helps reduce state bloat at L2+, which could be more severe given exponentially more complex and lengthy contracts. ps: libraries will stay stateless. I think @martriay raised this point on starknet shamans already.

Author: codemedian
Content: Not sure about terminology here, but does that basically translate to "you can have up to 2^251 felts changes"  between L1 commits as opposed to you can use 2^251 felts in storage in total?

Author: codemedian
Content: not that I'd ever hit that limit either way, but still curious üôÇ

Author: roboteddy
Content: hehehe umm of those the latter statement is probably more strictly true ("you can only have 2^251 felts in storage"). But it might be hard to get there, since it's more bits than are in the observable universe!

Content: in the starknet pytest environment, the block timestamp always defaults to 0. however you can "stub in" a new timestamp for testing purposes ‚Äî for an example of this: https://github.com/zorro-project/zorro/blob/main/chain/test/starknet/conftest.py#L35

Author: roboteddy

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
RANGE_CHECK_BOUND = 2**128, you can read more here https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/builtins.html?#range-checks 
TLDR
it's not trivial to check whether or not a felt is in a given range, StarkNet's range check builtin is built to check if an element is in [0,rc_bound)

Author: dewi-tim#8251
starjam#9720
Content:
Hi.  I seem to be having problems using namespaces in CairoFunctionRunner.  Comments welcome.

Consider a namespace

```
namespace Foo:
    func bar{range_ptr_builtin}():
        return()
    end
```

When I invoke `Foo.bar` using CairoFunctionRunner I get this error message:

```
E           starkware.cairo.lang.compiler.identifier_manager.MissingIdentifierError: Unknown identifier '__main__.Foo.bar.ImplicitArgs'.
```

It seems that CairoFunctionRunner isn't finding `bar` in the namespace `Foo`.  The CairoFunctionRunner invocation works fine if I remove the namespace and e.g. call the function as `foo_bar`.

I hope this is clear and I welcome comment.  Thanks in advance.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: you don't need the implicit arguments in the definition of the namespace

Author: starjam#9720
Content:
Thanks for the quick response.  To be clear, my example is simplified.  IRL the code in the function `bar` is more complex and does use range check. 

Does this answer your question?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Behind the scenes calling Foo.bar just applies the call_contract system call with the appropriate parameters (address of the contract, selector of `bar`, and the arguments). The implicit arguments play no role here, although they have to be specified at the called contract implementation (on execution, the os passes range_check_ptr to the external function so that you will be able to perform range checks, but this is not part of the interface).

Anyway, I created a version without implicit parameters and oddly it throws a similar error.  Here it is:

```    # testing here, to delete

```

        struct_name: ScopedName, identifier_manager: IdentifierManager

>           raise MissingIdentifierError(struct_name)
E           starkware.cairo.lang.compiler.identifier_manager.MissingIdentifierError: Unknown identifier '__main__.Foo.bar.ImplicitArgs'.
```

Note that no implicit arguments are mentioned in the definition of `Foo.bar`.

I can also confirm that the call to CairoFunctionRunner has `builtins = []`.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
the trace is not sent to Goerli
You run the program -> create trace (more specifically, a cairo_pie object that contains information on all the memory segments post execution) -> send this to SHARP -> create proof (part of this proof is a commitment to the trace, not the trace itself) -> send to L1 verifier

Author: ilya.lesokhin
Content:
The tail call
return foo()
compiles to
foo()
ret

This only works (and only allowed) if the implicit args and returns values of foo are the same as the caller's.

Author: dewi-tim#8251
Content: Thank you! This makes sense. And these are the implicit arguments for externally calling balanceOf, which are distinct from those of balanceOf in the external contract itself (which cannot be known by the compiler anyway)?

Author: dewi-tim#8251
Content: (which would otherwise be the same)

Author: ilya.lesokhin
Content:
We have an optimization that removes dead code.

Anything not referenced from the main scope is considered dead.

Since bar is defined inside a namespace and not referenced, it is considered as dead code.

Author: ilya.lesokhin
Content: Yes.

Author: hocwyn
Content: Ty. To be clear, the trace (that can be generated and inspected locally) is the matrix (a_i, v_i) and the vector (z, alpha) is generated by the prover, correct?

Author: hocwyn
Content: I assumed this is the case from semantics (I.e. if SHARP is just plugging those quantities into the AIR it is verifying the computation, not proving it, no?) and functionally (a shared prover is useful, a shared verifier less so)

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
You're mixing things up a bit
The a_i,v_i are  (address,value) pairs who form a subset of the memory, the trace is (in high level) the memory after execution, organized in a certain way. This subset is the "public memory", the section of the memory that you want to share with the verifier (which otherwise will see only a commitment).
In the interactive protocol, the verifier picks z,alpha as part of a query (challange) to the prover, but since we're doing the non interactive version (applying Fiat-Shamir) they are technically generated by the prover.

Author: hocwyn
Content: Okay

Author: tonysprocket
Content:
```def create_invoke_command(
    address, name_of_contract, function_name, input_list, signature
):
    cmd_list = [
        f"starknet",
        f"invoke",
        f"--address",
        f"{address}",
        f"--abi",
        f"interfaces/{name_of_contract}_abi.json",
        f"--function",
        f"{function_name}",
        f'--network={os.getenv("STARKNET_NETWORK")}',
        f"--inputs",
    ]

    for i in input_list:
        cmd_list.append(str(i))

    cmd_list.extend([f"--signature", f"{signature[0]}", f"{signature[1]}"])

    return " ".join(cmd_list)```

Author: Oleh#0408
Content:
hi everyone!
Is it possible to transfer ether in cairo, or I need L1 contract to do that?

Author: roboteddy
Content: hi Oleh, there's a bridge that takes ether from ethereum to starknet in a trust-minimized fashion. (it's live on goerli, will end up live on mainnet as well.). The actual eth ends up locked in an L1 bridge contract, and some "L2" eth is minted commensurately inside StarkNet. This "L2" eth can then be transferred around (using Cairo on StarkNet) and eventually withdrawn back over the bridge to L1, which retrieves the real eth again.

Author: chqrles
Content: a smart contract has to be deterministic, with the blockchain in a given state, a transaction `x` must always change the state in the same way

Author: chqrles
Content: so it's not possible to generate anything random

Author: chqrles
Content: On top of that, in Cairo, because your program is provable, the same input will always lead to the same result

Author: starjam#9720
Content:
Good morning.  I'm using CairoFunctionRunner to invoke a Cairo function that returns a value of type `felt*` that points to some complex data structure (think: a felt representation of an ascii string, terminated with -1).
What's the approved way to read that string from the vm's memory, given the  `felt*` pointer as a result?

Here's some illustrative code:
```
struct MyBigDataStructure:
    member pointer_to_data : felt*
end

func id(a : MyBigDataStructure) -> (a : MyBigDataStructure):
    return (a=a)
end
```
Imagine that I have just used CairoFunctionRunner to invoke `id` (performing the identity computation on my big data structure).  The runner's return value is a felt containing `pointer_to_data : felt*`.  So my question is: what's the canonical way to read that data out of the runner? 

I hope this question is clear but if you need further details please just ask.  Thanks in advance.

Author: Oleh#0408
Content:
Hello
Quick question: what is better: create mapping `id -> struct`
or a lot of mappings for each member of struct

Author: _sam___
Content:
IIUC a struct with n members will cost around the same as storing them separately

However, if you store them separately it's more concise to update a single value:

https://hackmd.io/@RoboTeddy/BJZFu56wF#Concisely-update-large-structs

Likely depends on your access patterns and if you will be updating many of the fields at the same time

Author: clacladev
Content:
Hello all. I am learning Cairo and I am following an ERC721 exercise.

I am trying to create as storage_var which is a map `token_id -> Animal` struct. But I am having difficulties to check if I get an Animal struct when I read or an empty value.

```
struct Animal:
    member sex: felt
    member legs: felt
    member wings: felt
end

@storage_var
func animals(token_id: felt) -> (animal: Animal):
end

@view
func get_animal_characteristics{syscall_ptr: felt*, pedersen_ptr: HashBuiltin*, range_check_ptr}(
        token_id : Uint256) -> (sex : felt, legs : felt, wings : felt):
    let (animal) = animals.read(token_id=token_id.low)
    assert_not_zero(animal) # << This throws an error. What is the correct way of testing animal has been found?
    return ((animal.sex, animal.legs, animal.wings))
end
```

What is the correct way of testing animal has been found?
Thanks all!

Author: milan3774
Content:
do e.g. `assert_not_zero(animal.sex)`, assuming 0 is not a valid value for `sex`;
btw you can also return a struct from a func (just FYI, returning a tuple is also fine)

Author: jpick713
Content: right, just be careful you are not using 0 for either male or female as milan said, but thanks again for posting code. always good to read through others and learn!

Author: t_k_s
Content:
When using Cairo's hints, the documentation says that there are two entities: verifier and prover.
I'm still not sure about this.
Can a malicious prover spoof the execution in hints? (If the starknet prover is decentralized)

Author: MatinLex#7524
Content: Hey I'm also ramping up on Cairo, but thought I'd share my understanding: I believe Cairo programming is more like specifying the constraints. In a deterministic program there is only going to be one solution so that's fine and there's no way for prover to do anything malicious, but with undeterministic program pattern when there are more than one solution, than it is possible for the prover to provide a solution that is not calculated according to the hint.

Author: t_k_s
Content:
I see. Thanks. For example, the sha256 function in the following program uses hints to calculate the output and does not check the output.
There are no constraints on the solution(output) in such a case. So can malicious prover change sha256 output to any output, right?
https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-examples/blob/3657496e98b6a8e8107aa78d9d7ebf907b43b7c4/sha256/sha256.cairo#L31

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: The addresses for struct fields are consecutive, hence they are close in the Merkle Patricia tree which means less hashes, so the cost will be cheaper (hand wavingly, you need log # of non zero values more hashes)

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Regarding your second question, handlnig l1->l2 messages in the testing framework can be done via the Postman class, where the operation of the sequencer is mocked (you choose when to consume the messages). See https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/ed6cf8d6cec50a6ad95fa36d1eb4a7f48538019e/src/starkware/starknet/testing/postman.py#L30

Author: starjam#9720
Content:
Good morning.  I'm trying to create a datum of variable felt length in Cairo, then set its value in a hint (for subsequent Cairo verification).  

For this message, suppose the function should create a list of n felts in memory, populated (in the hint) with values of some function `complicated_function`.  Here it is in code:

```
func create_list(n : felt):
   alloc_locals
   local my_list_ptr = alloc()
   %{ hint_to_populate_my_list %}
end
```

By my understanding, `my_list_ptr` points to a new memory segment allocated by `alloc()`.  So from within the Python hint I should compute 

`my_list = complicated_function(n) : List[int]` 

and then (from within the hint) set the segment pointed to by `ids.my_list` to the list value `my_list`.  I can then exit the hint and verify the value which has nondeterministically appeared at `my_list_ptr`.

Unfortunately I can't figure out how to set a segment to a list value from within a Python hint.  I would be very grateful for guidance on the correct way to do this please.  Thanks in advance.

Author: pajkecrypto
Content: Im having trouble understanding how we can assign temporary variables if the memory is immutable

Author: dewi-tim#8251
Content: A temporary variable statement just assigns a value to some part of memory, then gives it a name. It is temporary because we could later assign a different value to another part of memory and give it that same name, updating what that name refers to. It's similar to updating the value but the original assignment in memory is unchanged

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
See the instruction structure here https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/1063.pdf (p.31, examples on p.36)

Instructions are spread over 1 or 2 felts,  `[fp] = 5201798304953761792; ap++` has one felt for the instruction and the other for the argument you substitute in fp, 5201798304953761792. It decomposes to 
` 100 10 000 01 100 0 0 0111111111111111 0111111111111111 1000000000000000`
which is roughly `[ap] = [ap-1]+[ap-1]` (see argument offsets in instruction structure, those are the `0111111111111111`). Since the ap_update flag is 2 you also increment ap, so basically you keep multiplying [ap-1] by 2, putting the result in [ap], and applying ap++.

Author: jpick713
Content:
```
from starkware.cairo.common.cairo_builtins import SignatureBuiltin

# Verifies that the prover knows a signature of the given public_key on the given message.
#
# Prover assumption: (signature_r, signature_s) is a valid signature for the given public_key
# on the given message.
func verify_ecdsa_signature{ecdsa_ptr : SignatureBuiltin*}(
        message, public_key, signature_r, signature_s):
    %{ ecdsa_builtin.add_signature(ids.ecdsa_ptr.address_, (ids.signature_r, ids.signature_s)) %}
    assert ecdsa_ptr.message = message
    assert ecdsa_ptr.pub_key = public_key

    let ecdsa_ptr = ecdsa_ptr + SignatureBuiltin.SIZE
    return ()
end
```
I am trying to understand the ecdsa signature verification...and I am still puzzled how this function actually checks that the message and public key is actually verified here?
I see the hint being used, so is there something going on with that behind the scenes and if so where could I find add_signature for ecdsa_builtin? (i looked in builtin folder and found an add_signature function but it wasn't for ecdsa_builtin...unless I just missed it in my search)
