Author: _ekhidna
Content: Hey! What is the difference in Cairo between a let statement and a local variable, is it only that a reference built with a let statement can be revoked ?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Yes

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
When you use `let`, this only creates an alias to the expression on the right hand side.
Local creates a reference that won't be revoked (and computes the right hand side immediately).
You should use `let` only if you know this is what you need (usually for optimization).
You can find more information here https://cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/consts.html#local-variables.
We also have a playground challenge (Variables) about that (http://cairo-lang.org/playground)

Author: boqdan
Content:
Not sure if there's a better channel but I have a question about this exercise https://starknet.io/docs/how_cairo_works/cairo_intro.html#exercise-a-simple-cairo-program
which relates to reconstructing `x^3 + 23*x^2 + 45*x + 67` for `x = 100`, and I did it in a very naive way, but it says there you can do it in 5 instructions, and I can't figure out how, or more precisely what's missing in my understanding to be able to optimise my naive solution.

What I did is:
```
func main():
    [ap] = 100; ap++
    # << Your code here >>
    [ap] = [ap - 1] * [ap - 1]; ap++
    [ap] = [ap - 1] * [ap - 2]; ap++
    [ap] = [ap - 2] * 23; ap++
    [ap] = [ap - 1] + [ap - 2]; ap++
    [ap] = [ap - 5] * 45; ap++
    [ap] = [ap - 1] + [ap - 2]; ap++
    [ap] = [ap - 1] + 67; ap++
    ret
end
```

Author: boqdan
Content: (also thanks for making x = 100 and the constants such that it adds up to 123456, made it much easier to debug the memory layout and spot the intermediate values, nice touch ü•∞)

Content:
Hello everyone. I'm currently doing Ex2 of @Henri-l | StarkWare's ERC721 guide, and I'm a bit stuck. 

I have gotten the random values assigned:
```
legs: 1
sex: 2
wings: 3
```

My current code is:

```
Interface Contract:

  func get_animal_characteristics(token_id : Uint256) -> (sex : felt, legs : felt, wings : felt):

        let legs = ERC721_legsOf(token_id)
        let sex = ERC721_sexOf(token_id)
        let wings = ERC721_wingsOf(token_id)

        return (sex, legs, wings)
    end

ERC721_base.cairo Contract:

func mint_animal{syscall_ptr: felt*, pedersen_ptr: HashBuiltin*, range_check_ptr}(to: felt) -> (tokenId: Uint256):
    
    let token_id : Uint256 = Uint256(2, 0)
    
    # Ensures the token_id is unique
    let (exists) = _exists(token_id)
    assert exists = 0

    let to = to
    let animal : Animal = Animal(legs=1, sex=2, wings=3)
    ERC721_animals.write(token_id, animal)
    ERC721_owners.write(token_id, to)

    Transfer.emit(_from=0, to=to, tokenId=token_id)
    return(token_id)
end

I've also created a couple of view functions to get the values of a specific token ID to query traits here: https://goerli.voyager.online/contract/0x07351fc00da0e904a31233ef123e745f79868461760d5f0f2549bfd1199498fd#readContract

I've been hacking at the excersize for almost 24 hours, and I cannot figure out what I am doing wrong

Any help is appreciated!

Author: karmabull
Content: In the case that the compiler doesn't automatically rebind a reference when you add `alloc_locals` (like with an if-block), is there a cleaner way to rebind the builtin pointers (`syscall_ptr`, etc.) than doing it manually?

Author: karmabull
Content:
Namely, every time I have a simple if statement like
```
if x == 0:
  do_something()
end
```
I have to change it to 
```
if x == 0:
  do_something()
  tempvar syscall_ptr : felt* = syscall_ptr
  tempvar pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin* = pedersen_ptr
  tempvar bitwise_ptr : BitwiseBuiltin* = bitwise_ptr
  tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
else:
  tempvar syscall_ptr : felt* = syscall_ptr
  tempvar pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin* = pedersen_ptr
  tempvar bitwise_ptr : BitwiseBuiltin* = bitwise_ptr
  tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
end
```
or else the references get revoked. Sorta yucky and wondering if there's a better way

Content:
Excersize 4 - ERC721

Hello everyone, I am on ex4 for the ERC721 tutorial by Henri. My current burn function is

```
func ERC721_declare_dead_animal(token_id):

    let exists = _exists(token_id)
    assert_not_zero(exists)
    
    let animal : Animal = Animal(legs=0,sex=0,wings=0)

    ERC721_animals.write(token_id, animal)

There are no logical operators.. You will have to use some math tricks

Author: _sam___
Content:
a "hash chain" is essentially what you descibe: the hash of an array of items

though, we're *not* concatenating all bytes in the array then hashing:  `H( arr[0] + arr[1] + ... + arr[n-1])` 

instead, it is a recursive call such that the result is `H( arr[0], H( arr[1], H( arr[n-2], arr[n-1] ) ) )`

Author: _sam___
Content:
in cairo (https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/cairo/common/hash_chain.cairo) the call seems a little non-standard, in that you need to have your length & array elements under a single `data_ptr : felt*` like [3, 1, 2, 3] where the first is the length. Instead of `data_len : felt, data : felt*` like most other functions taking arrays as input

in the python helper you linked, it recurses&hashes in the same order as the cairo one. So you can just `compute_hash_chain(data=[len(arr),  *arr])`

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: `let (local a : felt)` alone is not valid, it must be part of a function call: `let (local a : felt) = foo(...)`. In this case `a` is a local variable. (This is indeed a confusing syntax due to backward compatibility. We'll make it less confusing in the future)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Worth noting that for shift-right dividing using `/ 2**n` won't work (since it's field division and not integer division).
You can either first make the last n bits zero before doing `/ 2**n`, or alternatively do integer division using `unsigned_div_rem`.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Try using `call_info.execution_resources`

Author: znity#3108
Content:
In https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_starknet/intro.html
> For efficiency, hints are still used by the standard library functions, through a mechanism of whitelisting (a function is whitelisted by an operator if it agrees to run it, when it knows that it can run its hints successfully. It doesn‚Äôt have to do with the question of the soundness of the library function, which should be verified separately). This means that not all the Cairo library functions can be used when writing a StarkNet contract.

Author: znity#3108
Content:
Here is the do_swap function of amm sample ```py
# Swaps tokens between the given account and the pool.
func do_swap{syscall_ptr : felt*, pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*, range_check_ptr}(
        account_id : felt, token_from : felt, token_to : felt, amount_from : felt) -> (
        amount_to : felt):
    alloc_locals

    # Get pool balance.
    let (local amm_from_balance) = get_pool_token_balance(token_type=token_from)
    let (local amm_to_balance) = get_pool_token_balance(token_type=token_to)

    # Calculate swap amount.
    let (local amount_to, _) = unsigned_div_rem(
        amm_to_balance * amount_from, amm_from_balance + amount_from)

    # Update token_from balances.
    modify_account_balance(account_id=account_id, token_type=token_from, amount=-amount_from)
    set_pool_token_balance(token_type=token_from, balance=amm_from_balance + amount_from)

    # Update token_to balances.
    modify_account_balance(account_id=account_id, token_type=token_to, amount=amount_to)
    set_pool_token_balance(token_type=token_to, balance=amm_to_balance - amount_to)
    return (amount_to=amount_to)
end
```

Author: znity#3108
Content:
If I write this same function as ```py
# Swaps tokens between given account and pool
func do_swap{
    syscall_ptr: felt*,
    pedersen_ptr: HashBuiltin*,
    range_check_ptr
}(
    account_id: felt,
    token_from: felt,
    token_to: felt,
    amount_from: felt
)->(
    amount_to: felt
):
    # Get pool balance
    let (amm_from_balance) = pool_balance.read(token_from)
    let (amm_to_balance) = pool_balance.read(token_to)

    # Calculate swap amount
    let (amount_to, _) = unsigned_div_rem(
        amm_to_balance * amount_from, 
        amm_from_balance + amount_from    
    )

    # Update token_from balances
    modify_account_balance(account_id, token_from, amount_from)
    set_pool_token_balance(token_from, amm_from_balance + amount_from)

    # Update token_to balances
    modify_account_balance(account_id, token_to, amount_to)
    set_pool_token_balance(token_to, amm_to_balance - amount_to)
    return (amount_to)
end
```

Author: karmabull
Content:
A better option is to "precompute" all the powers of 8 you want, store them in a constant array, and retrieve them. So you'd have a function like this:
```
func pow_8(n) -> (power):
    let (pows_address) = get_label_location(pows)
    return (power=[pows_address + n])

    pows:
    dw 0x1 # 8^0
    dw 0x8 # 8^1
    dw 0x40 # 8^2
    dw 0x200 # 8^3
    dw 0x1000 # 8^4
    ...
end
```
then to shift a value `x` by `b`  bytes just do 
``` 
let (shift) = pow_8(b)
tempvar x_shifted =  x * shift
```
Much faster than recursion

Author: zetsuboii
Content: if you set cairoFormatPath to that, and select virtual env as interpreter (ctrl shift p -> select interpreter) it might work

Author: karmabull
Content: `assert` can be used for both assignment, and, well, asserting

Author: karmabull
Content: In this case, because `owner` has already been assigned, `assert` does in fact ensure that `owner` and `caller` are equal

Author: zetsuboii
Content: Oh, I thought since it is a reference it'd be reassigned

Author: karmabull
Content: references are only re-bound with the `let` keyword (or `tempvar` or `local`)

Author: karmabull
Content: Since memory is immutable, using those keywords is the only way to get a reference to point to a different value (more precisely, a different memory cell containing that value)

Content: I see, that was misunderstanding on my part. Thanks for the explanation

@external
func set_cost_schedule{pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*, syscall_ptr : felt*, range_check_ptr}(
        rating_breaks_len : felt, rating_breaks : felt*, costs_len : felt, costs : Uint256*) -> ():
    alloc_locals
    Ownable_only_owner()
    let (current_round : felt) = round.read()
    let (current_round_dao_members_length : felt) = dao_members_length.read(current_round)
    with_attr error_message("already members for this round"):
        assert current_round_dao_members_length = 0
    end

    with_attr error_message("no costs"):
        assert_not_zero(costs_len)
    end

    with_attr error_message("unequal arrays"):
        assert costs_len = rating_breaks_len
    end

    let (valid_costs : felt) = _check_valid_costs(costs_len, costs, rating_breaks_len, rating_breaks, Uint256(0, 0), 0, 0)

    with_attr error_message("invalid costs or ratings"):
        assert valid_costs = TRUE
    end

    let (cost_schedule_write_ptr : felt) = get_label_location(cost_schedule.write)
    let invoke_test : felt = invoke{pedersen_ptr = pedersen_ptr, syscall_ptr = syscall_ptr}(
        cost_schedule_write_ptr, costs_len, costs)
    #assert invoke_test = 0
    cost_schedule_length.write(costs_len)
  
    return ()
end
```

Author: .lev_s
Content: Anyone know if there is a way to work with field elements within Python rather than just ints? Like say I have a field element defined, `x` and I want the hint to do some exponentiation of the field element with a secret field element, `s`. Would there be a way to do this or would this be just standard `x ** s`?

Author: karmabull
Content:
In that case, I'm pretty sure you can just do, in python, `x**s % PRIME` assuming x and s are positive. 

It also might work if x is negative, but I don't remember if % in python is the same as the modulus in math. 

The main challenge is when you get into multiplicative inverses/division. Then you have to use the extended euclidean algorithm https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extended_Euclidean_algorithm#Computing_multiplicative_inverses_in_modular_structures

Author: philip#4143
Content: the starkware 101 jupiter noteboosk use a python field element class

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: You can use python's builtin pow function which takes x, y, m and computes `x**y` mod m (without it `x**y` will be too big). You can use div_mod() defined in math_utils.py in cairo-lang for inverses

Author: .lev_s
Content: Awesome, thank you!

        --output {BUILD_DIRECTORY}/{filename}.json \

        --abi {ABIS_DIRECTORY}/{filename}.json --disable_disable_hint_validation
```

Author: spartucus
Content:
Hi @Lior Goldberg  What's the meaning of `2 ** 127` here?
code from https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-examples/blob/master/secp/secp.cairo#L40

```
# Computes x * s^(-1) modulo the size of the elliptic curve (N).
func mul_s_inv{range_check_ptr}(x : BigInt3, s : BigInt3) -> (res : BigInt3):
    %{
        from starkware.cairo.common.cairo_secp.secp_utils import pack
        from starkware.python.math_utils import div_mod, safe_div

        N = 0xfffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffebaaedce6af48a03bbfd25e8cd0364141
        x = pack(ids.x, PRIME) % N
        s = pack(ids.s, PRIME) % N
        value = res = div_mod(x, s, N)
    %}
    let (res) = nondet_bigint3()

    %{ value = k = safe_div(res * s - x, N) %}
    let (k) = nondet_bigint3()

    let (res_s) = bigint_mul(res, s)
    let n = BigInt3(N0, N1, N2)
    let (k_n) = bigint_mul(k, n)

    # We should now have res_s = k_n + x. Since the numbers are in unreduced form,
    # we should handle the carry.

    tempvar carry1 = (res_s.d0 - k_n.d0 - x.d0) / BASE
    assert [range_check_ptr + 0] = carry1 + 2 ** 127

    tempvar carry2 = (res_s.d1 - k_n.d1 - x.d1 + carry1) / BASE
    assert [range_check_ptr + 1] = carry2 + 2 ** 127

    tempvar carry3 = (res_s.d2 - k_n.d2 - x.d2 + carry2) / BASE
    assert [range_check_ptr + 2] = carry3 + 2 ** 127

    tempvar carry4 = (res_s.d3 - k_n.d3 + carry3) / BASE
    assert [range_check_ptr + 3] = carry4 + 2 ** 127

    assert res_s.d4 - k_n.d4 + carry4 = 0

    let range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr + 4

    return (res=res)
end
```

Author: starjam#9720
Content:
Hi.  I'm trying to import an identifier from a namespace and it doesn't work.

I attach a minimal failing example (try to compile `test_namespace_1.cairo` (this should work) and then `test_namespace_2.cairo` (this doesn't).   Error message is:

```
$ cairo-compile test_namespace_2.cairo --output test_namespace_2_compiled.json 
test_namespace_2.cairo:1:41: Unexpected token Token('DOT', '.'). Expected one of: ",", "as".
from test_namespace_1 import MyNamespace.id as id
```

I have tried variations without success so far, and can find no information about importing from namespaces in the cairo-lang documentation (e.g. here https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/reference/syntax.html#library-imports), nor examples of this in the Cairo source files (grep for `namespace`).

Advice would be gratefully received.

Author: starjam#9720
Content: File attached.

Author: 0xevolve#5922
Content: Hey! Actually this is quite an interesting question and it really depends on what you want to do. Uint256 is a structure and will take more space in memory so when possible just stay with felts. When you need to interact with standards such as the ERC20 from OZ then you can use Uint256 but only where needed or you lose part of the advantage of coding in Cairo.

Author: clacladev
Content: Thanks! That's helpful advice. I did not know what was the future direction. If making Uint256 the standard to have a higher level api or not. But now I get the spirit

Author: starjam#9720
Content:
Hey, I figured it out.  

A namespace is logically the identifier.  Just import the namespace -- you get all the identifiers within it.  A Python class import is conceptually similar (and this may be what the Cairo namespace behaviour is based on).

(It's not quite like a Python class though because the Cairo garbage-collector will eliminate any identifiers from a namespace that are not called from outside that namespace but from within the file in which the namespace appears ... but that can be worked around with a dummy call.)

Author: jerryho
Content:
I'm experimenting with hints and print for debugging purposes.
```
Reason:
1. The standard serialize_word method is not doing well on my side, no idea why.
2. According to 
https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/debugging_tricks.html#debugging-tricks
> In addition to these flags, you can always add a hint with a print statement to output the value of a certain identifier or a memory cell.

It seems that this is the suggested way currently, cause cairo doesn't have log utilities as of yet.
```
I already checked many existing cairo libs using hints, but I don't have a clue - maybe I'm just dumb. 

===

Considering a simple program, size=5:

```
func random(size):
    alloc_locals
    local result
    %{
        from os import urandom
        result = urandom(ids.size)
        print(ids.size)
        print(result)
    %}
    return ()
end

```
This works, with results printed correctly:

```
5
b'\xd6\x99\xdb}\xe1'
```
I guess that the *result* var being used here belongs to inside the scope of hint(python) var. Because even after removing *alloc_locals* and *local result*, the code still worked fine.

    local result
    %{
        from os import urandom
        ids.result = urandom(ids.size)
        print(ids.size)
        print(ids.result)

end

```
func do_stuff {range_check_ptr} (x, y) -> ():
  with_attr error_message("beep, x={x} and y={y}"):
    assert 1 = 0
  end
end
```
calling `do_stuff(1,2)` would print `beep, x={x} and y={y}` instead of `beep, x=1 and y=2`

Hi all, Im using `hash_state` to pedersen hash an array and im struggling to get the cairo version to produce the same hash as the python one. Heres what ive been using with an input `calldata` array of [1]: 
```
from starkware.cairo.common.hash_state import hash_init, hash_update 
...
@external
func hash1{pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*}(
        calldata_len : felt, calldata : felt*) -> (hash : felt):
    let (hash_state_ptr) = hash_init()
    let (hash_state_ptr) = hash_update{hash_ptr=pedersen_ptr}(hash_state_ptr, calldata, calldata_len)

    return (hash_state_ptr.current_hash)
end
```
and in python: 
```
from starkware.cairo.common.hash_state import compute_hash_on_elements
hash = compute_hash_on_elements([1])
print(hash)
```

Edit: Figured it out so for anyone else - You have to add the length of the array before hashing to the cairo function. So actually pass the array [1,1] and you get the hash 3416....

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The problem is that implicit argument is not only an argument but also a return value, so you can't do `{hash_ptr=expression}`

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041

Author: filiplaurentiu
Content:
why I can't use `tempvar` for assigning a function result, like:
```
tempvar (caller : felt) = get_caller_address()
```

Author: karmabull
Content:
I highly recommend reading this section https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/functions.html#return-values.

The important part: "The function writes to the stack its return values just before the `ret` instruction. Thus, after the function call the return values will be available to the caller at `[ap - 1]`, `[ap - 2]` and so on."

The `let x = foo(y)` and `let (x) = foo(y)` syntax just automatically create references to the locations ( `[ap - 1]`, `[ap - 2]`, etc.) of the return values. 

It doesn't really make sense to use tempvar here because tempvar assigns a value to a new memory cell and then creates a reference to that cell. In this case the function has already assigned the return values to memory cells, so we just need an easy way to reference them.

Author: jcob_the_student
Content:
Hi guys,

My name is Jacob Salzberg and I'm a first year PhD student at NYU.

My research group is interested in optimizing the memory representation (eg in permutation networks) of zero knowledge proofs,  hopefully using classical techniques from shape analysis.

However, I think we know a lot more about shape analysis than zero knowledge proofs. Is there any chance someone here knows how memory in cairo works and is willing to discuss potential optimizations?

thank you üôÇ

Content:
it probably will! Thank you! üôÇ

Someone in my research group uses permutation network memory in interesting ways, and is interested in how new mechanisms similar to permutation networks might optimize memory checks.

I will definitely read. Someone to discuss with may help as well...

Content: memory is immutable in cairo as of now, so would the memory checks be as necessary you think?

Author: jcob_the_student
Content: hmm. perhaps not. I thought there were still permutation networks used

Author: jpick713
Content: I think they do plan to possibly later allow for that but it increases the complexity of verification I believe, cause you don't just check execution trace but also memory...but I am not an expert in this area by any means!

Author: jcob_the_student

Author: jpick713
Content: it's turing complete so technically I think you could run djikstra's alogrithm for instance, but it just might be really hard ?

Content: you'd have to modify the backend instructions wouldn't you

Author: jcob_the_student

Author: jpick713
Content: I think might be better to get in touch with @Lior Goldberg , he seems to know the ins and outs of the AIR and cairo like the back of his hand and has thought deeply about this stuff

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: No, network permutations aren't necessary if you add another interaction round as described in the Cairo paper

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Implementing a RW memory can be done in exactly the same way as the read-only one, but it'll cost more per access, so we chose not to go in this direction. (see Sec 2)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Sec 8 (IIRC) describes how to stimulate a RW memory using a non-deterministic read only memory.
And this is what the squash_dict() function does

Author: jcob_the_student
Content:
hrm okay. 

there are drawbacks right to adding the extra round of interaction?

Author: jcob_the_student
Content: sorry I know that's already baked into cairo so it's a bit of a moot point

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
The cons are: It increases the proof size, and requires the proof protocol to allow it.
But it's the best method I know of

Author: clacladev
Content:
I get the following error 
```
An ASSERT_EQ instruction failed: 3 != 2.
        endIndex = totalSupply - 1
        ^************************^
```
when 
```
func tokens{
        syscall_ptr: felt*,
        bitwise_ptr: BitwiseBuiltin*,
        pedersen_ptr: HashBuiltin*,
        range_check_ptr
    }(
        pageNum: felt, pageSize: felt
    ) -> (
        tokens_len: felt, tokens: TokenInfo*
    ):
    alloc_locals

    assert_not_zero(pageSize)

    # Ensures start index is less than total_supply
    let (totalSupplyUint256) = ERC721_Enumerable_totalSupply()
    local totalSupply = totalSupplyUint256.low
    assert_not_zero(totalSupply)
    let startIndex = pageNum * pageSize
    assert_lt(startIndex, totalSupply)

    # Define the end index
    local endIndex = startIndex + pageSize - 1
    let (isEndIndexLessThanTotalSupply) = is_le(endIndex, totalSupply - 1)
    if isEndIndexLessThanTotalSupply == 0:
        endIndex = totalSupply - 1
    end

    # Populate the tokens array
    let (tokens: TokenInfo*) = alloc()
    buildTokenInfoArray(startIndex, endIndex, 0, tokens)

    let tokensLength = endIndex - startIndex + 1
    return (tokens_len=tokensLength, tokens=tokens)
end
```

what is the reason?

Author: philip#4143
Content: You're writing to endIndex twice. Cario's memory only allows you to write to a memory cell once.

Author: lucasstarkware
Content: using locals for every variable will double your step number. You can safely use `let` in your code and for some cases you can introduce locals

Author: lucasstarkware
Content: have you tried using a `tempvar` instead of a `let`

Author: lucasstarkware
Content:
You can do this:
```py
let (res : Uint256, carry : felt) = uint256_add(a, b)
```
and if you don't need the carry you can discard it like so:
```py
let (res : Uint256, _) = uint256_add(a, b)
```
But uint256_add returns a tuple so be aware of it

Thank you very much for your reply. The only thing I'm still concerned about is:
> In some cases, the compiler will not automatically detect that a jump may occur (for example, in an explicit relative jump, see the exercise below) and the reference will not be revoked. However, using this reference in such cases may result in an undefined behavior.

Could this happen with `if` ? More generally, are there any best practises to avoid this? Like... extracting jumps (ie. `if`) in their own function?

Author: 0xTD#8452
Content:
Hi guys, I am using the cairo uint256 library. Do you know how I can send a Uint256 in JavaScript to cairo's Uint256 format. I tried BN.js and thers.js but I don't know if it's really possible.
For my error after testing, they told me : HardhatPluginError: low is undefined

Author: lucasstarkware
Content:
Using hardhat you have to send an object that defines low and high like that:
```ts
const cairoUint = { low: 1, high: 0 }
```

Author: 0xTD#8452
Content: Thanks for your reply but can you tell me more about how this works? I have tried this but if I want to send 250 in Uint256 type how can I find the low and high?

Author: laurip
Content: or with CLI (and in some other cases) number `1` is just `1 0` as parameter

Author: lucasstarkware
Content: as you can see in this picture, the low part is the low 128 bits of the number and high is the high 128 bits of the number

Author: lucasstarkware
Content:
for 250 as it uses only 8 bits you can just put
```ts
const uint250 = { low: 250, high: 0 }
```

Author: 0xTD#8452
Content: ooh ok ok so for 250000 I have to add the high value

Author: lucasstarkware
Content: no, you have to use the high value only if you number is greater than 2^128

Author: 0xTD#8452
Content: Okay thank you very much and sorry if the question was a bit silly

Author: pscott1337
Content:
I'm trying to find the Cairo way of setting a variable conditionally, and using it.
Ideally I'd have something like that:
```
let a = 0
if foo == 1:
  a = 2
else:
  a = 7
end

call_my_fn(a)
```

The way I'm doing it rn is by having ANOTHER function, like so:
```
func get_a(foo: felt) -> (a: res):
  if foo == 1:
    return 2
  else:
    return 8
  end
end

// code in another function...
let a = get_a(foo)
call_my_fn(a)
```

But wondering if there's a better way of doing that that I'm not aware of...

Author: ariiellus
Content: Windows 10 64bits

Author: lucasstarkware
Content: using wsl2?

Author: lucasstarkware
Content:
use a tempvar:
```py
if amount == 1:
    tempvar a = 2
else:
    tempvar a = 3
end
```

Author: pscott1337
Content: Ah that‚Äôd the keyword I forgot existed üòÇ

Content: Thx

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Like Lucas mentioned you can use the Keccak implementation, but I'm not sure what's the motivation for this

Author: stan7717
Content: I'll look into using the Keccak hash then. My use case is still quite experimental but the idea is to implement a modular strategy pattern using the `__default__` function and delegate calls. If you want to know more about this I invite you to come to our talk at the Devcon next week on Wednesday https://onlydust.notion.site/From-zero-to-Cairo-in-5-hours-f2b1da36f34e4c27af026d9dd88b3cfa

Author: jpick713
Content: you implementing a proxy or diamond pattern?

Author: stan7717
Content: Yeah it's a kind of diamond pattern, but without knowledge of the proxied methods ‚Äì thus using the `__default__` function

Author: jpick713
Content: diamond still goes into the fallback function but uses a mapping in storage to map out to "facets" by function selector and then uses delegate call to actually utilize the logic in the facets, but yeah cool stuff üî•

Author: stan7717
Content: oh ok. Then it's a diamond haha

Author: jpick713
Content: yeah, very interesting pattern for sure

Author: stan7717
Content: How do the "child" strategies register their function selectors? I thought about an `init` method in every children, the parent making a delegate call to theses functions in its constructor to let the children update its internal mapping with their selectors

Author: jpick713
Content:
diamond pattern uses something called a diamond-cut...
but essentially there is an enum with 3 options (add, replace, remove) and then that function is called to either register a new selector with an address, replace a current selctor with a new address or remove a selector)

Author: stan7717
Content: I knew I should have read this EIP üòÇ

Author: jpick713
Content: the mapping is stored inside diamondStorage or Appstorage as a "global" storage

Author: stan7717
Content: This is really cool. Quite close to what we currently have ‚Äì though we only have the "add" option. Thanks for pointing this out!

Author: jpick713
Content: for sure, I am utilizing diamond pattern in a project of mine, but it is not ready yet (and repo is private) or else I would share

Author: awolff3
Content: Hey, can someone advice me on when to wether use let, local or tempvar ?

Author: awolff3
Content:
and also detail what is this syntax for ? :
```let (local name) =```

Author: karmabull
Content: You might find this thread helpful üôÇ https://twitter.com/bllu404/status/1504250159408062464?s=21&t=tvqQ1ZbkcC9HIbTUypS9Mg

Author: karmabull
Content:
I'm pretty sure this just copies a function output to a local variable. So it's syntactic sugar for something like 
```let (name) = foo()
local local_name = name```

Content: it really depends on the context  and what you are trying to achieve but if you really want some general guidelines i'd say `tempvar` in `if else` conditions and `local` when you want to use a value outside of the function it's defined. Author: lucasstarkware
Content: you can read this https://stackoverflow.com/questions/71738301/what-does-it-mean-to-declare-a-local-variable-inside-a-let

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: let defines a reference, so no change in the Cairo program itself, useful for setting references to return values of functions. temp var first puts the value in memory and then sets a reference to it, it can be used to substitute a value based on a compound expression. local - part of the function's frame, similar behavior to other stack based languages.

Content:

function(Uint256(x,0))```
Or do I have to do: ```
let (new_x) = felt_to_uint(x)
function(new_x)```

Author: quentinspaceshard
Content:
```func _felt_to_uint{syscall_ptr : felt*, pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*, range_check_ptr}(
        value : felt) -> (value : Uint256):
    let (high, low) = split_felt(value)
    tempvar res : Uint256
    res.high = high
    res.low = low
    return (res)
end```

Author: milan3774
Content: I think the best you can do is have a namespace inside the module and then `from module import namespace` and use `namespace.function()` in the code

Author: lux#4835
Content: basically whenever you do `let (x) = foo(x)` you are essentially unpacking a 1-tuple, because all functions return tuples even ones that return only one value

Author: lux#4835
Content: but when you don‚Äôt have a function on the rhs there‚Äôs no tulle to unpack. like for instance in `let foo = a + b`

Author: calabashsquash
Content:
```
%lang starknet

from openzeppelin.token.erc20.ERC20 import constructor
from starkware.cairo.common.cairo_builtins import HashBuiltin
from starkware.cairo.common.uint256 import Uint256
from starkware.cairo.common.bool import TRUE, FALSE

from openzeppelin.security.pausable import Pausable_when_not_paused
from openzeppelin.token.erc20.library import (
    ERC20_transfer,
)

@external
func transfer{
        syscall_ptr : felt*,
        pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*,
        range_check_ptr
    }(recipient: felt, amount: Uint256) -> (success: felt):
    Pausable_when_not_paused()
    ERC20_transfer(recipient, amount)
    return (TRUE)
end
```

Compiling the above code gives the following error message:

```
contracts/file.cairo:14:6: Redefinition of '__wrappers__.transfer.__wrapped_func'.
func transfer{
     ^******^
üõë Failed to compile the following 1 contract
   contracts/file.cairo
```

I have two questions:
a)  I can't figure out where `__wrappers__.transfer.__wrapped_func` is. How would I go about locating the original definition which I am "redefining"?
b) Is there a way to override functions, like an `@override` decorator?

Author: Dave_#2123
Content: in the beginning x = 1, when you [ap] = x; AP++ , ap  is increased but jump rel -1 revokes this reference, remember when references are revoked its because jmp does not update your ap refrence values for you, AP was increased but the refrence was not updated, so the reference is now pointing to one memory slot higher than it was before

Author: Dave_#2123
Content: stepping through the program using the  tracer, via the-- tracer flag, you will see that when your program jumps back 1 instruction to [ap] =x; ap++  op1_addr = 11. op1_addr is the operand 1 address, it shows which address [ap]=x is pointing to

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The main advantage is that it's more efficient than RW memory (inside a STARK proof). Another nice property is that if you run several programs you can be sure they can't affect one another

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Also, proving things about a program is much easier (if you write 5 to some cell, you know if going to be 5 forever, unlike in RW memory)

Author: laurip
Content: The main thing to understand is that there are only `felt`s in Cairo, no other data types. A felt is basically an integer. So whatever you want to store/transfer, has to be encoded as felts. And to input an array of felts, you need two parameters: the array length and the array data

Author: jedi42
Content: gotcha, to further confirm this, does it mean that the ordering matters?

Author: laurip
Content: ordering of the parameters? Yes, the length has to be before

Author: laurip
Content: ...I think

```
@pytest.mark.asyncio
async def test_approve(erc20_factory):
    erc20, account, spender = erc20_factory

    # check spender's allowance starts at zero
    execution_info = await erc20.allowance(account.contract_address, spender.contract_address).invoke()
    assert execution_info.result.remaining == UINT_ZERO

    # set approval
    return_bool = await signer.send_transaction(
        account, erc20.contract_address, 'approve', [
            spender.contract_address,
            *AMOUNT
        ]
    )
    assert return_bool.result.response == [TRUE]
```

Author: jerryho
Content:
Leaving issues and solutions here, so that people can search for it if they ever encountered it.

Issue, cairo 0.8.0:
I encountered this, due to debug print needs.
You CANNOT print struct's members inside in-line python hint. It will pop up some python cast error:
```
raise CairoTypeError(
starkware.cairo.lang.compiler.type_casts.CairoTypeError: :1:1: Cannot cast 'felt' to 'your_struct.member'.
cast((some_value), your_struct.member)
```
Cause:
Seemingly not supported at the moment.

Solution/how to bypass it:
Simply:
```
let tempvar = your_struct.member
```
and print ids.tempvar, instead of ids.your_struct.member.

Author: lucasstarkware
Content:
Ok there's something that you can already change. This line:
```py
# cast felt to TestStruct*
abi_helper(data_len = calldata[0], cast(calldata[1], TestStruct*))
```
should look smth like that:
```py
# cast felt* to TestStruct*
abi_helper(data_len=calldata[0], data=cast(calldata, TestStruct*))
# note that you can increment the initial pointer so it doesn't initially point on data_len
abi_helper(data_len=calldata[0], data=cast(calldata + 1, TestStruct*))
```

Author: wraitii
Content: oooh that works

Author: wraitii
Content: mh

Author: wraitii
Content:
Then:
`abi_helper(data_len = calldata[0], data=cast(cast(calldata[1], felt*), TestStruct*))`
isn't equivalent to
`abi_helper(data_len = calldata[0], data=cast(calldata + 1, TestStruct*))`

Author: wraitii
Content: which doesn't look right, but the latter works while the former doesn't

Author: wraitii
Content: oooh wait

Author: wraitii
Content: yeah nevermind, I needed an extra `&` in there

Author: lucasstarkware
Content:
this 
```py
abi_helper(data_len = calldata[0], data=cast(calldata + 1, TestStruct*))
```
would be equivalent of that
```py
abi_helper(data_len = calldata[0], data=cast(&calldata [1], TestStruct*))
```

Author: wraitii
Content: This works -> `abi_helper(data_len = calldata[0], data=cast(&calldata[1], TestStruct*))`

Author: jedi42
Content: anyway, what's the difference between `call` and `invoke`?

Author: karmabull
Content: `call` makes a copy of the contract state before calling the function while invoke doesn't. Use `call` if you don't want the function call to affect the state, and `invoke` in all other cases (invoke is also way faster).

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
Some usage examples from one of our engineers who worked on it:

```
let (local keccak_ptr_start) = alloc()
let keccak_ptr = keccak_ptr_start

# run as many keccaks as you want (or verify_eth_signature), pass keccak_ptr implicitly 
let (hash : Uint256) = keccak_uint256s_bigend{keccak_ptr=keccak_ptr}(n_elements=2, elements=elements)

# call finalize once at the end
finalize_keccak(keccak_ptr_start=keccak_ptr_start, keccak_ptr_end=keccak_ptr)
```
You can also call keccak, keccak_bigend and keccak_as_words exactly the same, but for these you have to prepare the input as 64-bits little endian words, or use the helper functions for that, for example:
```
let (inputs) = alloc()
let inputs_start = inputs

# add many words, uints, and felts to inputs, can use the helper functions
keccak_add_uint256s{inputs=inputs}(n_elements=n_elements, elements=elements, bigend=0)

# call keccak with inputs
keccak{keccak_ptr=keccak_ptr}(inputs=inputs_start, n_bytes=n_elements * 32)
```
To get the best optimization we can offer right now, you should call keccak as many times as you need in your code and call finalize_keccak once at the end. 
DO NOT FORGET TO CALL `finalize_keccak`, otherwise you're basically getting the results from hints without verifying

Author: gaetbout
Content: Is there a reason behind the finalize not being automatically called?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Yes, optimizing performance, it's better to do it once after all the keccak calls were accumulated

Author: calabashsquash
Content:
Are `felt` in the range [0, P), or are they in the range (-P/2, P/2)?

This area of the docs suggests [0, P): https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/cairo_intro.html#field-elements

However, places like this: https://medium.com/nethermind-eth/solidity-on-starknet-terminal-velocity-e8df5f63e010
suggest it is (-P/2, P/2). And `assert_nn` exists in the starkware library to check if a `felt` is <0, which seems contrary to the first link I shared as well.

Author: calabashsquash
Content: Or is this potentially a pure Cairo vs StarkNet Cairo thing?

Author: karmabull
Content:
[0,P), but finite field arithmetic behaves in such a way that we can treat the upper half (P/2, P) of this range as ‚Äúnegative‚Äù numbers. 

Try it yourself on a smaller prime field like F_7 to get a feel for it (just do your calculations modulo 7 instead of Cairo‚Äôs prime)

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: this hint is from `unsafe_keccak_finalize`, you should use the safe keccak instead

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Cairo was designed for the motivation of being able to succinctly prove the execution of programs (e.g. program P on input x executed correctly and produced output y, by succinctly I mean that the verification time is much lower then the runtime of P). Theoretically you can do this with any language, but the overhead will be much larger, Cairo's instruction-set was tailored made to be easy to prove.

Author: jedi42
Content:
I think I know the answer, please correct me if I'm wrong.

So the thing is, every deployer have their own Starknet state, so we have to store all of the deployer in the same state, or else, they will end up in different states, which will lead to the error saying that specific contract is not deployed

for instance, lets say we have two contracts, `Account` and `ERC20`
the first way is to make 2 different fixtures functions to deploy them

```async def alice():```
```async def ust():```

but since they're deployed to two different states, we can't sign `ust` using `alice`, because in `alice` perspective, `ust` haven't been deployed

to fix this, we need to deploy them in the same state

```async def alice_and_ust()```

and problem solved!

# Gets the integer lift of a felt
def get_lift(x):

```

Content: I guess they will answer in more detail later on, but a couple of points. Cairo is Turing complete, so YES, you can write whatever you want in Cairo. Also, I guess the main use for L2 right now is scalability, not zk. Although zk is, of course, one of the main feats of cairo/starknet.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Yes, can't have arbitrary python crashing the sequencer's machine. In the future whitelising new hints will probably be up to some form of a Governance decision.

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Nondeterminism has a lot more potential than just privacy. For example, for asserting that an element is a member of a list, you need O(1) Cairo steps, since the correct index could be obtained from a hint. This eventually translates to cheaper cost for this operation (the actual finding of the element is done on the sequencer side, so there is only cloud cost and no on-chain operations).

Author: lucasstarkware
Content:
- for now there's no privacy on StarkNet but no doubt that it'll appear some day (maybe you want to build something?)  
- You can't transpile everything from solidity because some patterns are not supported in cairo (ex: try/catch) but most of it can be transpiled. 
- Writing smart-contracts in cairo allows you to have a more optimized smart-contract
- StarkNet not only reduces the gas cost but allows cheap computation

Author: xenoliss
Content:
Hi there, reading the Cairo tutorial but can't understand why this code leads to `[ap]` being alternatively 1 or 2:
```
func main():
    let x = [ap]
    [ap] = 1; ap++
    [ap] = 2; ap++

    [ap] = x; ap++
    jmp rel -1  # Jump to the previous instruction.
end
```
I understand that `let` declares a reference and then the compiler will track how `ap` changes to replace `x` by its equivalent `[ap - y]`.
But I can't see why the compiler does not manage to keep the `x` reference valid (so pointing to `1`). Seems pretty clear to me when `ap` is increased (and thus how to replace `x`), why is the jump leading to an issue ?

Thanks üôÇ

Author: 0xzenexpert
Content: is there any cairo code to calculate contract adress?

Author: aurelou
Content: Same here

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: hi! just before the jump, what should the compiler replace `x` with? At first you would want to replace it with `[ap-2]` as `ap` advanced by 2 since the reference was defined. The issue is, how do you know when is the command `[ap]=x` executed, if it's before the jump then you'd want to have `[ap]=[ap-2];ap++`, but if it's after the jump then it should be `[ap]=[ap-3];ap++` since `ap` was bumped just before the jump. The compiler can't handle this conflict, you have several paths leading to the usage of the reference, each requiring a different value.

Author: xenoliss
Content:
Hello! Thanks for the answer.

Not sure to understand this part:
> if it's before the jump then you'd want to have [ap]=[ap-2];ap++, but if it's after the jump then it should be [ap]=[ap-3];ap++ since ap was bumped just before the jump.
Does a `jmp` opcode changes `ap` ? (I don't think it does). Here it's pretty explicit when `ap` is changing thus not sure why the compiler can't figure it out

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: I was talking about the `ap++` in `[ap]=x;ap++`

Author: xenoliss
Content: Hm so what's the problem with that ? When `ap++` it means the next reference to `x` should be adjusted to decrement once more

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Yes, but the offset of `x` relative to `ap` depends on how many times you did that jump (no jump, `[ap-2`, first jump `[ap-3]`, ...)

Author: xenoliss
Content: `jmp rel -1` brings back to the `[ap] = x; ap++` so I don't see why you're saying "the offset of x relative to ap depends on how many times you did that jump"

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: `[ap=x];app+` increases `ap` by 1

Author: xenoliss
Content: Yes it does. And it does so **before** the `jmp` so that's 100% predictible how to update `x` then

Author: xenoliss
Content: I mean I'm sure I'm wrong somewhere but trying to explain you how I understand this stuff so that you can spot where I'm wrong

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: let's try an example, you're the compiler, what should `x` in the line `[ap]=x;ap++` be replaced with

Author: xenoliss
Content:
1. As a compiler I have a `counter` of how many times the `ap++` opcodes has been called
2. Each time `ap++` is called I increment `counter` by `1`.

```
let x = [ap] 
[ap] = 1; ap++ ==> counter = 1
[ap] = 2; ap++ ==> counter = 2
[ap] = x; ap++ ==> [ap] = [ap - counter(2)]; ap++ => counter = 3
jmp rel -1  # Jump to the previous instruction. => counter = 3 (no change)
```

Author: xenoliss
Content:
Then we do the jump:
```
(counter = 3)
[ap] = x; ap++ ==> [ap - counter(3)]; ap++ => counter = 4
jmp rel -1  # Jump to the previous instruction.

(counter = 4)
[ap] = x; ap++ ==> [ap - counter(4)]; ap++ => counter = 5
jmp rel -1  # Jump to the previous instruction.

(counter = 5)
[ap] = x; ap++ ==> [ap - counter(5)]; ap++ => counter = 6
jmp rel -1  # Jump to the previous instruction.

and so on...
```

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: You must decide a single fixed offset at compile-time, you don't have access to this counter

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
Not at the moment, can refer you to the docs https://docs.starknet.io/docs/Contracts/contract-address or the python implementation https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/ed6cf8d6cec50a6ad95fa36d1eb4a7f48538019e/src/starkware/starknet/services/api/gateway/contract_address.py#L12

In 0.9.0, that should be available in O(2 weeks), we will have this computation in Cairo as well

Author: xenoliss
Content: So basically after the first `jmp`, `x` will always be replaced by `[ap - 2]` ?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Depends on what you want to do in the compiler, the point is you can't dynamically change the offset in runtime (you must generate some fixed bytecode before you run). So whatever you do, at some iteration you will have lost `x` (whose value should be 1)

Author: xenoliss
Content: Then how do you handle arbitrary length loops ? ü§î

Author: xenoliss
Content: So here the main problem is the compiler can't determine at compile time how to update `x` right ?

Author: xenoliss
Content: Because of the unbounded loop basically

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
loops are not convenient in Cairo, we have recursion üôÇ If you want to see a loop example, check out https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/2abd303e1808612b724bc1412b2b5babd04bb4e7/src/starkware/cairo/common/hash_state.cairo#L87 (you need to make sure that the loop variables are always in the same offset).

It's also problematic to call functions in loops, there's a workaround that was suggested by someone on discord a few months ago by using `get_fp_and_ap` and having the function return the initial value of `ap` (not very elegant, but cool workaround and should work)

TLDR do recursion

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
because of the conflicting computation paths (even one jump would be enough)
I wouldn't say he can't decide how to update `x`, more of he can't decide what's the correct address of `x`

an easier example is with if/else
```
let x = [ap]
[ap]=1;ap++
if some_condition:
   [ap]=2;ap++
   [ap]=3;ap++
else:
   [ap]=2;ap++
end
[ap]=x //x is lost here
```

Author: xenoliss
Content: That's something I can't get my head around. Forgetting about the infinite recursion we had, doing on `jmp` should not prevent the compiler from knowing what's the correct address of `x` is at compile time.

Author: xenoliss
Content: Alright the example makes a lot of sense

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: since you jump backwards, the address of `x` may change depending on the visit index

Author: xenoliss
Content: So basically it has nothing to do with `jmp` or `call`. Both `jmp` and `call` change( or not) `ap` in a predictible way.

Author: xenoliss
Content: Do you have an example where the address of `x` would change because of a `jmp` ?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: well, the opcode itself yes, but when I call a function it may change `ap` in an unknown way

Author: xenoliss
Content: Only if it has some if/else logic with unknown variable right ?

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: Nope, it can just change ap in a way that I can't deduce at compile time (e.g. if the input was prime allocate 5 variables otherwise go to an infinite loop)

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content: The example you quoted is one. The jmp operation itself is not the cause, but the operations between the reference usage and the jump

Author: xenoliss
Content:
On this piece of code, even with a `call` opcode, it should not lead to any problem as `ap` updates are known at compile time right ?
```
func main():
    let x = [ap]
    [ap] = 1; ap++
    call_me(1,2,3)
    [ap] = x
    ret
end

func call_me(a, b, c) -> (d, e, f):
    [ap] = 1; ap++
    [ap] = 2; ap++
    [ap] = 3; ap++
    ret
end
```

Author: xenoliss
Content: I think I understood the idea anyway thanks a lot for you answers btw üôÇ

Author: FeedTheFed | StarkWare#8826
Content:
The compiler would revoke this reference because it doesn't run an algorithm to see if `call_me` always changes `ap` in the same way (such an algorithm does not exist, the problem is undecidable).

There's a special decorator you can mark a function with (`@expected_ap_change` or something of the sort) which can be used for constant changes, but the compiler won't check that for you.

Author: xenoliss
Content: Alright makes sense üôÇ

Mainly  these lines below:
"WHAT CAIRO IS, & ISN‚ÄôT
Cairo is a language for writing provable programs: running a Cairo program produces a trace that can then be sent to a trustless prover, which generates a STARK proof for the validity of the statement or computation represented by the Cairo program. The proof can then be verified using a verifier (which may or may not be on-chain).

**Cairo isn‚Äôt a blockchain language. It cannot be used for writing smart contracts (although it may become that, down the road).** "

Author: aurelou
Content:
```ocaml
from starkware.cairo.common.dict import dict_read, dict_write
from starkware.cairo.common.math import assert_nn_le
from starkware.cairo.common.registers import get_fp_and_pc

func modify_account{range_check_ptr}(
    state : AmmState, account_id, diff_a, diff_b
) -> (state : AmmState, key):
    alloc_locals

    # Define a reference to state.account_dict_end so that we
    # can use it as an implicit argument to the dict functions.
    let account_dict_end = state.account_dict_end

    # Retrieve the pointer to the current state of the account.
    let (local old_account : Account*) = dict_read{
        dict_ptr=account_dict_end
    }(key=account_id)

    # Compute the new account values.
    tempvar new_token_a_balance = (
        old_account.token_a_balance + diff_a)
    tempvar new_token_b_balance = (
        old_account.token_b_balance + diff_b)

    # Verify that the new balances are positive.
    assert_nn_le(new_token_a_balance, MAX_BALANCE)
    assert_nn_le(new_token_b_balance, MAX_BALANCE)

    # Create a new Account instance.
    local new_account : Account
    assert new_account.public_key = old_account.public_key
    assert new_account.token_a_balance = new_token_a_balance
    assert new_account.token_b_balance = new_token_b_balance

    # Perform the account update.
    let (__fp__, _) = get_fp_and_pc()
    dict_write{dict_ptr=account_dict_end}(
        key=account_id, new_value=cast(&new_account, felt)
    )

    # Construct and return the new state.
    local new_state : AmmState
    assert new_state.account_dict_start = (
        state.account_dict_start)
    assert new_state.account_dict_end = account_dict_end
    assert new_state.token_a_balance = state.token_a_balance
    assert new_state.token_b_balance = state.token_b_balance

    return (state=new_state, key=old_account.public_key)
end
```
can someone explain to me how the account token is updated ? because we use the state variable (for me refer to oldstate var)

Author: clacladev
Content: Hello all, I am coming back to an old issue of return an array of structs in a view method. The kick is that there is an array inside the struct (long string). And that is not supported `return value must be a felts-only type`. Have any of you found a workaround?

Author: albert_g
Content: Hey, what is a standard way to import custom functions in hints?

Author: Deleted User
Content:
edit: I'm sorry I think I misunderstood your question, I thought you needed a way to store an array
Hey there, you have a few workarounds depending on what kind of list you want to store

Author: Deleted User
Content: The most simple which works fine if you just want to store a list that can only be extended is to have two storage variables:

Author: Deleted User
Content: 1) A associates an index to a struct (you give the index to get the struct)

Author: Deleted User
Content: 2) B returns the size of A

Author: Deleted User
Content: When you want to add a struct to this array you pay for this struct, its index + for updating the size, so 2+s where s is your struct size

Author: Deleted User
Content: Another solution which brings more flexibility is to use a "chained list"

Author: Deleted User
Content: 1) A associates an index to your struct

Author: Deleted User
Content: 2) B associates an index from A to another index from A or 0

Author: Deleted User
Content: Here when you want to add a struct you need to add it to A (so 1+s) and "connects" it to another "link" within B (so 2) which means you pay 3+s

Author: Deleted User
Content: I use the second solution when I want to easily modify my list.

Author: calabashsquash
Content:
The range check builtin is used to assert that certain values are within the range [0, 2**128). These builtins exist because doing it in vanilla Cairo is expensive, so they added certain low level optimized instructions to the Cairo CPU.

I highly recommend reading the whitepaper for an in depth justification and explanation. Or the "builtins" page from How Cairo Works in the docs.

I'm on mobile now so can't give links but lmk if you have trouble finding those

Content: not possible currently, but will change with version 0.9 (in maybe 2 weeks). at that point, contracts are compiled into a "contract class", which can be referenced by its hash. Instances of a contract can be created based on class hash. So that enables factory-like constructs.

Author: jedi42
Content: hi guys, are there any docs about the tradeoffs of using `Uint256` instead of `felt`?

Author: laurip
Content: the main reasoning is that a felt can't fit all the data of an uint256. So if you want to bridge a token from Ethereum L1, you have to use a different data structure: Uint256

Author: jedi42
Content:
aaah gotcha

as for the context of L2 operations, are there any tradeoffs using `Uint256` vs `felt`? I mean if its going to be bridged into L1 in the end it should be `Uint256` format, but under the hood we're can convert Uint256  into felt vice versa inside the function

Author: eni7912
Content: Is there a way to pass a `storage_var` as a function parameter or should we directly import the storage var from another contract and read from it?

Author: laurip
Content: if some asset lives only inside StarkNet, I don't see any reason not to use a felt. But I think typically things should be L1 compatible

Author: jedi42
Content: yep totally make sense, however im just curious about operations cost of felt vs Uint256. i mean, i totally agree that it should be totally compatible, so let's say we always want to Uint256 as a return value. However, inside the function, we can convert it back and forth from Uint256 to felt and returning it into Uint256 in the end

Author: laurip
Content: you have to remember that if you convert it to felt *at any point*, you may lose data and/or weird things will happen. Otherwise, in general, it's of course cheaper to use just felts since no conversions are needed - the Uint256 structure is a bit cumbersome

Author: jedi42
Content: gotcha, this part `that if you convert it to felt at any point, you may lose data and/or weird things will happen.` is what im looking for. thank you so much ser :StarkNet:

Author: Victor-#8350
Content:
I'm trying to deeply understand memory allocation in Cairo and wrote a simple program:

```
func main():
    [ap] = 1
    ret
end
```
It resulted in this output

```
Number of steps: 2 (originally, 2)
Used memory cells: 6
Register values after execution:
pc = 7
ap = 6
fp = 7
```
The behavior of the `ap` output bewilders me. I expect the program to report `ap = 1` after execution. Can someone please help me understand where is it getting the value 6 from? Bonus points for explaining `pc & fp = 7`? I suppose Cairo is filling in pointers with arbitrary values to start?

Author: karmabull
Content: It's not telling you the value of the memory cell to which the register points, but rather the value of the register itself. 6 memory cells were used, therefore `ap` must have been incremented 6 times

Author: Victor-#8350
Content: Omg thank you, that unlocked a lot of learning for me. Appreciate it!

Author: Victor-#8350
Content:
Hey @bull would you mind helping me understand why an empty program produces these results? 

```
func main():
    ret
end

Number of steps: 1 (originally, 1)
Used memory cells: 3
Register values after execution:
pc = 4
ap = 4
fp = 4
```

It says it used 3 memory cells but states `ap = 4`. Could it be that if a program does not have instructions that explicitly manipulate `ap`, then it would auto-increment?  Is that why 

```
func main():
    [ap] = 1
    ret
end
```

Results in 
```
pc = 7
ap = 6
fp = 7
```

It is missing a `; ap++` suffix? 

I'm also curious to know why adding 1 additional line to the empty program where I state `[ap] = 1` results in 3 additional memory cells as opposed to 1 additional memory cell? Any idea what's happening there? And also at what memory *address* is the value `1` being stored in?  Is it in `[0] = 1 ` , `[4] = 1`, or `[6] = 1` ? Really appreciate any guidance on this topic, thanks!

Author: karmabull
Content:
Good question, I'm not sure. 

As for why adding [ap] = 1 uses 3 memory cells instead of one, I believe that's because not only the value must be loaded into memory, but also the program instructions. Could be wrong tho. The cairo whitepaper talks about this in more detail https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/1063.pdf

Author: Victor-#8350
Content: I'll check it out in more detail, ty ser

Content: Ah yes I'll try that too!

Author: gaetbout
Content:
When trying to manipulate bit, is it normal that it looks like we don't have to access to all 252 bits? 
Even in the starkware code all bit as 1 is: 
`const ALL_ONES = 2 ** 251 - 1`
Does that mean that we can "only play" with 251 bits?

Author: gaetbout
Content:
I know the biggest felt is some prime number on 252 bits but if we want to play with bitwise operation then we can't access all 252 bits and have to limit to 251?
If yes then it is a bit annoying because 252 is a nice number to be divided:
1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 9, 12, 14, 18, 21, 28, 36, 42, 63, 84, 126, 252

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: Because we look for a FFT friendly curve and the largest below 256 bits is this one

Author: jpick713
Content: I'm guessing some really deep math is coming...but what makes a certain prime/curve FFT friendly?

Author: gaetbout
Content:
But then why is it written that a felt is encoded on 252 bits if we can't actually access all of those bits?
I must be misunderstanding something somewhere: https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_cairo/intro.html#the-primitive-type-field-element-felt

Author: codethecosmos
Content: In the case of `ALL_ONES` I believe it is because to represent an additional bit (specifically as all ones) the value would be `2 ** 252 - 1` and this is larger than the actual `PRIME` value of `2 ** 251 + 17 * 2 ** 192 + 1`

Author: gcdepaula
Content:
Hello everyone! I‚Äôm going through the Cairo language docs and looking at some examples. Great community, great project, and great docs üôÇ
 
I have some questions, maybe you can offer some insight!

The docs say that running a Cairo program generates a trace, which is kind of agnostic; we can feed this trace to a prover (implementation not specified), which can later be verified by a verifier. References to this prover/verifier pair seem to point to SHARP and StarkNet, and verification in L1. I was interested in a more general use of Cairo.

I‚Äôm not sure whether I‚Äôm misunderstanding the process. The example setup I have in my mind is kinda like this. Me and a friend agree upon a Cairo program in some way. I‚Äôll run this Cairo program on my machine with private inputs and generate the trace. Then, I‚Äôll feed this trace to my prover on my computer and generate a STARK proof. Then I‚Äôll send this proof to the friend, perhaps with a few extra data, I don‚Äôt know. Then the friend will run the verifier and know the outputs of this program without needing to trust me or knowing secret inputs.

Does this story make sense, or am I misunderstanding something?

If it does make sense, could someone point me to this prover/verifier implementations? Like a library or something that I can compile and run locally.

Cheers!

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: You perfectly understood. Cairo does not have to be on StarkNet but writing StarkNet programs is a lot easier than writing in pure Cairo thanks to all the features the OS provides

Author: gcdepaula
Content:
Cool! Thank you for the reply.

Are there open source implementations for the prover/verifier pair? I understood that Cairo only builds the traces.

Author: swp0x0

Author: lhadri
Content: In this section https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/cairo_intro.html#field-elements I understand that a felt max value is P-1. So when we add 1 we return to the felt min value, that is 0.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: @fredozz @lhadri , in fact both are correct: it depends on whether you consider your felt as signed or unsigned. Just like you may switch between uint64 and int64. The large positive integer P-1 and the negative integer -1 are represented by the same felt

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Use `keccak_bigend` which gets the number of bytes

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: For example, `keccak_bigend(inputs=new (0,), n_bytes=0)` should give you the hash of an empty string

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: If you want one byte it should be: `keccak_bigend(inputs=new (my_byte,), n_bytes=1)`

Author: lucasstarkware

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: If you're building the inputs argument of `keccak_bigend` directly, it should be little endian (that means `byte0 + 256 * byte1 + ... + 256**7 * byte7`), right aligned (so `byte0 + 256 * byte1` if you only have two bytes), packed into 8 bytes chucks

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Yes, you should call `finalize_keccak` for all the functions with the `keccak_ptr` implicit argument. We'll make sure it's documented better.
(as mentioned in this channel, ideally `finalize_keccak` should be called exactly once at the end of your transaction to get the optimal performance. Not calling it at all won't be sound - it'll mean the sequencer can put any value it wants as the result

    [ap - 1] = 128 # verify the result

    [ap] = 1; ap++ # pow

    body:
    [ap] = x; ap++
    [ap] = n - 1; ap++
    call foo
    [ap] = [ap - 1] * x; ap++ # pow
    ret

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
The problem is that `arr`  keeps changing relative to `ap`, and the compiler is unable to track it properly (this is the case when you have backward jumps in the function). Converting it to a local variable (relative to fp instead of ap) solves the problem:
```
    alloc_locals
    let (local arr) = alloc()
```

Author: Deleted User
Content: Amazing, thank you Lior. If that's a problem with the compiler, shouldn't it throw an error and not compile?

Author: merkle

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Usually yes, but backward jumps are one exception - it's not exactly a problem with the compiler, just undefined behavior.
I recommend using recursion instead of such for loops in real code, unless performance is crucial.

Content: Example:

Author: Deleted User
Content:
```
%builtins output

from starkware.cairo.common.serialize import serialize_word
from starkware.cairo.common.alloc import alloc

struct Bar:
    member a : felt
    member b : felt
end

func get_arr() -> (arr : felt*):
    let array : felt* = alloc()
    assert [array] = 3
    assert [array+1] = 5
    return (array)
end

func main{output_ptr : felt*}():
    let bar_ : Bar* = get_arr()
    let bar : Bar = [bar_]
    serialize_word(bar.a)
    serialize_word(bar.b)
    return ()
end
```

Author: xutyr_
Content:
hey guys! I'm on the exercice regarding local variable 
```
func pow4(n) -> (m : felt):
    alloc_locals
    local x

    jmp body if n != 0
    [ap] = 0; ap++
    ret

    body:
    x = n * n
    [ap] = x * x; ap++
    ret
end

func main():
    pow4(n=5)
    ret
end
```
I think the inefficiency is link to the   `alloc_locals` and `local x` declared even if n = 0. But I'm not sure :/ 

So I move those into the body but nothing change on memory side. However replacing  `alloc_locals` and `local x` by `tempvar x = n*n` seem to fix the inefficiency

Author: lhadri
Content: Hi! In the case of n=0, if we don't move` alloc_locals` and `local x` into the body we will have a hole in the memory addresses. That is the memory cell pointed by x will be empty

Author: shashankmestry
Content: Hi, I am following https://starknet.io/docs/hello_starknet/deploying_from_contracts.html documentation to deploy the contract. My question is how can I get OWNABLE_CLASS_HASH?

Author: xutyr_
Content: hey man! thx it's was I thought. However I saw that local variable takes little be more space in memory than tempvar. I don't really get the point to use local instead of tempvar and the opposite

Author: lhadri
Content: Good morning üôÇ I don't think that a local variable and a tempvar are related to a memory space consumption. My understanding is that the main difference is related to how the compiler can track address locations. `tempvar `is based on the `ap `register, so it is susceptible to be revoked if the compiler can't predict its behaviour. On the other hand, `local `is based on the `fp `register, so we  are sure it will not be revoked because the compiler has control over it.

Author: xutyr_
Content: thx for the info üôÇ So in that case what is the point to prefer tempvar againts local. What I understand is your message is that local is better in order to avoid unpredicted behavior

Author: lhadri
Content: In the situation where the choice leads to the same result, at my actual level of Cairo knowledge I don't have a clear answer. But personally in this case I prefer using tempvar just for learning purposes üòÖ

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Indeed, this is a result of this change. To solve it, you can either rename the return value, if it makes sense in the context, or do `let (res) = foo(...)` and then `return (result=res)`

Author: Deleted User
Content: Thank you!

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: The reason for this change is to allow functions to returns things other than tuples, for example `func foo(...) -> felt`. This will then enable to support using a function as an expression (e.g., `foo(bar())` in one line).

Author: lucasstarkware
Content:
what you can do is prefix each nested array by its size like this:
`[[2, 1, 2], [3, 3, 4, 5]]` and you could only use these arguments
```
nested_len : felt,
array_len : felt,
array : felt*
```
You subtract `array_len` at the beginning of every new sublist and decrement `nested_len` at every iteration when it reaches 0 you repeat the process until `array_len` is 0
does that make sense ?

Author: Victor-#8350
Content:
In the AMM example, is the state even changing with these instructions:

```
    # Construct and return the new state.
    local new_state : AmmState
    assert new_state.account_dict_start = (
        state.account_dict_start)
    assert new_state.account_dict_end = account_dict_end
    assert new_state.token_a_balance = state.token_a_balance
    assert new_state.token_b_balance = state.token_b_balance
```

Does the new state now contain the updated `Account` balance? Is there some magic happening to the `DictAccess*` for `account_dict_start` and `account_dict_end` when performing `dict_write` calls? Those struct members should be immutable once written to, no?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
`dict_write` has an implicit argument named `dict_ptr`, pointing to the next **unused** slot of `DictAccess`.
Calls to `dict_write` write a new entry of the form `(key, prev_value, new_value)` at `dict_ptr` and advances `dict_ptr` to point to the next unused entry.
In the example you quoted, we keep the pointers to the dict entries (start and end in the `AmmState` struct).
When you move from one struct to the other, it's like including more accesses to the dict.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: So all the memory is indeed immutable (no magic). The way this works is that at the end you (must) call `dict_squash` which goes over the accesses and make sure they are legit

Author: Victor-#8350
Content: Thanks for replying! I suppose I understand that calling `dict_write` will advance the `dict_ptr` with new entries, but I am still confused why we go through the trouble of creating a `new_state` and assigning it all the old pointers. Can't we just return `state`? Or is there an advantage to creating and returning a new `local` variable?

Author: Victor-#8350
Content: As far as I understand, `new_state.account_dict_start` is the same pointer as `state.account_dict_start`. Is that not the case? ü§î

Author: Victor-#8350
Content: I could actually understand  `new_state.account_dict_start` being the same as `state.account_dict_start`. But shouldn't `new_state.account_dict_end` equate to a new pointer (since we've just added a new Account key pair in the example)?

Author: Victor-#8350
Content: Another way to phrase the question is if `account_dict_end` (passed in as an argument) is still the pointer to the end of the Account dictionary *after* having performed a `dict_write` call. And if it isn't, then I assume `dict_read` doesn't care if it's not the last pointer, as it will still find the latest key pair in a `dict_read` call

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: `account_dict_start` is indeed the same as in `state`, but `account_dict_end` is not. The reason the rest of the fields are copied is that we can't modify `state` (because of immutability), so we must create a full new copy with the modified fields (in our case, only `account_dict_end` is modified).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: While the reference `account_dict_end` starts the same (`let account_dict_end = state.account_dict_end`), it's then rebound to a new value (because of `dict_write{dict_ptr=account_dict_end}(...)`)

Author: Victor-#8350
Content: Rebind!!! Ahhh

Author: Victor-#8350
Content: That'd be a super helpful note to have üòÖ I shall write it down in my learning. Appreciate you @Lior Goldberg  üôÇ

Author: Victor-#8350
Content: The rebind was the "magic" I couldn't wrap my head around hahaha

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: We'll add a comment there, to make it more clear üôÇ

Author: Victor-#8350
Content:
In the `main` function for the AMM example, we see the following:

```
    let (account_dict) = get_account_dict()
    assert state.account_dict_start = account_dict
    assert state.account_dict_end = account_dict
```
How come we are asserting that the state members `account_dict_start` *and* `account_dict_end` are both equal to `account_dict`? In `get_account_dict()`, a new dict is being initialized with a hint. So I imagine the new dict has initial key pairs. Shouldn't `state.account_dict_end` then be asserted with something like `account_dict + initial_number_of_entries` ? That 2nd assert statement is confusing to me, hmmm.

[60, 115, 118, 103, 62, 60, 47, 115, 118, 103, 62]
```

Author: dhruv_kelawala
Content: We can't do that in cairo yet. I was also thinking about a way of doing it. But seems like you have to write a function that does this.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
The low-level dict, used in this example, has a very complicated API, that takes advantage of hints. This is why we generally recommend using the slightly higher-level default_dict. (also, the low-level version won't work on StarkNet because hints are required)
But to answer your question: you start with an empty list of accesses (hence start=end) and the initial values are kept in the hint. In the end, you squash the dict and make sure that the initial values **of the values that were changed** are consistent with the Merkle commitment. You don't care about the other initial values, since they were ignored anyway.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
You can try using `func split_int{range_check_ptr}(value, n, base, bound, output : felt*):` from `math.cairo`.
`value` should be the felt with the short string (not a pointer to it), `n=31`, `base=bound=256`, `output` should be a new memory segment (using `alloc()`).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: I suspect you'll get the bytes in reversed order though

Author: Deleted User
Content: Are you talking about storage variables storing a list using a function which associates a value to an index ?

Author: Deleted User
Content: In these situations, you are the one responsible for knowing the size which means you can have a lot of different ways to do it:

Author: Deleted User
Content: 1) just using a second storage variable which stores the size (quite expensive because every time you add a value to the array you will have to pay for the value + for updating the size)

Author: Deleted User
Content: 0 is the default value, so if you "blacklist" it (let's say you store numbers, that would mean adding 1 to any number before writing it and substracting one after reading it), this allows you to do some cool tricks

Author: Deleted User
Content: 2) just read your array until you reach 0

Author: Deleted User
Content: 3) ask the size of your array in your functions parameter (like a hint) and verify it is correct by checking previous value is not 0 and nth value is 0

Author: Deleted User
Content: 4) use some kind of dichotomia/exponentation like algorithm to quickly find the array size

Author: Deleted User
Content: And a demo:

Author: Deleted User
Content:
```
@view
func test_reverse{syscall_ptr : felt*, range_check_ptr, pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*}():
    let (arr : felt*) = alloc()
    assert arr[0] = 5
    assert arr[1] = 4
    assert arr[2] = 3
    assert arr[3] = 2
    assert arr[4] = 1
    let (rev_len, rev) = reverse(5, arr)
    assert rev[0] = 1
    assert rev[1] = 2
    assert rev[2] = 3
    assert rev[3] = 4
    assert rev[4] = 5
    return ()
end
```

Author: lucasstarkware
Content: Get label location allows you to have a pointer to a function that you can later call using the `invoke` function. Here's an example provided by Lior https://discord.com/channels/793094838509764618/793094838987128843/955560517248909394

Author: lucasstarkware
Content:
You have to use `assert` like so:
```py
    local lower_pair : Pair
    local higher_pair : Pair

    # Get the higher/lower pair based on prices
    let (is_le_price0_price1) = is_le(price0, price1)  # base token cheaper on pair 0
    if is_le_price0_price1 == TRUE:
        assert lower_pair = pair1
        assert higher_pair = pair2
    else:
        assert lower_pair = pair2
        assert higher_pair = pair1
    end
```

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
You need to provide a bound on the result to prevent overflows in the computation. If all the values you're dealing with are 64-bit integers, you should be ok with setting `bound=2^64`
If you're dealing with larger value you may need to pick bound more carefully to make sure the assumptions hold.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: On the contrary. `ACCEPTED_ON_L1` is stronger. It implies `ACCEPTED_ON_L2`

Author: Jedward#3272
Content:
Hi guys, I am going through the syscall messaging source code and have found this function:

```
func call_contract{syscall_ptr : felt*}(
    contract_address : felt, function_selector : felt, calldata_size : felt, calldata : felt*
) -> (retdata_size : felt, retdata : felt*):
    let syscall = [cast(syscall_ptr, CallContract*)]
    assert syscall.request = CallContractRequest(
        selector=CALL_CONTRACT_SELECTOR,
        contract_address=contract_address,
        function_selector=function_selector,
        calldata_size=calldata_size,
        calldata=calldata)
    %{ syscall_handler.call_contract(segments=segments, syscall_ptr=ids.syscall_ptr) %}
    let response = syscall.response

    let syscall_ptr = syscall_ptr + CallContract.SIZE
    return (retdata_size=response.retdata_size, retdata=response.retdata)
end
```

I was wondering if someone could help explain the syntax around this line: 
```
    let syscall = [cast(syscall_ptr, CallContract*)]
```
I understand that is essentially formatting syscall. 

Cheers.

Author: 0xstarkweel#5047
eddie88#9316
Content:
Cairo doesn‚Äôt support strings at the moment, and when it does, strings will be represented using " rather than ' (similar to the distinction in C/C++).
Alternatively, a short string is a string whose length is at most 31 characters, and therefore can fit into a single field element.
[ap] = 'hello'
which is equivalent to
[ap] = 0x68656c6c6f
It is important to note that a short-string is simply a way to represent a field element, it‚Äôs not a real string. 
The string‚Äôs first character is the most significant byte of the integer (big endian representation).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: syscall is given as a pointer to `felt`, which is Cairo's way of saying an untyped pointer (like `void*` in C). The cast operator instructs the compiler to treat this pointer as a pointer to the `CallContract` struct (defined above) and the `[]` takes the value at this address. In other words, `syscall` is a reference to the `CallContract` struct that starts at address `syscall_ptr`.

Content: Okay, so the behaviour is such that any function in the main scope (I called them "non-namespaced") is present in the bytecode, but it's not the case for namespaced (not in the main scope) ones. They are present in the bytecode, only if they are reachable from the non-namespaced ones
