Author: aundumla
zorozor1
Content: Fiddling with Cairo, why doesn't line 15 work as a replacement for line 14? I would think that loading the hash_ptr back onto the stack would be the correct way to return the updated location of the pedersen_ptr?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Yes, this is true. There's a compiler flag to disable this optimization if needed.
Functions in the main module (excluding imported functions and namespaced functions), external functions, and any function used by all of them are compiled.
So `main()` is not special in that sense.
Why do you need other functions compiled (given that they are not used)?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
`return ()` is a high level cairo statement that pushes pedersen_ptr on the stack. If you want to do it yourself, use `ret` instead.
(Though this is mainly useful if you really need to work with the low level Cairo. I wouldn't recommend doing that in production code unless there's a good reason)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: It is not really required, it's there just to give a more explicit failure message. You can achieve a similar result with `with_attr error_message` without using hints

    assert 3 = result[2]
    assert 4 = result[3]

Author: tekkac
Content:
Indeed, I wasn't very clear.
The trick I mentioned will only make sure you don't accidentally assign some value to `arr[0]`, e.g. when doing testing.
(Both instructions do not compile to the same low-level code.)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Ah, you're right, they **don't** compile to the same low level code.
As you said, this should only be used for testing (since a malicious prover may add a hint that will make the code pass).
Also, this should be treated carefully, since, for example if you replace the `1` with a variable `x` they will compile to the same bytecode.

```
from starkware.cairo.common.alloc import alloc

func main():
    let (arr : felt*) = alloc()
    tempvar x : felt = 0
    assert x = arr[0]  # This line and the next compile to 0x400080007ffe7fff
    assert arr[0] = x
    assert 1 = arr[1]
    assert arr[1] = 1
    ret
end
```
(You can copy-paste this into the playground https://www.cairo-lang.org/playground/)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Another trick to make sure a value is initialized (for testing only) is `tempvar x = arr[0]` - in this case `x` is unknown and if `arr[0]` is also unknown it'll fail.

Author: Deleted User
Content: make sure to not use let for bar if you want to get its address

Author: .strangerv
Content: let me try it

Author: Deleted User
Content: full code :

Author: Deleted User
Content:
```
%builtins output

from starkware.cairo.common.serialize import serialize_word
from starkware.cairo.common.alloc import alloc

struct Bar:
    member a : felt
    member b : felt
end

func main{output_ptr : felt*}():
    tempvar bar : Bar = Bar(1, 2)
    let bar_fields : felt* = &bar
    assert bar_fields[0] = 1
    assert bar_fields[1] = 2

    return ()
end
```

Author: Bohadana#8393
Content:
try this: 
- if you are getting the gmp.h error do the following:
    1. first install gmp with brew `brew install gmp`
    2. then:
        
        `CFLAGS=-I`brew --prefix gmp`/include LDFLAGS=-L`brew --prefix gmp`/lib pip install ecdsa fastecdsa sympy`
        
    3. if above (2) doesn‚Äôt work:
        1. find the path to gmp with `find /usr /opt -name "gmp.h"`
        2. export enviroment variable to the path of the gmp. (change the path in the example according to your local path). `export "CFLAGS=-I/usr/local/include -L/usr/local/lib"`
        3. export ‚ÄúCFLAGS=-I/opt/homebrew/Cellar/gmp/6.2.1_1/include/

Author: sa.bur.o
Content: Any hints on working with the result of `unsigned_div_rem()` if I want to e.g. multiply it or use it further?

Author: sa.bur.o
Content: Also Cairo Playground shows it as a single number, is it `q` or `r`?

Author: tekkac
Content:
unsigned_div_rem returns a tuple (q,r): the quotient and the remainder (modulo)
`unsigned_div_rem(a,b) = (q,r)` where `a = b*q + r`
if you're only interested in the quotient you could write
`let (q,_) = unsigned_div_rem(a,b)`

Author: sa.bur.o
Content:
Thanks, if say I need to divide 250/38 and then multiply it with 50 and get a precise result
```
let (q, _) = unsigned_div_rem(250, 38)
let result = q * 50
```

Author: sa.bur.o
Content: This gives me 300 in Cairo PlayGround, since quotient is 6 and 6 * 50 = 300

Author: sa.bur.o
Content: How can I obtain a precise result, which is 328 + 0.947368?

Author: tekkac
Content:
You can't do it with `unsigned_div_rem` which only deals with integer division and modulo (up to `2**128`). 
If you need decimals you will need to use a lib that can handles ratios, you can find some here: <https://github.com/beautyisourbusiness/cairo-goldmine#math>

Author: sa.bur.o
Content: Thanks, didn't think it's so complicated, could you please point me to any example of doing basic math if you saw any?

Author: tekkac
Content:
it's _complicated_ because Cairo knows only felts (field elements) which are integers modulo PRIME. There is no notion of decimals, therefore you have to code it yourself.
Simplest example I can think of is <https://community.starknet.io/t/library-for-math-with-quotients-in-cairo/236/2>

Author: Deleted User
Content: It's an interesting question. I don't think it is possible to represent a struct which contains an array in a view function. This is not a problem when you want to return a single struct (you can just return the struct content instead), but it's a problem if you want to return a struct containing an array within another struct or array. The only way to do it I can think of is to return a big array (arr_len, arr) which is in fact the concatenated [arr_len :: array_values] of all the arrays you want to send, and use their index in your structs, but this is a really complex way to do it. I'm interested if anyone has a better suggestion

Author: eni7912
Content: So you would only have 1 write instead of `n_members` writes ?

Author: eni7912
Content:
Here's a function you can use to easily update a struct 
```py
# @notice Modifies a struct by replacing a member with the specified value.
# @param struct_fields a pointer to the original struct
# @param struct_size size of the struct
# @param member_value pointer to the value of the member to be replaced
# @param member_index index of the member to be replaced
func update_struct{range_check_ptr}(
    struct_fields : felt*, struct_size : felt, member_value_ptr : felt*, member_index : felt
) -> (modified_struct : felt*):
    alloc_locals
    assert_lt(member_index, struct_size)
    let (local res : felt*) = alloc()

    memcpy(res, struct_fields, member_index)  # copy member_index elems from struct_fields to res
    memcpy(res + member_index, member_value_ptr, 1)  # store member_value at memory cell [res+member_index]
    memcpy(res + member_index + 1, struct_fields + member_index + 1, struct_size - member_index - 1)  # copy the rest of the struct_fields to res

    return (res)
end
```

Content: But let‚Äôs say this struct contains user addresses and you just want them to not be real user addresses

Author: Deleted User
Content: You might want to just switch one bit of those adresses (eg add 1 if it is divisible by 2, otherwise remove 1). That way if in the future price of transaction depends on the amount of bits changed you will pay dozens times less than by replacing it by 0

Content: For example when someone wants to burn a NFT, changing a bit is fine because you don‚Äôt need to know if that address is real or not

Author: udayj.
Content:
The following code gives a reference revoked error

`tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr

    if x == 2:
        
        if y == 1:
           
            assert_le(a, b)
            tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
            assert_le(b, c)
             tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
        else:
            assert_le(d, e)
            tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
            assert_le(e, f)
            tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
        end
  
    end
  assert_le(v,w)`

whereas this code compiles without any error

`tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr

    if x == 2:
        
        if y == 1:
           
            assert_le(a, b)
            tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
            assert_le(b, c)
             tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
        else:
            assert_le(d, e)
            tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
            assert_le(e, f)
            tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
        end
    else:
        tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
    end
  assert_le(v,w)`

@Lucas | StarkWare shouldnt the forst snippet also compile ?...the reference to the range_check_ptr is being stored in both branches of the inner if statement

Author: lucasstarkware
Content:
No
```py
if x == 2:
# If x != 2 we go directly in the else statement (which doesn't exist) and range check is not stored        
        if y == 1:
           
            assert_le(a, b)
            tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
            assert_le(b, c)
             tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
        else:
            assert_le(d, e)
            tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
            assert_le(e, f)
            tempvar range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr
        end
    end
  assert_le(v,w)
```

Author: rayquaza7
Content: Hey! I had a question, in `starknet-cairo-101/contracts/ex09.cairo`, inside the recursive function `get_sum_internal` I dont understand how this line `let sum = [array] + current_sum` works. u have a `felt*` and a `felt`, what happens when u add those?

Author: milan3774
Content: `[array]` is a `felt`, because `[]` is acts as an operator to get a value at a particular memory location - turns a pointer to a value (`felt*`) into a value (`felt`)

Author: rayquaza7
Content: so what would this mean: [10,20]+10? will it be [20,20]?

Author: milan3774
Content: `[]` is the operator, `array` is a variable name holding a memory address - in this case, don't think of it as a literal array, but as an array element, or rather an pointer to an array element and using the `[]` operator "makes it" the array element; see https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/reference/syntax.html#expressions or https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/reference/syntax.html#punctuation

Author: distracteddev
Content:
Can anyone help me through this revoked reference problem?

```
@external
func deposit{
        syscall_ptr : felt*, 
        pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*,
        range_check_ptr
    }(
        token_standard: felt,
        token: felt,
        token_id: Uint256,
        amount: Uint256
    ):
    alloc_locals
    
    local syscall_ptr: felt* = syscall_ptr
    local pedersen_ptr: HashBuiltin* = pedersen_ptr
    local range_check_ptr = range_check_ptr

    if token_standard == TokenStandard.ERC721:
        let (check_one) = uint256_eq(amount, Uint256(1,0))
        with_attr error_message("Guild Contract: ERC721 amount must be 1"):
            assert check_one = TRUE
        end
    end

    let (guild_certificate) = _guild_certificate.read()
```
gives
```
contracts/GuildContract.cairo:708:31: While trying to retrieve the implicit argument 'range_check_ptr' in:
    let (guild_certificate) = _guild_certificate.read()
                              ^***********************^
autogen/starknet/storage_var/_guild_certificate/decl.cairo:13:65: Reference 'range_check_ptr' was revoked.
    func read{syscall_ptr : felt*, pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*, range_check_ptr}() -> (res : felt):
                                                                ^*************^
üõë Failed to compile the following 1 contract:
   contracts/GuildContract.cairo
```

Author: eni7912
machilassab
Content: it depends on how you operate on bytes, the table to look at is available here: https://docs.starknet.io/docs/Fees/fee-mechanism. generally speaking, I wouldn't recommend to optimize your code too early

Author: distracteddev
Content: This works! Thanks a lot, any insight into why pre-defining as locals doesn't?

Author: eni7912
Content:
There's one branch in which your range_check_ptr is used and incremented while not in the other branch so the compiler doesn't know where to find it in the stack I believe.
By doing this you're explicitly assigning range_check_ptr to its current value so that you always keep track

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Currently we don't have a high level way to do it, so you'll have to construct the list of felts yourself: arrays are passed as: the length of the array followed by the array values.
For example, say a constructor takes (a: felt, b_len: felt, b: felt*, c: felt) and you want to pass a=11, b=[22,33], c=44. You should create the list [11, 2, 22, 33,44] where the 2 is the length of b

```

    syscall_ptr : felt*,
    pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*,
    range_check_ptr,
    }(
      constructor_calldata_size: felt,
      constructor_calldata: felt*
    ):
```
or is there still any way to construct the list inside of cairo?

Content: is this an external/view function?

Author: udayj.
Content: it is an external function

Author: Deleted User
Content: okay, I don't know what is an array received from an external or a view function

Author: Deleted User
Content: but in cairo I know two kinds of arrays

Author: Deleted User
Content: 1) the one created by alloc. It's a separate memory segment and you are free to write as much as you want in it. The pointer returned by alloc() is a pointer to a cell where you can write

Author: Deleted User
Content: this initial pointer can be seen as an array of size 0

Author: Deleted User
Content: 2) the one created with new, that you can't extend.

Author: Deleted User
Content: According to the docs, in this situation the values of the array are pushed to the stack, and a pointer to the first value added is returned

Author: Deleted User
Content: I think this value should be the location of ap at the moment the array was created

Author: Deleted User
Content: You can't extend arrays from a view or an external function, so they are probably added to the execution segment, like with new.

Author: Deleted User
Content: So unless they've done a specific code when the array is empty, the pointer probably points to the location of ap before calling the function

Author: Deleted User
Content: What do you think? @udayj

Author: udayj.
Content: What if the function takes in multiple arrays and more than 1 is empty... Do all pointers of such empty arrays point to the same location

Author: Deleted User
Content: Yeah I think that's likely. I they are written in the execution segment, I don't see what could be written on the stack between two arrays

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Weird... One thing that can explain it is that currently once a tx with a certain tx hash fails it will never retry it. So if you tried to invoke a tx and you didn't have enough balance for the fee, and then you move money to the account, you won't be able to send the exact tx again. You can either play with the parameters in such a case or send a dummy tx that will occupy the current nonce and then you'll be able to send the original tx with the next nonce.
This is of course just a temporary solution - in the future, such txs will be rejected before assinging a hash so this problem will disappear

Author: tarrence#4186
Content: Ah I see, I think that could have been the issue then

Author: .dpinones
Content:
Hi, does anyone know how get_caller_address() works or have a link to investigate?
I have a contract where I keep the balance per user.
If I call get_balance and pass the user address as a parameter, it works.
But if I call get_balance using get_caller_address it gives me 0 and I don't know why.
I gather that get_caller_address doesn't work for functions of type @view, but I'm not entirely sure.

Author: karmabull
Content:
How are you calling `get_balance` in the test suite? What's probably happening is the way you're calling it looks similar to `contract.get_balance().invoke()`, and by default the caller address is set to zero.

Try instead calling like this: `contract.get_balance().invoke(caller_address=addr)` where `addr` is the address you want it to be.

Author: 0x_rstm
Content:
**Hey StarkNet Community,**

We implemented a custom `ERC721Time` contract used in Lens Protocol Social Graph. 

Usual ERC721 contract stores only an owner of token. Mint timestamp is now stored in a TokenData struct alongside the owner address. It has 2 members: owner and mint_timestamp.

In order to port Lens contracts we rewrote the following functions: mint, transfer, burn. And created new get, set and view functions for TokenData struct. For example token_data_of, mint_timestamp_of, owner_of.

References:

https://github.com/aave/lens-protocol/blob/main/contracts/core/base/ERC721Time.sol
https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-721 

Your feedback is welcome!

https://gitlab.com/zk-graph/starknet-zkgraph-protocol/-/commit/0d7efb233d3d21cb273f5ab29425cfc03861700b (we are about to mirror our GitLab repo to GitHub).

Author: lucasstarkware
Content:
```py
func ERC20_initializer{syscall_ptr : felt*, pedersen_ptr : HashBuiltin*, range_check_ptr}(
    name : felt, symbol : felt, initial_supply : Uint256, recipient : felt, decimals : felt
):
    ERC20_name_.write(name)
    ERC20_symbol_.write(symbol)
    ERC20_decimals_.write(decimals)
    ERC20_mint(recipient, initial_supply)
    return ()
end
```
This will allow you to specify everything. Though your contract is not ownable so there's no point in passing an owner

Author: udayj.
Content: what is the difference between assert_lt and assert_lt_felt - The comments in math.cairo here https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/cairo/common/math.cairo say assert_lt_felt - Asserts that the unsigned integer lift (as a number in the range [0, PRIME)) of a is lower than that of b - but i can't understand what this means - could someone please share a pointer to help understand this

Author: milan3774
Content:
tl;dr: `assert_lt` works only on values up to 2**128 (range check bound), `assert_lt_felt` works on the whole felt range

if you want to dig deeper, check what the `split_felt` function does, which the latter assert uses internally and have a look at this holy scripture of Perama for more details https://perama-v.github.io/cairo/background/integer_lift/ üèãÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Author: vLDemonizer#9438
Content: Guys, how do you store an array in storage? and how do you handle removing a element for an array and updating the indexes?

Author: Deleted User
Content: Hey you need to create a storage variable which maps an index to a value

Author: Deleted User
Content: Because memory is immutable, removing a value that is not the last nor the first from your array will be expensive (you will have to create a whole new array)

Author: Deleted User
Content: If you want to often remove a value from a ¬´¬†stored¬†¬ª array, you might want to use a linked list. Writing complexity will be 2 instead of 1 but updating complexity will be in o(1) instead of o(n)

Author: grillo.eth
Content:
Hello everyone. I‚Äôm starting to look into building a game on StarkNet, where I would need 2+ users to take turns in calling a function. The input of one user would change depending on the input of the previous one. At some point, one of them would win the game. Let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs tic-tac-toe. The game is not real-time, but I‚Äôm looking for it to run as fast as possible from turn to turn.
I have some very basic questions about StarkNet, that someone might help me figure out:
1) The simplest design choice would seem to be to make every function call a state-changing transaction. Currently, on StarkNet Alpha, transactions take quite some time. I‚Äôm sure this will improve in the future, but I would like to know if there‚Äôs an estimate on how long a transaction might take to confirm in the future, and if this would be a viable path for a game like the one described above. A full match could easily take 500+ turns to complete.
2) A second design alternative could be to use a view function to receive signed user interactions and produce an output that would allow the next user to sign its next move, while saving all the steps off-chain. Once the game is finished, I could call a state-changing function that calls the view function recursively, once for every turn, until the winner is confirmed and stored. For this scenario: is there something like a ‚Äúgas limit‚Äù for StarkNet functions that I should take into account? Does this sound like a plausible solution?
3) I‚Äôve also read about SHARP, but if I understand correctly, SHARPs are independent from StarkNet, right? 
4) Is there any other more obvious design choice I could be missing?
Any info is welcome. Thank you!

Author: grillo.eth
Content:
So, after reading about Lightning and HTCL, I think I could:
1) Create a match registry on-chain with an initial timestamp and calculate a max_finish timestamp X minutes from then.
2) Have players call a view function on each turn, including the previous state (positions of all players and so on), turn number, and their signed move as inputs. The view function has the game logic. If it doesn't find a winner, it returns a new state, which would allow the next player to call the view function again, until a winner is found.
3) Each player stores the whole chain of actions. When a player wins, he can submit the whole list of actions to an external function, which verifies each step and finishes the game if the user really won. The first player to submit a whole chain of turns that finds him as the winner before max_finish would win.
4) A fraudulent move would be avoided because the user would not be able to provide a chain of valid movements that lead to him being the winner: the resulting state of the previous turn would not match up with input of the next turn. And he wouldn't be able to create new signed moves from other players to create additional moves that make him the winner.
5) If a player simply stops playing, I could make the last user who moved the winner, by a 'longest chain' rule after max_finish.
Basically, I use HTCL but instead of using a hash to unlock, I use a valid chain of signed turns. Do you find any error on this logic?

Author: grillo.eth
Content:
Just figured a player could simply leave the other waiting with their last turn and then submit a longer chain to win with one additional turn. So instead of a longer chain win, it should be longer chain challenge: at any moment a player can submit a chain of turns ending in his turn. If the next player doesn't answer within x minutes with a longer chain, that player is out. If he does provide a longer chain, the game resumes.
It's a little more complex than I would've liked, but it could work.

Author: tomorrowforsure.eth
Content: hey y'all, I'm wondering if someone has an explanation for the use of 0<x<2^128 when I'm already checking 0 < BOUND - x < 2^128 (https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/builtins.html?#range-checks). Seems to me that the use of 0<x<2^128 is not necessary

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Some comparisons cannot be done: you cannot compare two relocatable values of different segment, for example. This is because it's not well defined - it depends on the embedding of those segments to actual addresses.
For example, consider 1:10 and 3:1 - if segment 1 starts at address 100 and segment 3 starts at 109 the two relocatables will be 110 so they will be equal. But with different placement of the segments, they may point to different addresses.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
Check what happens when x is -1 (or PRIME - 1, which is the same value).
The check with BOUND will pass, but x is not in the range you wanted

Author: drasungor
Content:
Thank you very much, the questions are the following (sorry if it's too much, please answer only as much as you are comfortable with):
- Is all the data stored in memory? How do you manage to run programs with a lot of data "updates"? Do you send old data to disk to free up RAM?
- Which would be a way of using cairo for scientific calculations? These types of algorithms need floats but the felt integer divisions prevents us from using them. Is the standard to use a struct to represent a number with scientific notation?
- How sophisticated is the assert instruction? Does it assign a value to a previously unassigned value if we use a polynomial of degree greater than 1 (and the value is not set by a hint)? Which result would it use? We can take x squared - 1 = 0 as an example
- How do you manage memory allocation? All the used memory has to be continuous, so if you have to make a memory allocation then, taking into account that new variables will use memory that comes after the memory allocated, you either have to allocate a large amount of memory, have the memory fragmented (the end of a fragment is a pointer to another fragment of, for example, a list, i don't know how this would affect cache optimizations), or have redundant previous instances of the initialized memory after just resising like a normal memory chunk would be resized
- How expensive is actually runing something in Cairo? It surprises me that we are using python as an example of a fast language. Is the execution of code generating a proof so slow that the Amdahls Law determines that the lack of speed of python is worth it's ease of usage?
- Is all memory initialized with 0?
- Are all variables a version of a mapping? I don't see in ex3 a place in which user_counters_storage is initialized as one. Is the felt treated as a mapping with a unique undefined key? The code that made me question this is the following: https://github.com/starknet-edu/starknet-cairo-101/blob/main/contracts/ex03.cairo

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
The bytecode is created by the compiler and it is parsed both in the runner in order to generate the trace for the proof, and by the Cairo AIR itself.
The behavior of all the flag is explained in section 4 of the Cairo white paper. Examples which shows how each flag can be used to get meaningful operations is given in section 5.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
For example, op0reg controls whether op0 is ap or fp based (e.g., `[ap + 3]` vs `[fp + 3]`). op0 is the left operand of the instruction. For example, in `[ap] = [ap + 3] + 4`, op0 is `[ap + 3]`
If you're not familiar with ap/fp/the assembly syntax, I recommend giving over the first few pages of the "How Cairo Works" tutorial

Author: tarrence#4186
Content: @Lior Goldberg would starknet be open to adding whitelisted hints for `secp256r1` similar to what exists for `secp256k1`? In order to support secure enclaves and webauthn. We've implemented webauthn credential verification in cairo but the P256 signature verification is quite expensive. This would allow users to authorize transactions using FIDO2 hardware keys (i.e. face id, finger print, yubi key, ect) and make onboarding users to starknet with self custodial wallets incredible simple. Kobi / geometry are looking into improving efficiency but I imagine the best approach would be adding similar hints to whats used for `secp256k1`

Author: drasungor
Content: Hi, if I'm not mistaken, that is because the ap changed it's value from the second to the third instruction. So, for example, if ap was 1, then [ap - 1] = [1 - 1] = [0], you are assigning a value to the cell in address 0, after that the instruction ap++ is executed, which is equivalent to ap = ap + 1, so ap changes it's value to 2. Then on the next line you assign a value to the memory address ap - 1, which is 2 - 1 = 1, you can see that, while before you were assigning a value to the address 0, now you are assigning to the address 1 even though you are still using ap - 1, so what you are implying is not happening. Sorry if I misunderstood the question.

for a function that returns two values (tuple) how to I accept it ?

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Instructions are either 1 or 2 field elements. They are 2 when there's an immediate value (as in [ap+3]=5 - 5 is the immediate value). In this case the second word is the immediate which is not 63 bits (it's an arbitrary field element).

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: By the way, the large hex numbers are simply negative values

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Re. prog start and end - in general, you need to specify where your program starts and where it should end. However, if your program is proved by being called from another program (which is what we do), then you only need to specify where the `main()` function is. Once `main()` returns you know that you program was completed succesfully

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content:
It depends whether the function returns two values or a tuple of two values.
In the case of two values:
```
func foo() -> (x: felt, y: felt):
end

let (x, y) = foo()
```
And for a tuple:
```
func foo() -> (res: (felt, felt)):
end

let (pair) = foo()
let x = pair[0]
let y = pair[1]
```

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: You should construct an array of 64-bit numbers. You have functions that can help with that, such as `keccak_add_uint256` which adds 4 64-bit values from one `Uint256`. Then you should call `keccak_bigend` and finally `keccak_finalize` (without calling finalize, it may seem like it works, but it's not sound)

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: Constructing the array may be annoying if you have a mix of ints of different sizes. If you only have uint256's, it's much simpler - you can just call `keccak_uint256s_bigend`.

Author: Lior Goldberg#6041
Content: BTW, you'll want to use the bigend version (both inputs and outputs) to be solidity compatible (IIRC)

Author: feltroidprime
Content:
Please explain what inputs you have and what length they are in bytes.
If you have a of 28 bytes and b of 32 bytes, and you want to compute the hash of a and b concatenated , keccak will add padding at a to make it 32 bytes.

You may need to split b into 4+28 bytes and add the first 4 bytes of b at the end of a. Only the last input can be less than 32 bytes because you can specify n_bytes in keccak. Same principles with 8 bytes felts. Mp me if you need help

Author: kalzak
Content:
Is it possible to have revoked references in a compiled StarkNet contract?
In just the Cairo language alone apparently it's possible by using explicit relative jumps: https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/how_cairo_works/consts.html#revoked-references

I'm wondering if it's possible to have "silent" revoked references in StarkNet somehow, is that possible?

Author: udayj.
Content:
how is overflow in multiplication handled in cairo
for eg. if i have function like 
```@view
func mult{range_check_ptr} (x : felt, y: felt) -> (res : felt):
    let res = x*y
    return (res)
end
```

and i call mult(-1,-1) how is overflow handled - because "-1" is actually "0x0800000000000011000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000" in felt representation but the function returns the correct value 1

Author: Deleted User
Content: there is no overflow because operations are done in a field

Author: Deleted User
Content:
that's like doing operations modulo P.
-1 = P-1 so

Author: udayj.
Content: Ya... Just realized that... Thanks for the algebra üòÉ

Author: Drew_#0452
Content: nah figured it out

Author: Drew_#0452
Content: basicaly I'm using `hash_ptr` in a few calls

Author: Drew_#0452
Content: and that isn't rebinding `pedersen_ptr`

Author: Drew_#0452
Content: so I have to explicitly pass in `my_func{pedersen_ptr=hash_ptr}(...)` to get it to rebind

Author: Drew_#0452
Content: also if you're using a `with hash_ptr` you have to rebind it at the end e.g. `let pedersen_ptr = hash_ptr`

Author: codyx42
Content:
Make sure that your function *also* has the implicit parameter `range_check_ptr`. It has to be specified in the func declaration.
Such as:
```
func my_fn{range_check_ptr : felt}():
```

Author: pilou_sekai
Content:
Hello, I didn't find any way to batch migrate contracts (in a specific directory) to the new Cairo syntax so here is a small script I made to do so :
```
#!/usr/bin/env bash

find . -type f | grep .cairo > cairo_files.txt

cat cairo_files.txt | while read file
do
    echo "" >> "$file"
    cairo-migrate -i $file
done
```
Hope it can help some people üôÇ

Author: milan3774
Content: `ids.loc_list` is the `loc_list` variable in your cairo code (outside the hint), `loc_list` is the variable in python, inside the hint, `segments.add()` creates a new memory segment (similar to `alloc`) to which you can write and returns the beginning of it

Author: Henri#6408
Content:
Hey, someone asked a question similar yesterday, here's what  I told him
In a nutshell:
The verifier is currently used (and usable) only by us, for two reasons 
1. there are no other prover software around, and ours is not public yet
2. verifying has a cost, and agregating programs to prove them makes much more sense economically

so SHARP is our Shared Prover, and it can receive and prove any cairo program

these proofs are then sent to the sharp verifier on L1

and the outputs of the cairo programs can be used on L1

But, Starknet currently also uses Sharp. 
So any programyou send to sharp will end up being verified on L1 probable around the same time StarkNet blocs get verified on L1

Author: david_mitesh#4616
Content: The question is quite longüòÖ, but I am searching this answer for about a week now. From docs, what I understood is cairo‚Äôs actual need of addition to the blockchain paradigm  is that , it helps to execute complex business logic on the inputs offchain instead of today‚Äôs case, where whole business logic is in the smart contract on chain itself thus making it unscalable and storage inefficient. So, this implies that, if we are to implement a AAVE equivalent in starknet, then states will be handled in the onchain contract( in L1) and we will mimic the similar execution logic like that of aave solidity contract in cairo(off-chain). So, if a user now wants to  call a deposit function through cairo contract , along with the inputs which the function needs, he(or the dapp ui ) needs to pass in the current state of the AAVE contract which is in mainnet?  Because that is state what we will be applying our business logic on. And during the construction of the proof, we will have initial state  and the final state after the execution of business logic on user inputs and that will be registered on the Fact Registry contract and finally the AAVE on the L1 can call isValid on the Fact registry and include that state transition in its state.  If we maintain the state in the cairo contract as well, what is the guarantee that it is always synchronized with the one on the L1 chain? If we only allow the users to  make the transactions through the cairo path, then it is possible I think. But if it done to support current implementation as well, then how this whole architecture can be formed?

Author: lucasstarkware
Content: Everything is executed on chain (StarkNet is a blockchain). If you want to build AAVE on StarkNet you can keep the same architecture they have on L1

Author: sa.bur.o
Content:
Just saw this in Cairo v0.10 docs: "support using functions as expressions"
Can anyone explain how does that work exactly? any example would be very helpful

Author: thanhtx
Content: can you point to specific location in docs?

Author: sa.bur.o
Content: It's mentioned here: https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/releases/tag/v0.10.0#:~:text=Support%20using%20functions%20as%20expressions

Author: karmabull
Content:
It means doing things like 
```
let x = foo(y) + z;
let a = foo(bar(b));
```
etc.

Note that it currently only works for functions that return a felt (not a tuple) with a known ap change, which means no recursive functions, and no if statements (mostly. I think certain if-statements work but I haven't tried it myself)

Author: vargastartup#1355
Content:
I'm very curious: does Cairo have any logic operators? I found bitwise_or bitwise_and etc. but it is not wokring if I want to do something like

if (x == y) OR (x == -y) { ... }

Author: karmabull
Content:
Only `and` is currently supported in if-statements. If you want to get `or` then in this case you can do
```
if ((x - y) * (x + y) == 0) {...}
```
Then, if x == y then the first factor will be zero (and therefore the entire expression will be zero), and if x == -y then the second factor will be zero, so it basically functions like an `or`

Author: karmabull
Content: That's just what the Cairo instruction set allows (or rather, doesn't allow). Sections 4-5.2 of the cairo whitepaper cover possible instructions. As for the exact reason it's this way, I don't know :). But if I had to guess, it probably has to do with tradeoffs (e.g., enabling this would cause each instruction to take up more space, or use more trace cells, for relatively little gain, or something like that)

Author: drasungor
Content: Hi, I've been studying starks and cairo and I have a question about the code's execution proof. How does the verifier know that the constraints apply specificly to the bytecode he sent to execute to the prover (and not another program that the prover decided to execute)? I guess one could check the bytecode itself and each instruction to see if it corresponds to what is expected but that would have a linear time instead of a polynomial logarithm time

Author: karmabull
Content: During execution of a Cairo program, the bytecode is loaded into memory, and is therefore included in the execution trace (constraints)

Author: drasungor
Content: Yes, thank you for your answer, I was aware of that, sorry if I was not clear enough. My question pointed more to how do we know that those constraints apply to the code that we wanted to execute and not some other bytecode. We cannot check the address of the instruction each constraint tries to validate because if we did that then the verification would be O(n) in trace cells or constraints amounts

Author: Deleted User
Content: From what I understood it works using a polynomial commitment. The committer can prove that the value of the polynomial at a certain point z satisfies P(z) = a through a proof without revealing the polynomial P.

Author: Deleted User
Content: This is an explanation of how it works with Starks: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gd1NbKUOJwA

Author: Deleted User
Content: I haven't studied it yet but I have to do it this week for school so I could help you if you want

Author: drasungor
Content: Thank you for your offer, but if I'm not mistaken this is not related to FRI. What I don't understand is, even if the prover gets to prove that the result comes from a valid program execution. How does the verifier know that execution comes from the bytecode that produces the execution that he wants to verify? Unless you are implying that the bytecode gets translated to a polynomial and used as part of the proof

Author: Deleted User
Content: Yeah kind of

Author: Deleted User
Content: In this example, they want to compute the 1023th number of a specific squared Fibonacci sequence, and to do so they create a trace.

Author: Deleted User
Content: This trace contains all the numbers computed to reach this 1023 number

Author: Deleted User
Content: Then they chose a set of constraints that they express as polynomials, basically:

Author: Deleted User
Content: - first and second element of the trace are correct

Author: Deleted User
Content: - all element of the trace is equals to the squared sum of the two previous

Author: Deleted User
Content: They will translate that set of constraints into a different problem where you need to prove that a rational polynomial is a polynomial. I think that‚Äôs what they are going to commit

Author: Deleted User
Content: With cairo I guess it‚Äôs the same idea, except your trace is the stack and you have other instructions like jump instead of just square summing.

Author: Deleted User
Content: Oh and the trace is also ¬´¬†converted¬†¬ª to a polynomial, where all x is an element of a sub group of the size of the trace and all y is just the value you are interested in. They interpolate those points. I remember they said you need to compute the merkle root of it, but I think the FRI video should help us

Author: Jimothy#8368
Content:
Could you explain more what you mean here? If we stop reading to save felt values at any point then we don't capture the entirety of whatever `felt*` is pointing to. I wanted to change it so each token had its own metadata uri, so somehow build a mapping of tokenId -> tokenUri. For every URI, because of the above, we need to have a way to store the length, and then a way to store the value **at each index of the byte array**, if we stop early then we don't have a complete picture. 

Because of this behaviour, we would need a set of these two mappings for every single token.

Author: .dpinones
Content:
Hey, we are implementing a solution to the path finding problem on a map represented by a 2d grid.
The map is n*m in size, the algorithm we chose to solve this problem is called jump point search, which is characterized by the pruning of non-relevant cases.
The implementation is still in progress and while testing a method on testnet we encountered the following problem:
For instances where n=50 and m=50 (values that should be easily solved) we get the following error.
StarknetErrorCode.OUT_OF_RESOURCES.
The question related to this would be: what is the limit of steps and the memory capacity that is given in a transaction (we read that in testnet the limit of steps is 500k, is it correct?)
We are worried about having a stack overflow because of the amount of recursive calls that are executed inside the algorithm.
Where can we read more about this to understand the tools we have? thanks.

Author: parkyeung.eth
Content:
Hi guys I have two questions: 

1. Why are dictionaries referenced by the location of their last memory cell rather than the first? This makes it difficult to keep track of the location of the dictionary as it continues to grow in size (I'm trying to cast the DictAccess* as a felt but the address becomes outdated every time the dictionary updates).

2. Why does reading a dictionary add to its size? What is the point of adding a new dictionary entry for reading (where the value does not change)?

Author: feltroidprime
Content:
1: you should keep both the beginning and the end of the dict. See the link of the square grid code a few messages above. 
2. Both read and write operations involves a hint and implies to write a value to ensure the read value was correctly reported by the prover when the  dict is finally squashed.
See https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo-lang/blob/master/src/starkware/cairo/common/dict.cairo

Author: _dsi
Content:
Hey guys, how do you handle inheritance in StarkNet contracts ? For example I have two contract that have the same functions at core and each contract then implement new functions on top. 
I thought about making a library and importing functions from there, but those core functions read storage variables, and I don't think you can store variable in a namespace/library. 

I thought about making a third contract that store/read those variables to remove any storage from the namespace, and then import those logic only functions, but it's kind of inconvenient to call variables everytime so I was wondering if there was another solution if you have core functions shared amongst many contracts ?

Author: whatthedev
Content: Not sure if this helps, but what about import your logic only functions from another contract, then have a function here with the sole purpose of calling one of those logic only functions?

Author: _dsi
Content: Hmm the thing is that it'll be an AMM, and this logic in in pairs and there will be multiple pair deployed from a factory. I'm scared it's cumbersome and prone to error in this situation but I may be wrong, what do you think ? Still a good idea in this situation ?

Author: eni7912
Content: You cannot  recreate inheritance but  the extensibility pattern is the closest possible

Hey, I looked into it last week. I found a Schnorr subgroup of the Field used by Starknet but I think it is too small to be used for anything in real life. If it ever helps someone, I found:
```
q = 166_848_103
r = 21687407429895269553632999849540213865201135761978646529610780508160
h = 2
```
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schnorr_group/

So I guess you won't be able to do it using cairo native operations üò¶

Author: sergioargent
Content: Hi there üëã  Is there a way to make an inner call revert while letting the outer call run? A use case would be to have a multicall where some of the calls might fail. This is possible in solidity but i don't see how it can be done with Cairo. Any ideas?

Author: milan3774
Content: no, that's currently not possible in Cairo; will be with Cairo 1.0, where you can return a Rust Result like enum

Author: sergioargent
Content: besides returning an error, will the inner call revert?

Author: milan3774
Content: if it reverts, the whole multicall fails üò¶

Author: sergioargent
Content: oh, then it won't work for the use case i wanted. I still need to continue if one of the call in the multicall fails

Author: sergioargent
Content: another use case for the same feature will be this https://github.com/safe-global/safe-contracts/blob/c36bcab46578a442862d043e12a83fec41143dec/contracts/common/StorageAccessible.sol#L36 So running a transaction, reverting it but returning it's data

Author: Kong#4844
Content: HI guys! I'm learning about cairo right now, but I don't know what is difference between `let` and `tempvar` can anyone explain this for me?

Author: Deleted User
Content: Tempvar will compute the expression and add it to the stack, the compiler will then keep track of its location compared to ap. Afaik with let the expression will be recomputed every time you use it.

Author: Deleted User
Content: A tempvar is basically:

Author: Deleted User
Content:
assert [ap+1] = your expression, ap++;
let your_name = [ap-1];

Author: Kong#4844
Content: Thank you for your kind answer. it's really helpful!! can you explain what is difference between `local var`  and `let (local var)` too?? üòÖ üòÖ

Author: Deleted User
Content: You are welcome. I think the only difference is it doesn't take the same expression. The second one will take a tuple of one value (usually returned by a function) and split it in one value.

Author: Kong#4844
Content: wow, Thank you @Deleted User! learned a lot!

Author: 0xgiwook
Content: I'm just asking because I'm not sure, is it `assert [ap+1]`? not`assert [ap]`?

Author: Deleted User
Content: Hmm I think you are right, iirc ap points to the last cell not used from the stack, so that must be assert [ap]

Author: 0xChicken#7060
Content: hmm ok think I'm not phrasing the question correctly. I got confused by the docs which state different ranges for felts. one is signed `-P/2 < x < P/2` and other is unsigned `0 < x < P`. you're saying the finite field is actually unsigned? so `0-1 = P-1` rather than `0-1 = -1`

Author: aurelou
Content: Yeah it's equal to -1 mod P

Author: aurelou
Content: which is P - 1

Author: Deleted User
Content: You can see a field as a set of equivalence classes. In a finite field, you have a finite number of these classes. You can put any integer into one of these classes, and to represent an element of your Field, you can take an element that belongs to its class (often we take the smallest positive integer, sometimes the smallest signed number).

Author: Deleted User
Content: For example, you can consider the finite field Z/3Z, its size is 3, which contains 3 classes of equivalence

Author: Deleted User
Content: Here I used the smallest positive integer to represent the equivalence class, to find the equivalence class of an integer you can divide it by the field size (so 3 here) and take the rest.

Author: Deleted User
Content: This means that adding or removing the field size to a field element is not going to change the element, because this like adding 0.

Author: Deleted User
Content: If you take the field element 1 and substract 3, you'll get -2, which is still the same field element

Author: Deleted User
Content: I think you can try it, adding something like :

Author: Deleted User
Content: It's up to you to consider how you want to represent your numbers, but be careful with felt native operations.

Author: sergioargent
Content:
Hi there! I'm trying to understand a bit better how to work with felts. I run some fuzzing on the method `starkware.cairo.common.math_cmp.is_le` and i found some unexpected results. Here are some examples of what i found:
```
3618502788666131213697322783095070105623107215331596699973092056135872020480 <= 0 returned True
0 <= 340282366920938463463374607431768211457 returned False
-1 <= 1809251394333065606848661391547535052811553607665798349986546028067936010239 returned False
-1809251394333065606848661391547535052811553607665798349986546028067936010240 <= 0 returned False
```

is there any reason to return values like this?

Author: t.aksoy
Content:
There are some ranges for this function. Your values probabl bigger than RANGE_CHECK_BOUND(2^128).
You can use `is_le_felt`
> `// Returns 1 if a <= b (or more precisely 0 <= b - a < RANGE_CHECK_BOUND).
> // Returns 0 otherwise.
> func is_le{range_check_ptr}(a, b) -> felt `

Author: sergioargent
Content: Why would someone prefer tu use `is_le` if the other function works for every number? Is it expensive to call?

Author: t.aksoy
Content:
Probably, I am not sure. I didnt check it. 
But you should use `is_le_felt` for external inputs

Author: closer2282
Content:
Here's the reply :
In Cairo, everything is a felt.
So depending on how you represent the string, you‚Äôll probably have to convert each digit of his tokenId to the relevant ascii represenation of that digit.
EG ‚Äú0‚Äù in Ascii is ‚Äú38" in decimal.
So for token ‚Äú10‚Äù you will have to convert it to a felt array with [48, 38] with a recursive function and divisions
And you can look at the Open Zeppelin implementation to check how it is coded
https://discord.com/channels/793094838509764618/793094838987128844/923695315649970208

Author: grumpus#0426
Content:
Ok so I got it to work. Here is what I did.

1. Went to https://goerli.starkgate.starknet.io/
2. Swapped to Goerli network
3. Connected a wallet via metamask with some goerli eth
4. Created a new wallet using Braavos chrome extension
5. Transferred some goerli eth from first wallet to new wallet
6. Deployed the newly created wallet with the transferred funds from Braavos
7. Back in terminal, opened the `~/.starknet_accounts` file
8. Added an entry for the new account including public/private key and address which I retrieved from braavos.  For salt I just used the salt of one of the other entries
9. Deployed the contract successfuly by specifying the new account with the `--account` flag

Author: grumpus#0426
Content: Looking now at the `~/.starknet_accounts` files, there is also a `deployed` flag on the accounts, potentially could have set that to `false` manually, added more funds to the account I created from the CLI, and tried using that account again

Author: 0xmur
Content:
Hi, how do I get the storage slot of a mapping which has a struct as its key?
like mentioned here: https://www.cairo-lang.org/docs/hello_starknet/cli.html#get-storage-at
> Later on, at the user authentication section, you will see a generalization of storage variables, which allows, for example, having a balance variable for each user. This will require minor adjustments to the code above, which we will review in the relevant section.

Author: wind.rider
Content: ser,i've consulted with dev advocates and will contact you immediately if there's any reply, thank youü§ù

Author: 0xmur
Content: Thank you very much!!!

Author: closer2282
Content:
To compute this key, run the following Python code:
```from starkware.starknet.public.abi import get_storage_var_address

balance_key = get_storage_var_address('balance')
print(f'Balance key: {balance_key}')```

Author: 0xmur
closer2282
Content: I think through ```@storage_var```, add it to change the balance storage variable to a map from public key (user) to balance (instead of a single value)? But i'm not a dev, you can wait the reply from our dev advocates

Author: closer2282
Content: As the document says, use the @storage_var decorator to create maps

Author: 0xmur
Content: Nope, we don't need storage_var to create a struct type

Author: closer2282
Content: The struct contains storage_var , but it's okay, you can wait for the reply from our dev advocates, thanks for your patience!

Author: wind.rider
Content:
ser,pls try this:From Cairo: use `storage_var_name(args).addr()`
From python: use ` get_storage_var_address('storage_var_name', struct_field1, struct_field2, ...)` pls check it,thank you

gm guys.

- At this stage what is better to learn/test/test with community: 0.1 or wait for 1.0?

Author: wind.rider
Content:
Yes,ser, you can start using cairo1.0 now, as it's already open source: https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo (but is not available on the testnet right now, as the integration on the testnet is now v0.10.3) you can now start experimenting with basic Cairo 1.0 code, besides here are 2 articles about it, if you are interested pls check first: https://medium.com/starkware/open-sourcing-cairo-1-0-b3100a664bb0
https://medium.com/starkware/cairo-1-0-aa96eefb19a0 at this stage, it's up to you own to learn/test the current cairo (v0.10.3) or 1.0, but already planned to start integrating cairo 1.0 soon (see: https://medium.com/starkware/starknet-regenesis-the-plan-bd0219843ef4), thank youü§ù

Author: 0xandee
Content: I ran into the problem while implementing `approve` function from ETH contract on testnet, the problem is the `approve` event emitted is from ERC721 which is in form of `event Approval(owner,approved,tokenId` , not ERC20 which should be `event Approval(owner,spender,value)`. Here is my function in image attached, do you guys see any thing wrong with it?

Author: lastsurvivor21
Content: Is there a rule of thumb to know how many cairo steps makes it worth it to use cairo instead of solidity? Let's say my program does 5'000 steps, would that cost a lot in solidity?

Author: milan3774
Content:
always use Cairo (StarkNet) over Solidity (L1) üòÅ 

I'd say that's a wrong question to ask, because you're comparing ecosystems, kinda depends on what you want to do, what are you building...

either way, 5000 steps is nothing, it's 250 gas, see here for an overview of computation costs https://docs.starknet.io/documentation/architecture_and_concepts/Fees/fee-mechanism/

Author: technovision99
Content: I'm not exactly sure where to ask this because it's not exactly language specific, but when runner generates the witness, does the AIR operate on this witness to generate polynomial constraints? And then from there when you actually want to use the STARK protocol, do you take the execution trace values, interpolate it to another polynomial, and then start to extend/commit/FRI? I guess I am confused as to what the AIR is specifically used for and how that actually relates to STARK, I understand you need to have polynomial constraints, but do those constraints come from the AIR? If so what is the need for interpolation?

Author: closer2282
Content:
For a Cairo program, The polynomial constraints for Cairo are common for everyone. The runner generates the trace using the constraints that define Cairo.
An AIR is a set of polynomial constraints; Cairo is an AIR.
You can understand more through STARK-101
https://starkware.co/stark-101/

Author: pierre_emmanuel
Content: Hello. I am working on a contract to contract interaction. I am calling an entrypoint that triggers an event. Can I read this event from the calling contract ?

Author: 0xcoburn
Content:
No the calling contract can only read the returned value from the invoked function, not the event.
events are mostly used by indexers and then dapps to provide users with feedback

Author: closer2282
Content:
May i ask what's the entire error message? Maybe you can check this issue first

> Issue 2. 
> If you are seeing 
> Error message: Proxy: caller is not admin
> Error at pc=0:302:
> An ASSERT_EQ instruction failed: 0 != 
> 
> This means that you likely recovered your Argent wallet in another StarkNet wallet (e.g. Braavos), and this would have changed the contract. We are working on a fix and thank you for your patience. In the meantime, a workaround would be to either use that other wallet, or create a new Argent wallet and send the assets from the old one to the new address. If you can't use the wallet in another extension, please reach out to their support team for help.

I want to do something like this :
- Define an interface as a struct which takes functions pointers as members
```rust
struct MyInstance {
  function1:felt*,
  function2:felt*
}
```
- Define abstract functions for the interface, taking the interface implementation as an argument and calling the implementation function

```rust
func function1(instance:MyInstance, parameter:MyInput){
  // call instance.function1 with parameter as input 
}
```
- Import the arguments from their respective files
```rust
# file_1
struct MyInput{
  member_a:felt,
  member_b:felt,
}
==========
# file_2
struct MyInput{
  member_a:felt,
  member_b:felt,
  member_c:felt,
}
```

The problem is that if `function1` expects type `file_1.MyInput` it's not going to work with `file_2.MyInput`. I only want to use it as a redirection to the implementation function though...
cc @Lucas | StarkWare, do you have something I can look into?

Author: lajosd
Content:
Hello!
Can someone tell me what are my options if I want to pass a large byte sequence into a function?
The max size for a `felt` is 252 bits, so it won't fit.
I could of course use multiple felts if I know the size of the byte sequence in advance, but what if I don't?
In solidity we have `bytes`. What are my options here?

Author: lajosd
Content:
What I have in mind is this:
`func test(array_len: felt, array: felt*)`

So I'd cut my byte sequence into 252bit chunks, pass the number into `array_len`, and the chunks into `array`

Feels kinda hacky, is this the only way to do this rn?

Author: quentinspaceshard
Content:
Hello 
I would like to know what is the len of an address on Starknet ? 
I mean for exemple I have this address 0xa7326e15e3aef7e20285a20c6b4f90d982203d537f144df980fa64dca49a3d which is 62 char 
if an address should be 64 char (32 bytes) it will means that the correct address is 0x00a7326e15e3aef7e20285a20c6b4f90d982203d537f144df980fa64dca49a3d and Cairo juste remove the first two 0 . Am I correct ?
Also what's the encryption algorithm used to generate the private key ?

Author: milan3774
Content: address is a numerical value, not a string so those two representations are equivalent, same as  0xa and 0x00a are; since everything is a `felt`, an address cannot be 32 bytes; as for the algo, have a look here https://docs.starknet.io/documentation/architecture_and_concepts/Contracts/contract-address/ hth

Author: scarletssstarktitan
Content:
find this answer for you   
In Solidity (L1), you can create a payload to send a message on L2 with strings by using the `abi.encodePacked` function. This function takes a list of parameters and encodes them into a byte array. For example, if you wanted to send a message with two strings, you could use the following code: [source,js] ---- let message_payload = abi.encodePacked(string1, string2);

            L2ContractAddress,
            CLAIM_SELECTOR,
            payload
        );```

Author: wind.rider
Content:
ser,I would try using a `local` variable instead of `let` when having function calls between the reference creation and its usage to avoid revoked references which could be the problem here even if the error message doesn't say so explicitly.
```let (local to_return_temp) = alloc();```

Author: orleg#6795
Content: thank! its works, can you please explain again when should i use local? or give me any reference so i could read? thanks!

Content: let me check with the team,serü§ù

Author: epizeuxius
Content:
How does the call_contract() handle caller address?

Elaboration: 
We have a modular smart contract which receives all calls and it calls specific libraries through library_call. One of these modules can interact with a separate modular smart contract which is used for integrations. Integration smart contract then again uses library calls to call its modules. We want some functions of integration smart contract to only be called by the owner of the 1st smart contract so we use assert_only_owner() but the value it is returning in get_caller_address() in assert_only_owner() is that of the user so this check is failing.

The logic is designed on the basis of msg.sender handling in solidity, need to confirm if call_contract() works the same way like call in solidity and not like delegatecall.

Author: wind.rider
Content: @santamariaSer, about your question from yesterday,pls check: When having an if statement, your program has two possible branches. The branch that ultimately gets used can only be known at runtime, not at compile time. That's why the compiler can't resolve the reference, not even with the alloc_locals trick. thank you

Author: epizeuxius
Content:
Is there any way to differentiate between Account contracts and possibly malicious attacker accounts?

For example in Solidity you can limit external interaction by checking extcodesize to ensure interaction is not coming from a contract or using ercrecover to ensure caller is an EOA and not a contract.

Is there a similar functionality available in Cairo? Can we check class hash of account for example if it is similar to popular or standard account implementations.
Or if in any way the above concerns could be addressed with ERC165 or in any other manner in Cairo

Author: wind.rider
Content:
Ser,there is no exhaustive way to do this, no. Account contracts are contracts, they are part of this bigger set.
A contract is an account contract if it implements certain functions. But you can add any function you like.
Now, a non exhaustive way would be to indeed check the class hash of the caller contract. We don‚Äôt have this syscall yet(still confirming),but it‚Äôs on the to do list

Author: jason_lious
Content:
Hi, some developers had met errors to setup cairo env with `cairo-lang-0.10.3`  ,
the most of the errors are cause by `typeguard` and `web3` version,In the newly version ,cairo-lang had limited typeguard version to less than 3.0.0,But do not limit web3 version,I had make a pr to fix this.

Author: 0xcoburn
Content: Cairo1 will greatly improve the DX, i‚Äôd checkout the starklings cairo1 tutorial

Author: pilou_sekai
Content: Well, everything that is on-chain is public. You can run encryption algorithms on-chain but all the inputs (private key for the algo, salt, ...) will be public so there's no privacy/security. Everyone will be able to decrypt your data **if** you encrypt it via a smart contract

Author: ten3#6234
Content:
In STARKNET, it is necessary to register a class using the "starknet declare" command before deploying it using "starknet deploy". The "class_hash" is generated during the "declare" process, so please check the output of the "starknet declare" command first.

Please refer to the following URL for more details:
https://docs.starknet.io/documentation/getting_started/deploying_contracts/#declare_a_contract_class
https://docs.starknet.io/documentation/architecture_and_concepts/Contracts/contract-classes/

Author: glihm
Content:
Cairo compiler supports plugins, to parse and process the Cairo code. Starknet plugin for instance is a plugin of the compiler to support contracts. üëç 
And I was thinking of a plugin for a project idea, but at the end I change my mind as plugins rewrite code but not in the way I was expecting so.. It would be better using some parsing adhoc (outside the compiler for my specific case).

Thanks for taking the time to answer!

Author: _mahlukat
Content:
Yo Everyone, 

Does anyone know how can i perform the equivalent of the following code in cairo 0. 

```
const msgHash5 = typedData.getMessageHash(typedDataValidate, accountAddress);
```

Source of above code:
https://www.starknetjs.com/docs/guides/signature/#sign-and-verify-following-eip712

Author: glihm
Content:
You have to chain keccak hash, on the same fields and the same order as shown in your js object.
This is done like this because the syscall to sign with ECDSA only takes a felt as input, so the best way to have a good hash, is chaining keccak. üôÇ

Here you have an example: https://github.com/mintsquare/marketplace-cairo0-contracts/blob/main/contracts/marketplace/SignatureChecker2.cairo

Author: glihm
Content:
Playing a bit with this tonight, and literally it‚Äôs a proxy by itself ahah it‚Äôs an amazing syscall.

Just calling it (with some extra check), you just swap your implementation and the storage is conserved. So beautiful.

Indeed, as the storage is mapped to an address, and the address is mapped to the clash hash, well this call swap the latter, and it‚Äôs ready to be executed with the new call. So nice. üî•

Author: martriay
Content:
hey there NFT implementers, users, minters, and enjoooyers: a big decision is coming and we need your input! (believe me, you want to voice your opinion)

we at OpenZeppelin are trying to understand how to deal with the ERC165 -> SRC5 migration and whatever we decide will have major consequences on any newly minted ERC721 token

tl;dr is: do we want cheap, released-sooner vs complex but retrocompatible ERC721 contracts?

https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/cairo-contracts/discussions/640

Author: kontrol_oopa
Content: can someone tell me the difference between `#[starknet::contract]` and `[contract]` annotaions ? i guess the first one is the correct (preferred) syntax but the second one also compiles afaik. Are they from different versions of the language, if yes i would like to know which ones .

Author: glihm
Content:
`#[contract]` is the deprecated attribute, it was replaced by `#[starknet::contract]`. No difference. üôÇ
Consider using only the new one, `#[starknet::contract]` as a future version may remove the deprecated one.

https://github.com/starkware-libs/cairo/blob/f42b647f8f90b4051d82aaf9114066feebf5cd70/corelib/src/zeroable.cairo#L3
